3-3-11: MINORS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Presence Of Underage Persons In Establishments: A licensee or any
officer, associate, member, representative, agent, or employee of a licensee
shall be prohibited from permitting a person under the age of twenty one (21)
years to enter and remain in that portion of a licensed premises that sells,
gives, or delivers alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises. No
prohibition under this subsection, however, shall apply to any licensed
premises, such as, without limitation, a restaurant or food shop, where
selling, giving, or delivering alcoholic liquor is not the principal business
of the licensee at those premises. In addition to any other penalty imposed for
violations of this chapter, a minimum fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) and
a maximum fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) shall be imposed for
violations of this subsection.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Underage Persons Frequenting Establishments Or Purchasing Or Receiving
Liquor: It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty one (21)
years to knowingly frequent any dramshop where alcoholic beverages are sold or
to purchase any alcoholic beverages, whether for consumption on the premises or
in package form for consumption off the premises. Any person under the age of
twenty one (21) years who knowingly frequents any dramshop wherein intoxicating
beverages are sold shall be subject to a minimum fine of one hundred dollars
($100.00) and a maximum fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) shall be
imposed for violations of this subsection.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Notification Of Guardians: When any person under the age of twenty one
(21) years is charged as a delinquent child, the department of police shall
notify the parent, guardian or legal representative when to appear before the
juvenile court of the county, wherein the minor's case will be heard.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Unlawful To Serve Underage Persons: It shall be unlawful for any
licensee, manager for the licensee or any other person in charge of the
premises or employed by the licensee or manager to sell, give away, deliver or
offer any alcoholic beverage to a person under the age of twenty one (21)
years. In addition to any other penalty imposed for violations of this chapter,
a minimum fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) and a maximum fine of seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) shall be imposed for violations of this
subsection. For the purposes of preventing the violation of this subsection,
all licensees, agents or employees must refuse to sell or serve alcoholic
beverages to any person who is unable to produce adequate written evidence of
identity and of the fact that such person is over the age of twenty one (21)
years. For purposes of this subsection, a nonoperator's identification card
issued by this state or any other identification wherein proof of age is not
required for the issuance of the identification card is not competent evidence
of age and may not be relied upon by any licensee, his employee or agent in any
transaction. (Ord. 09-58, 11-16-2009)
3-3-12: SALE TO INTOXICATED PERSONS, HABITUAL DRUNKARDS:
No licensee nor any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or
employee of such licensee shall sell, give or deliver alcoholic liquor to any
intoxicated person or to any person known by him to be a habitual drunkard,
spendthrift, insane, mentally ill, mentally deficient or in need of medical
treatment. (1987 Code)
3-3-13: VIOLATIONS, PENALTY:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any person who manufactures, imports for distribution or use, or
distributes or sells alcoholic liquor at any place within the village without
having first obtained a valid license under the provisions of this chapter, or
shall make any false statement or otherwise violate any of the provisions of
this chapter in obtaining any license hereunder, or who having obtained a
license hereunder shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter with
respect to the manufacture, possession, distribution or sale of alcoholic
liquor, or with respect to the maintenance of the licensed premises, or shall
violate any other provision of this chapter, shall levy a fine on the licensee
for violations. The fine imposed shall not exceed one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) for a first violation within a twelve (12) month period, one
thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for a second violation within a
twelve (12) month period, and two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for
a third or subsequent violation within a twelve (12) month period. Each day a
violation continues shall constitute a separate violation, but not more than
fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) in fines may be imposed against any
licensee during the period of the license.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In the event that a liquor license holder fails to submit a license
renewal application to the village before or on the expiration date of the
current license, the licensee will be assessed a late filing fee of twenty five
dollars ($25.00). Late applications and instruments of payment will be returned
to the licensee. Late filing fees will be in addition to any fines or penalties
ordered for operating without a valid license.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â If, after a hearing on any citation charging a violation of any
provision of this chapter, the local liquor control commissioner or the deputy
local liquor control commissioner finds adversely to the licensee, in addition
to the suspension or revocation of the license, any fine imposed, and any other
costs imposed, the local liquor control commissioner or the deputy local liquor
control commissioner may order the licensee to pay to the village reasonable
attorney fees incurred by the village and the local liquor control commissioner
or the deputy local liquor control commissioner in the prosecution of the
violation.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â If such decision is appealed and is upheld by the state liquor control
commission, the licensee shall be responsible for attorney fees incurred by the
village in defending the appeal to the state liquor control commission.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Any servant or employee engaged in the business of the sale of
alcoholic liquors or beverages who shall violate any section of this chapter
shall be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and
not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. (Ord. 09-
58, 11-16-2009)
3-3-14: BEVERAGE ALCOHOL SELLERS AND SERVERS TRAINING (BASSET) PROGRAM:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Each applicant for a liquor license shall have each person who will
supervise or be in charge of the sale of liquor upon commencement of their
license successfully complete a beverage alcohol sellers and servers training
(BASSET) program conducted by an agency licensed by the Illinois liquor
commission, or successfully complete a state of Illinois certified alcohol
awareness program, prior to issuance of a liquor license except as set forth in
subsections B and C of this section. Proof of successful completion of BASSET
training shall be required prior to issuance of the liquor license.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Each employee, whether or not supervisory, of a liquor licensee, who is
engaged in the selling, mixing, preparing, serving or delivering of alcoholic
beverages to customers, guests or patrons, for consumption on or off the
premises, shall successfully complete a BASSET program conducted by an agency
licensed by the Illinois liquor control commission, or successfully complete a
state of Illinois certified alcohol awareness program. Such training shall be
completed not more than sixty (60) days after the employee begins employment
with the licensee. A copy of the employee's certificate of completion of
training shall be filed with the village liquor commission.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Liquor license applicants applying for a liquor license effective
January 1, 2010, shall be granted a ninety (90) day grace period from January
1, 2010, to have supervisors and employees, as designated by this section,
successfully complete a BASSET program conducted by an agency licensed by the
Illinois liquor commission, or successfully complete a state of Illinois
certified alcohol awareness program. This grace period shall not apply to new
liquor license applicants when the application for the liquor license is
submitted after December 31, 2009.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Liquor license holders shall keep a standing record of when the
required BASSET training, and/or successfully completed a state of Illinois
certified alcohol awareness program, was completed. This will include, but is
not limited to, a photocopy of a BASSET card and/or a photocopy of a
certificate from a state of Illinois certified alcohol awareness program. This
standing record shall be kept on the business premises and available to
inspection by representative(s) of the village liquor commission or other
village representative. (Ord. 09-58, 11-16-2009)
3-3-15: SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Suspension Of Business Operation: When the conduct or operation of any
liquor licensee shall constitute a nuisance in fact and a clear and present
danger to the public health, safety, or general welfare, the liquor control
commissioner shall be authorized to summarily order the cessation of business,
the closing of the premises and the suspension of any license for a period not
to exceed seven (7) days. Within the seven (7) days after he or she has so
acted, the liquor control commissioner shall call a hearing for the purpose of
determining whether the license should be suspended for an additional period of
time or revoked.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Revocation Of License: Liquor licenses issued under this chapter,
unless otherwise provided, may be suspended for up to thirty (30) days or
revoked by the liquor control commissioner after notice and hearing as provided
below for any of the following causes:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Any fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the
application for the license;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Any violation by the licensee of this code relating to the license,
the subject matter of the license, or the premises occupied;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Conviction of the licensee of any felony or of a misdemeanor when
such conviction indicates his or her inability to operate a safe, honest, or
legitimate business operation within the village;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Failure of the licensee to pay any fine or penalty owing to the
village;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Refusal to permit an inspection, or any interference with a duly
authorized village officer or employee while in the performance of his or her
duties in making such inspections, as provided in this chapter; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Any other violation of any village code, ordinances, resolutions, or
regulations.
Such suspension or revocation, if ordered, shall not preclude prosecution and
imposition of any other penalties provided for the violation of other
applicable ordinances of the village.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Hearing: Notice of the hearing for suspension or revocation of a
license shall be given in writing setting forth specifically the grounds of the
complaint and the time and place of the hearing.
At the hearing, the village attorney shall present the complaint and shall
represent the village. The licensee shall be permitted counsel and shall have
the right to submit evidence and cross examine witnesses. A stenographic or
electronically recorded record of the hearing shall be kept. The liquor control
commissioner and/or his designee shall preside and shall render the decision
within a reasonable time after the conclusion of the hearing, but not later
than thirty (30) days thereafter. The decision shall be in writing and shall
summarize the evidence and state the reasons for the decision.
Any licensee whose license is suspended or revoked shall pay to the village the
costs of the hearing before the liquor control commissioner and/or his
designee.
The liquor control commissioner and/or his designee shall determine the costs
incurred by the village for the hearing, including, but not limited to, court
reporter fees, the costs of transcripts or records, attorney fees, the cost of
preparing and mailing notices and orders, and all other miscellaneous expenses
incurred by the village or such lesser sum as the liquor control commissioner
and/or his designee may allow.
The licensee shall pay said costs to the village within thirty (30) days of
notification of the costs by the liquor control commissioner and/or his
designee. Failure to pay these costs within thirty (30) days of notification is
a violation of this section and may be cause for license suspension or
revocation or the levy of a fine. (Ord. 09-58, 11-16-2009)
3-3-16: LICENSEE OR REPRESENTATIVE'S PRESENCE ON PREMISES:
An owner, partner, corporate officer or approved manager must be present on the
premises licensed under this chapter during all business hours. In addition to
any other penalty imposed for violations of this chapter, a minimum fine of one
hundred dollars ($100.00) and a maximum fine of seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) shall be imposed for violations of this section. (Ord. 09-58, 11-16-
2009)
3-3-17: RESPONSIBILITY FOR AGENTS AND EMPLOYEES:
Every act or omission of whatsoever nature, constituting a violation of any of
the provisions of this chapter by an officer, director, manager or other agent
or employee of any licensee, if such act is committed or omission is made
within the scope of such agency or employment or with the authorization,
knowledge, or approval of the licensee, shall be deemed and held to be the act
of such employer or licensee and such employer and licensee shall be punishable
in the same manner as if such act or omission has been done or omitted by the
licensee personally. (Ord. 09-58, 11-16-2009)
3-3-18: DECOY/STING OPERATIONS:
The chief of police, and/or the local liquor control commissioner, the deputy
local liquor control commissioner and/or their respective designees are hereby
authorized to conduct sting operations for the purpose of purchasing alcoholic
beverages and/or tobacco products through the use of decoy agents under the
minimum age for the lawful purchase of the alcoholic beverages or tobacco
products. The local liquor control commissioner, the deputy local liquor
control commissioner and the chief of police are hereby authorized to adopt
rules, regulations and procedures for the employ of underage decoy agents.
(Ord. 09-58, 11-16-2009)
3-3-19: CONSUMPTION OF ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR AT UNLICENSED ESTABLISHMENTS
PROHIBITED:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â No person or entity shall allow alcoholic liquor to be brought into
and/or consumed on the premises of an establishment which is not in possession
of a retail liquor dealer's license specifically allowing alcoholic liquor to
be sold and/or consumed on such premises; provided, however, nothing contained
in this section shall prevent the possession and transportation of alcoholic
liquor for the lawful, noncommercial use of the possessor, and his family and
guests within the possessor's own property.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â No person shall bring to and/or consume alcoholic liquor upon the
premises of an establishment which is not in possession of a retail liquor
dealer's license specifically allowing the sale and/or consumption of alcoholic
liquor on such premises.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â For purposes of this section, an "establishment" shall be defined as an
enterprise or concern, whether for profit or not, which is engaged in the
conducting of business within the village.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Individuals and entities which violate this section shall be subject to
the penalties described in section
1-4-1, "General Penalty", of this code. Further, establishments which violate
this section may be subject to revocation of operating and business licenses.
(Ord. 10-38, 8-16-2010)
CHAPTER 4
AMUSEMENTS
SECTION:
3-4-1: Applicability Of Provisions
3-4-2: License Required
3-4-3: Circuses And Carnivals, Bond Required
3-4-4: Conditions Of License
3-4-5: Building And Premises
3-4-6: Enforcement
3-4-1: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this chapter, except as to licenses and fees, shall apply to
all public shows, theatricals, circuses and other amusements in the Village,
whether licensed specifically in another article of this chapter or not. (1987
Code)
3-4-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate any amusement which is open to the
public and for admission to which a fee is charged without having first secured
a license therefor; provided, that the provisions of this section shall not be
held to apply to those amusements which are specifically licensed by other
provisions of this chapter, this Code or other ordinances. Applications for
such licenses shall be made to the Village Clerk and shall comply with the
general provisions of this chapter relating to such applications. Except as
otherwise provided, the fees for such licenses shall be as provided in section
3-1A-1 of this title. (1987 Code)
3-4-3: CIRCUSES AND CARNIVALS, BOND REQUIRED:
No license for a circus, menagerie or carnival shall be issued until the
applicant therefor shall have filed with the Village Clerk a surety and
indemnity bond in such amount as may be required by the Board of Trustees from
a surety company authorized to do business in the State. The bond shall be
approved by the Village Attorney and shall be conditioned to save harmless the
Village from any liability which might arise by reason of the operation or
conduct of such circus, menagerie or carnival. (1987 Code)
3-4-4: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Order, Crowding:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The audience of any amusement, show or theatrical shall be orderly
and quiet at all times and it shall be unlawful to create or permit a
disturbance at such performance.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful to permit or gather such a crowd to witness any
amusement or show as to create a dangerous condition because of fire or other
risks.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Indecent Shows: It shall be unlawful for any person to present, exhibit
or conduct any indecent show, theatrical, motion picture, exhibition or other
form of public amusement or show.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Riots, Public Disturbances: It shall be unlawful to present any public
amusement or show of any kind which tends to or is calculated to cause or
promote any riot or public disturbance. (1987 Code)
3-4-5: BUILDING AND PREMISES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Compliance With Building Regulations: It shall be unlawful to conduct
or hold any public show, theatrical or public meeting in any building or
premises which does not comply with the requirements of this Code, the Village
Fire Code 1  and other ordinances of this Village relating to the construction
of buildings. (1987 Code; amd. Ord. 2018-33, 12-17-2018)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Exits Required: It shall be unlawful to conduct or hold any such
performance or exhibition in any place not equipped with adequate exits, and
all exits in such building or place shall be kept free of access and
unobstructed. (1987 Code)
Â 
Notes
1 1. See title 5, chapter 2 of this Code.
3-4-6: ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be the duty of the chief of police to see to the enforcement of the
provisions of this chapter. (1987 Code)
ARTICLE A. POOL AND BILLIARD ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
3-4A-1: License Required
3-4A-2: Application For License, Fee
3-4A-3: Consent Of Adjoining Landowners
3-4A-4: Closing Hours
3-4A-5: Minors
3-4A-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate, maintain or conduct a billiard, pool, bagatelle or
pigeon hole table open to the public without first having secured a license
therefor as provided in this Article. (1987 Code)
3-4A-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE, FEE:
All applications for such licenses shall be made in writing to the Village
Clerk and shall state thereon the location of the place of business and the
number of tables to be used therein. The annual license fee for any license
required by this Article shall be as provided in Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. (1987 Code)
3-4A-3: CONSENT OF ADJOINING LANDOWNERS:
It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate any billiard or pool establishment
anywhere in the Village where a majority of the buildings lying wholly within a
radius of three hundred feet (300') are used for residential purposes without
having first secured the written consent of the owners of two-thirds (2/3) of
the lots or parcels of land lying within such radius. (1987 Code)
3-4A-4: CLOSING HOURS:
All pool or billiard establishments open to the public in this Village are
hereby required to be closed for all purposes and cease doing business of any
kind whatsoever at one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and they shall remain so closed and
no business whatever be done therein until six o'clock (6:00) A.M. (1987 Code)
3-4A-5: MINORS:
Minors under the age of seventeen (17) years shall under no circumstances
frequent, loiter, go or remain in any pool or billiard establishment licensed
pursuant to this Article at any time unless it be upon some lawful errand and
sent by the direction and with the consent and knowledge of the parent,
guardian or other person having the lawful custody of such minor. It shall be
unlawful for the proprietor of any pool or billiard establishment so licensed
to allow or permit any such minor to frequent, loiter or remain within the pool
or billiard establishment in violation of this Section. (1987 Code)
ARTICLE B. BOWLING ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
3-4B-1: License Required
3-4B-2: Application For License
3-4B-3: Consent Of Adjoining Landowners
3-4B-4: Conditions Of License
3-4B-5: Sanitary Conditions
3-4B-6: Parking Requirements
3-4B-1: LICENSE REQUIRED 1 :
It shall be unlawful to operate or conduct a bowling lane, pin or ball lane
open to the public or for use of which a fee is charged, without having first
secured a license therefor. (1987 Code)
Â 
Notes
1 1. See section 3-1A-1 of this title for license fees.
3-4B-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Applications for licenses shall conform to the general provisions of this
chapter relating to applications for licenses and shall state, in addition to
all other matters required, the number of lanes to be operated. (1987 Code)
3-4B-3: CONSENT OF ADJOINING LANDOWNERS:
It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate any bowling lane anywhere in the
village where a majority of the buildings lying wholly within a radius of three
hundred feet (300') are used for residential purposes without having first
secured the written consent of the owners of two-thirds (2/3) of the lots or
parcels of land within such radius. (1987 Code)
3-4B-4: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Conduct Of Patrons: It shall be unlawful to permit boisterous or
disorderly conduct by any persons in or on the premises operated as a bowling
lane, or to use or permit the use of profane, obscene or indecent language
therein.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Gambling Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to gamble, to
bet or to tolerate any form of gambling or betting in any premises used for a
bowling lane, pin or ball lane. (1987 Code)
3-4B-5: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
It shall be the duty of every person conducting or operating a bowling lane,
pin or ball lane in the village to keep the premises in a clean and sanitary
condition. (1987 Code)
3-4B-6: PARKING REQUIREMENTS:
No such business shall be conducted, and no such license shall be issued,
unless there is provided within two hundred feet (200') of the premises an
adequate and suitable place for the parking of at least two (2) motor vehicles
for each lane operated, which place shall not be on any public street, parkway
or lane or other public place. The use of such parking place shall be permitted
without extra charge to patrons of the bowling lane. (1987 Code)
ARTICLE C. COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES
SECTION:
3-4C-1: Definitions
3-4C-2: License Required
3-4C-3: Application For License
3-4C-4: License Fees, Renewals
3-4C-5: Term Of License, License Nontransferable
3-4C-6: Investigations
3-4C-7: License To Be Posted
3-4C-8: Limitation On Number Of Devices
3-4C-9: Conditions Of License
3-4C-10: Revocation Of License
3-4C-11: Penalty
3-4C-1: DEFINITIONS:
COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICE: Any mechanical or electronic amusement machine
or device, the operation of which is governed or controlled by the deposit of a
coin or token, including, without being limited thereto, any such coin-
controlled machine or device capable of producing or reproducing any vocal or
instrumental sounds, for the purpose of amusement or skill and for the playing
of which a fee is charged. The term does not include vending machines in which
are not incorporated gambling or amusement features, nor does the term include
any coin-operated mechanical musical devices or billiard or pool tables.
MULTIPLE-PLAY MACHINES OR DEVICES: Any machine or device in which more than one
coin, token or similar object can be inserted so as to affect the results of
the person playing such machine or device.
OPERATOR: Any person, firm, partnership, corporation or association who sets up
for operation by another or leases or distributes for the purpose of operation
by another, any machine or device as herein described, whether such setting up
for operation, leasing or distributing be for a fixed charge or rental, or on a
basis of a division of the income derived from such device or otherwise.
PROPRIETOR: Any person, firm, partnership, corporation, association or club
who, as the owner, lessee or proprietor, has under his or its control, any
establishment, place or premises in or at which such machine or device is
placed or kept for use or play or on exhibition for the purpose of use or play.
SINGLE-PLAY MACHINES OR DEVICES: Any machine or device in which not more than
one coin, token or similar object can be inserted for the playing of said
machine or device. (1987 Code)
3-4C-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of an operator or proprietor of coin-
operated amusement devices, as the terms are herein defined, without first
having obtained the proper license therefor. (1987 Code)
3-4C-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for said license shall be made to the Village Clerk in
conformity with Chapter 1 of this Title, except as otherwise provided herein.
In addition, the application shall set forth the following:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The location and character of the building or place where such
amusement device is to be located, maintained or operated;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The charge to be made to the player for operating each such device; and
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The main or principal occupation or business being conducted or to be
conducted by the applicant upon the same premises wherein such device or
devices are to be located, maintained or operated. The proper license fee shall
accompany such application. (1987 Code)
3-4C-4: LICENSE FEES, RENEWALS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Operator: The license fee for an operator shall be as set forth in
section
3-1A-1 of this title, payable upon application for the license and renewable
annually, for each year the operator sets up, sells, leases or distributes coin
operated amusement devices within the village.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Proprietor: The license fee for a proprietor shall be as set forth in
section
3-1A-1 of this title, for each coin operated amusement device placed or kept by
the proprietor for public use within the village. This fee shall be payable
upon application for the license and said license shall be renewable annually.
(1987 Code)
3-4C-5: TERM OF LICENSE, LICENSE NONTRANSFERABLE:
All licenses under this article shall expire on December 31, following their
issuance and no license issued to any person under this article shall be
transferable. (1987 Code)
3-4C-6: INVESTIGATIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Applicant: Applications for license hereunder shall first be referred
by the village clerk to the president and board of trustees who shall make or
cause to be made such investigation as they deem necessary. If the application
is approved by the president and board of trustees, the license shall be issued
by the village clerk. If the license is denied, the fee shall be returned to
the applicant.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Premises, Machines: No such license shall be issued until the office of
the building commissioner shall have investigated the location wherein the
machine or device is proposed to be operated and has determined that the
proposed operation of the machine or device complies with all the terms of this
article and other applicable ordinances of the village. (1987 Code)
3-4C-7: LICENSE TO BE POSTED:
The license or licenses herein provided for shall be posted permanently or
conspicuously at the location in the premises wherein the machine or device is
to be operated or maintained. (1987 Code)
3-4C-8: LIMITATION ON NUMBER OF DEVICES:
No license shall be issued to any proprietor or for any premises in excess of
one license for every five hundred (500) square feet of gross floor area for
each premises in which said machine or device is located; provided however,
that no more than six (6) such amusement devices may be located, maintained or
operated in or upon any single business establishment, and no such device or
devices shall be so located, maintained or operated unless the location,
maintenance or operation thereof is secondary or incidental to the main or
principal occupation or business being conducted or to be conducted by the
applicant in or upon said establishment. (1987 Code)
3-4C-9: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Closing Hours: No coin operated amusement device shall be operated on
any premises within the village between the hours of one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
and six o'clock (6:00) A.M.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Disturbing The Peace, Nuisances: No license issued hereunder shall
permit the operation of a coin operated amusement device at any place or in any
manner which will disturb the peace of persons otherwise properly within or
without the licensed premises, or shall permit the operation thereof to amount
to a nuisance in fact.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Gambling: No coin operated amusement device shall be operated or
permitted to be used in such a manner as to violate the gambling laws of the
village or of the state 1 .
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â No Free Replays: No proprietor, operator or person in charge of a coin
operated amusement device shall permit free replays to players on the basis of
the player's skill, accumulated score or any other means, and no machine shall
record or indicate free replays. (1987 Code)
Â 
Notes
1 1. 720 ILCS 5/28-1 et seq.
3-4C-10: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The President and Board of Trustees shall have the right to revoke any license
issued hereunder for the violation of any of the provisions of this Article.
(1987 Code)
3-4C-11: PENALTY:
Any person violating or refusing to comply with any of the provisions of this
Article shall be subject to the penalties described in Section
1-4-1, General Penalty, of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense
shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues. (1987 Code; amd. Ord. 2019-15, 6-17-2019)
ARTICLE D. MOTION PICTURES AND THEATRICALS
SECTION:
3-4D-1: License Required, Exceptions

3-4D-1: LICENSE REQUIRED, EXCEPTIONS:
It shall be unlawful to give, present or conduct any motion pictures or
theatricals, for admittance to which a fee is charged, excepting performances
given solely for the benefit of and under the supervision and auspices of a
religious, educational or charitable organization, without having first secured
a license therefor. (1987 Code)
3-4D-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Applications for licenses shall be made in conformance with the general
provisions relating to such applications as set out in Chapter 1 of this Title
and shall state in addition to the other information required, the place of the
intended performance and the seating capacity thereof. (1987 Code)
3-4D-3: LICENSE FEES:
The license fees for motion pictures including those which are to be presented
in premises which are not covered by an annual license, shall be as provided in
Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. (1987 Code)
3-4D-4: BUILDING AND PREMISES:
No motion picture shall be presented in or on any premises or building which
does not fully comply with the requirements of this Code for the construction
or maintenance of buildings for this purpose.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Exits: It shall be unlawful to present any public motion picture in any
building or structure which does not contain the number of exits required for
buildings or places intended for motion picture performances by this Code and
the ordinances of the Village or by State statute.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Electric Wiring 1 : It shall be unlawful to present any public motion
picture in premises in which the electric wiring does not fully comply with
this Code.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Ventilation: All places used for the exhibition of theatricals must be
kept adequately ventilated during the performance and for so long a time as the
audience may remain therein.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Obstruction Of Exits And Aisles: It shall be unlawful to obstruct or
permit the obstruction of any aisles, corridors or exits leading from any room
or enclosure in which a motion picture performance is being given or in which
an audience for such a performance is gathered.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Scenery: It shall be unlawful to use scenery in any theater that has
not been rendered noninflammable by application of fire preventive coatings or
by other adequate means.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Parking Requirements: No such business shall be conducted, and no
license shall be issued, unless there is provided within one hundred feet
(100') of the premises adequate and suitable place for the parking of at least
one motor vehicle for each four (4) seats, which place shall not be on any
public street, parkway or alley or other public place. The use of such parking
place shall be permitted without extra charge to patrons of the theater. (1987
Code)
Â 
Notes
1 1. See Title 9, Chapter 3 of this Code.
3-4D-5: CROWDING:
It shall be unlawful to permit any person, excepting ushers or other theater
employees, to remain standing in a hall or room in which a motion picture is
presented during the time of such performance, and it shall be unlawful to
admit to any hall more persons than can be accommodated by the seating
arrangements for the premises. (1987 Code)
3-4D-6: TYPES OF MOTION PICTURES RESTRICTED:
It shall be unlawful to offer or present any motion picture which has a
tendency to cause a riot or public disturbance of the peace, or any indecent
picture or performance 2 . (1987 Code)

CHAPTER 5
AUCTIONS AND AUCTIONEERS
SECTION:
3-5-1: License Required, Exceptions
3-5-2: Application For License
3-5-3: Investigation Of Applicant

3-5-1: LICENSE REQUIRED 1 , EXCEPTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct an auction in the Village or to
do business as an auctioneer, whether the goods are owned by the auctioneer or
not, without having first obtained a license therefor.
Nothing in this Chapter shall be held to apply to any public auction or sale
made or conducted by a public officer by virtue of any judicial order or
process or by virtue of any power or authority in a mortgage or trust deed.
(1987 Code)
Â 
Notes
1 1. See Section 3-1A-1 of this Title for license fees.
3-5-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for an auctioneer's license or for a single auction shall state
thereon the place of business intended to be occupied if any, or the place of
such auction, and such applications shall give the names of the employees, not
to exceed two (2), who are to be authorized to conduct auctions under the
authority of the license. (1987 Code)
3-5-3: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT:
No such license shall be issued to any but a person of good character. The
Chief of Police shall investigate the character of each applicant before the
license shall be issued. (1987 Code)
3-5-4: NUMBER OF EMPLOYEES, LIABILITY OF LICENSEE:
Every person licensed as an auctioneer may designate not to exceed two (2)
employees who may be authorized by him to conduct auctions. The employer shall
be liable for any violations of this Code and other ordinances committed by
such employees in conducting an auction. (1987 Code)
CHAPTER 6
PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS
ARTICLE C. CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS
SECTION:
3-6C-1: Applicability Of Provisions
3-6C-2: Registration Required
3-6C-3: Application To Solicit, Liability Insurance
3-6C-4: Approval Of Solicitation Request
3-6C-5: Conditions Of Solicitations
3-6C-6: Violation
3-6C-1: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Solicitors: In accordance with State law, no person shall stand on a
highway or street within the Village for the purpose of soliciting
contributions from the occupant of any vehicle except as specifically permitted
herein.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Soliciting Agencies: Solicitation on highways and streets within the
Village shall be permitted for only those soliciting agents which meet the
requirements contained herein. (1987 Code)
3-6C-2: REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
Soliciting agencies shall be registered with the Attorney General as a
charitable organization as provided in "An Act to regulate a solicitation and
collection of funds for charitable purposes, providing for violations thereof,
and making an appropriation thereof", approved July 26, 1963, as amended 1 ,
and such agencies must be engaged in a Statewide fundraising activity. (1987
Code)
Â 
Notes
1 1. 225 ILCS 460/1 et seq.
3-6C-3: APPLICATION TO SOLICIT, LIABILITY INSURANCE:
Soliciting agencies shall make application upon a form provided by the office
of the Village Clerk wherein it shall be liable for, and indemnify the Village,
against any injuries to any person or property during the solicitation which is
related to an act of ordinary negligence of the soliciting agent. Such agencies
shall present proof of public liability insurance in the amount of one million
dollars ($1,000,000.00) for personal injury and five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00) for property damage, and show the Village as an additional
insured. (1987 Code)
3-6C-4: APPROVAL OF SOLICITATION REQUEST:
All requests for permission to solicit hereunder shall be approved by the
President and Board of Trustees before solicitation commences. (1987 Code)
3-6C-5: CONDITIONS OF SOLICITATIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Location: Solicitation on streets and highways within the Village shall
be allowed only at intersections where all traffic is required to come to a
full stop.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Minors: Soliciting agencies shall not permit solicitation by any person
under seventeen (17) years of age.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Clothing: Soliciting agencies shall cause any person engaged in the act
of solicitation to be wearing a high- visibility vest. (1987 Code)
3-6C-6: VIOLATION:
Any person who violates the provisions of this Article shall be in violation of
State law 1  and shall be subject to prosecution thereunder. (1987 Code)

ARTICLE A. PEDDLERS, ITINERANT VENDORS AND CANVASSERS
SECTION:
3-6A-1: License Required
3-6A-2: Application For License
3-6A-3: Bond
3-6A-4: Investigation, Fee
3-6A-5: Approval Or Disapproval Of License Application
3-6A-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of peddling,
itinerant vending or canvassing within the Village without having first
procured a license therefor. (1987 Code)
3-6A-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE 1 :
Applicants for a license under this article must file with the Village Clerk a
sworn application in writing, in duplicate, on a form to be furnished by him,
which shall give the following:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Name of applicant.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Permanent home address and full local address of applicant.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Names, permanent home addresses and full local addresses of each
peddler, itinerant vendor or canvasser or any other member of a transient or
itinerant crew.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Brief description of the nature of applicant's business.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â If employed, the name and address of the employer together with
credentials establishing the exact relationship.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â The length of time for which the right to do business is required.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â A photograph of the applicant and each member of the applicant's crew
taken within sixty (60) days immediately prior to the date of filing the
application, which picture shall be two inches by two inches (2" x 2") showing
the head and shoulders in a clear and distinguishing manner.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â The names of at least two (2) reliable property owners of Cook County
who will certify as to the applicant's good character and business
respectability, or in lieu of the names of references, such other evidence as
to the good character and business responsibility of the applicant as will
enable an investigator of the Village to properly evaluate such character and
business responsibility.
Upon receipt of the application, the original shall be submitted to the
President and Board of Trustees for their consideration. (1987 Code)
Â 
Notes
1 1. See section 3-1A-1 of this title for license fees.
3-6A-3: BOND:
Every applicant for a peddler's, itinerant vendor's or canvasser's license
shall file with the Village Clerk a surety bond running to the Village in the
amount as provided in section
3-1-6 of this title with surety acceptable to and in form approved by the
Village Attorney, conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with all
the provisions of this Code and the ordinances of the Village and guaranteeing
to any resident in the Village that all money paid as a down payment will be
accounted for and applied according to the representations of such peddler,
itinerant vendor or canvasser and further guaranteeing to any resident of the
Village that any merchandise or service contracted for will be delivered or
performed according to the presentations of such peddler, itinerant vendor or
canvasser. (1987 Code)
3-6A-4: INVESTIGATION, FEE:
At the time of filing the application, a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be
paid to the Village Clerk to cover the cost of the investigation of the facts
stated on the application. This fee is in addition to the license fees shown in
section
3-1A-1 of this title.
Upon receipt of the application, the duplicate shall be transferred to the
Chief of Police who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business
and moral character to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the
public good. (1987 Code)
3-6A-5: APPROVAL OR DISAPPROVAL OF LICENSE APPLICATION:
The report of the Chief of Police on the application shall be forwarded to the
President and Board of Trustees. The President and Board of Trustees, together
with the original application and the report of the Chief of Police, shall
either approve or disapprove the application at the regularly constituted
meeting following date of application for permit. (1987 Code)

3-6B-1: DEFINITIONS:

3-6B-2: CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION REQUIRED, APPLICATION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Certificate Required, Fees: Every person desiring to engage in
"soliciting" as herein defined from persons in residences within this
Municipality is hereby required to make written application for a certificate
of registration as hereinafter provided together with the fees as required in
Section
3-1A-1 of this Title.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Application For Certificate: Application for a certificate of
registration shall be made upon a form provided by the Village Clerk and filed
with the Clerk. The applicant shall truthfully state in full, the following
information requested on the application:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Name and address of present place of residence and length of
residence at such address; business address if other than residence address;
also social security number;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Address or place of residence during the past three (3) years if
other than present address;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Age of applicant;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Physical description of the applicant;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Name and address of the person whom the applicant is employed by or
represents; and the length of time of such employment or representation;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Name and address of employer during the past three (3) years if
other than the present employer;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Description sufficient for identification of the subject matter of
the soliciting which the applicant will engage in;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â Period of time for which the certificate is applied;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â The date, or approximate date, of the latest previous application
for certificate under this Article, if any;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â Has a certificate of registration issued to the applicant under
this Article ever been revoked;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 11.Â Â Â Has the applicant ever been convicted of a violation of any of the
provisions of this Article, or the ordinance of any other Illinois municipality
regulating soliciting;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 12.Â Â Â Has the applicant ever been convicted of the commission of a felony
under the laws of the State or any other state or Federal law of the United
States;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 13.Â Â Â Such additional information as the Chief of Police may deem
necessary.
All statements made by the applicant upon the application or in connection
therewith shall be under oath.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Fingerprints Required: Every applicant shall submit to fingerprinting
by the Police Department in connection with the application for certificate.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Records Kept: The Village Clerk shall cause to be kept in his office an
accurate record of every application received and acted upon together with all
other information and data pertaining thereto and all certificates of
registration issued under the provisions of this Article and of the denial of
applications. Applications for certificates shall be numbered in consecutive
order as filed. Every certificate issued and any renewal thereof shall be
identified with the duplicate number of the application upon which it was
issued.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Persons Not Eligible For Certificates: No certificate of registration
shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of the commission of a
felony under the laws of the State or any other state or Federal law of the
United States, within five (5) years of the date of the application; nor to any
person whose certificate of registration issued hereunder has previously been
revoked as herein provided. (1987 Code)
3-6B-3: ISSUANCE AND REVOCATION OF CERTIFICATE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Issuance Of Certificate: The Village Clerk, after consideration of the
application and all information obtained relative thereto, shall deny the
application if applicant does not possess the qualifications for such
certificate as herein required, and that the issuance of a certificate of
registration to the applicant would not be in accord with the intent and
purpose of this Article. Endorsement shall be made by the Village Clerk upon
the application of the denial of the application. When the applicant is found
to be fully qualified, the certificate of registration shall be issued
forthwith.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Revocation Of Certificate: A certificate of registration issued
hereunder shall be revoked by the Village Clerk if the holder of the
certificate is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this
Article, or has made a false material statement in the application, or
otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a certificate of
registration under the terms of this Article. Immediately upon such revocation,
written notice thereof shall be given by the Village Clerk to the holder of the
certificate in person or by certified U.S. mail addressed to his or her
residence address set forth in the application. Immediately upon the giving of
such notice the certificate of registration shall become null and void. (1987
Code)
3-6B-4: VILLAGE POLICY ON SOLICITING:
It is hereby declared to be the policy of the governing body of this
Municipality that the occupant or occupants of the residences in this
Municipality shall make the determination of whether in-person solicitors shall
be, or shall not be, invited to their respective residences. If no
determination is made as is provided in Section
3-6B-5 of this Article then, in that event, registration is not required.
Solicitation by means other than in-person contacts shall be permitted. (1987
Code; amd. Ord. 2023-17-CO, 6-26-2023)
3-6B-5: NOTICE REGULATING SOLICITING:
Every person desiring to secure the protection intended to be provided by the
regulations pertaining to soliciting contained in this Article, shall comply
with the following directions:
Notice of the determination by the occupant of giving invitation to solicitors,
or the refusal of invitation to solicitors, to any residence, shall be given in
the manner as follows:
A weatherproof card, approximately three inches by four inches (3" x 4") in
size, shall be exhibited upon or near the main entrance door to the residence,
indicating the determination by the occupant, containing the applicable words
as follows:
Â Â Â ONLY SOLICITORS REGISTERED IN BROADVIEW INVITED
Â Â Â or
Â Â Â NO SOLICITORS INVITED
The letters shall be at least one-third inch (1/3") in height. For the purpose
of uniformity the cards shall be provided by the Village to persons requesting
at no charge. Such card so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice to any
solicitor of the determination by the occupant of the residence of the
information contained thereon. (1987 Code)
3-6B-6: DUTY OF SOLICITORS:
It shall be the duty of every solicitor upon going onto any premises in the
Municipality upon which a "residence" as herein defined is located to first
examine the notice provided for in Section
3-6B-5 of this Article, if any is attached, and be governed by the statement
contained on the notice. If the notice states "ONLY SOLICITORS REGISTERED IN
BROADVIEW INVITED", then the solicitor not possessing a valid certificate
registration as herein provided, shall immediately and peacefully depart from
the premises; and if the notice states "NO SOLICITORS INVITED", then the
solicitor, whether registered or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart
from the premises.
Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence, whether invited or not,
shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do
so by the occupant. (1987 Code)
3-6B-7: UNINVITED SOLICITING PROHIBITED:
It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any
person to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door, or
create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the
occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the
occupant thereof and engage in "soliciting" as herein defined, in defiance of
the notice exhibited at the residence in accordance with the provisions of
Section
3-6B-5 of this Article. (1987 Code)
3-6B-8: TIME LIMIT ON SOLICITING:
It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any
person whether registered under this Article or not, to go upon any premises
and ring the doorbell upon or near any door of a residence located thereon, or
rap or knock upon any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated
to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of
securing an audience with the occupant thereof, and engage in "soliciting" as
herein defined, prior to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. or after eight o'clock (8:00)
P.M. of any weekday, or at any time on a Sunday or on a State or national
holiday. (1987 Code)
3-6B-9: SOLICITING BUSINESS ON STREETS, HIGHWAYS OR PUBLIC SIDEWALKS:
No person shall stand on any street, highway or other thoroughfare or public
sidewalk in the Village for the purpose of soliciting business, employment or
sales from the driver or occupant of any motor vehicle. (1987 Code)
ARTICLE C. CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS

3-6C-1: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Solicitors: In accordance with State law, no person shall stand on a
highway or street within the Village for the purpose of soliciting
contributions from the occupant of any vehicle except as specifically permitted
herein.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Soliciting Agencies: Solicitation on highways and streets within the

Soliciting agencies shall be registered with the Attorney General as a
charitable organization as provided in "An Act to regulate a solicitation and

and making an appropriation thereof", approved July 26, 1963, as amended 1 ,
and such agencies must be engaged in a Statewide fundraising activity. (1987
Code)
Â 
Notes
1 1. 225 ILCS 460/1 et seq.
3-6C-3: APPLICATION TO SOLICIT, LIABILITY INSURANCE:
Soliciting agencies shall make application upon a form provided by the office
of the Village Clerk wherein it shall be liable for, and indemnify the Village,
against any injuries to any person or property during the solicitation which is
related to an act of ordinary negligence of the soliciting agent. Such agencies
shall present proof of public liability insurance in the amount of one million
dollars ($1,000,000.00) for personal injury and five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00) for property damage, and show the Village as an additional
insured. (1987 Code)
3-6C-4: APPROVAL OF SOLICITATION REQUEST:
All requests for permission to solicit hereunder shall be approved by the
President and Board of Trustees before solicitation commences. (1987 Code)
3-6C-5: CONDITIONS OF SOLICITATIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Location: Solicitation on streets and highways within the Village shall
be allowed only at intersections where all traffic is required to come to a
full stop.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Minors: Soliciting agencies shall not permit solicitation by any person
under seventeen (17) years of age.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Clothing: Soliciting agencies shall cause any person engaged in the act
of solicitation to be wearing a high- visibility vest. (1987 Code)
3-6C-6: VIOLATION:
Any person who violates the provisions of this Article shall be in violation of
State law 1  and shall be subject to prosecution thereunder. (1987 Code)

CHAPTER 7
SECONDHAND DEALERS AND PAWNBROKERS
SECTION:
3-7-1: License Required
3-7-2: Application For License, Investigation
3-7-3: Records Required, Inspection
3-7-4: Pawnbroker's License Required
3-7-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate or conduct a secondhand store in the Village without
having first obtained a license therefor or without complying with the
provisions of this Chapter. (1987 Code)
3-7-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE, INVESTIGATION:
Application for such license shall be made to the Village Clerk in writing and
shall state the location intended to be occupied. Upon receipt of any such
application, the Chief of Police or any person authorized by him or by the
President to do so, shall investigate the character of the applicant. No
license shall be issued to any person of bad character nor to any person who
shall have been convicted of receiving stolen goods, burglary or robbery. (1987
Code)
3-7-3: RECORDS REQUIRED, INSPECTION:
Every person operating a secondhand store shall keep a record of all articles
purchased, which record together with the articles themselves shall be open to
inspection by any member of the Police Department at all reasonable hours.
(1987 Code)
3-7-4: PAWNBROKER'S LICENSE REQUIRED 1 :
No person operating a secondhand store shall do business as a pawnbroker
without having obtained a pawnbroker's license in addition to the secondhand
dealer's license. (1987 Code)
Â 
Notes
1 1. See Section 3-1A-1 of this Title for license fees.
CHAPTER 8
TAXICABS
SECTION:

3-8-1: DEFINITION OF TAXICAB:
For the purpose of this Chapter, the term "taxicab" shall mean and include all
vehicles, however propelled, which carry passengers for hire upon or along the
streets of the Village, except vehicles operating regularly upon established
routes. (1987 Code)
3-8-2: LICENSES REQUIRED 1 :
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Business License: No person shall operate or maintain any taxicab
without first obtaining a license therefor and unless the license is in full
force.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Driver's License: No person shall operate a taxicab as the driver
thereof without first having obtained a driver's license in the manner set
forth in this Chapter, and unless the license is in full force. (1987 Code)
Â 
Notes
1 1. See Title 7, Chapter 2 of this Code.
3-8-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Business License: Any person desiring a license for any taxicab shall
file an application therefor with the Village Clerk setting forth the name,
business and address of the applicant, a full description of the motor vehicle
for which a license is desired, including the make, model, motor and engine
number and the State license number, and any other information that the
President or the Village Clerk may require.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Driver's License: Any person desiring a license as a driver of a
taxicab shall file an application with the Village Clerk setting forth the
name, sex, residence address, date and place of birth, former occupation,
experience as a driver and such other information as the President or Village
Clerk may require. (1987 Code)
3-8-4: ISSUANCE OF LICENSES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Business License: The license for a taxicab shall be issued upon
conformance with the terms of this Chapter.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Driver's License: The license required by subsection 3-8-2B of this
Chapter shall be issued by the Village Clerk to all persons of good moral
character who have complied with this Chapter and with all the laws of the
State governing taxicab drivers. No license shall be issued to any person under
the age of twenty one (21) years. (1987 Code)
3-8-5: LICENSE FEES:
Fees for licenses required herein shall be as provided in Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. Said license fees shall be paid semiannually, in advance.
(1987 Code)
3-8-6: INFORMATION REQUIRED TO BE CARRIED:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Certificate For Taxicab: All licenses under this Chapter must be
accompanied by a satisfactorily completed "vehicle inspection report" as
designated in Section
3-8-10 of this Chapter in order for the Village Clerk to issue a certificate
for each taxicab so licensed and so inspected. This certificate shall at all
times be firmly affixed above the Village sticker.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Driver's License To Be Carried At All Times: Every driver shall carry
the license issued to him under this Chapter at all times that he is driving or
on duty with any such taxicab, and shall exhibit it upon demand to any Village
police officer or law enforcement officer.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Rates Posted: The rates as approved by the President and Board of
Trustees shall be posted in plain view in every licensed taxicab.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Additional Information Required: In addition to having the approved
rates posted, the name of the driver, his or her picture and the State license
number shall be posted in each taxicab in front of the passenger compartment in
such a position that it will be in plain view of passenger(s) riding therein
and so lighted as to be plainly visible at night. (1987 Code)
3-8-7: REVOCATION OF LICENSES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Business License: The President shall have the right to revoke any
taxicab license issued under this Chapter whenever the taxicab is not kept in
the mechanical or sanitary condition required by this Chapter, or is not
equipped with a governor or other similar device in good repair. Any such
revocation shall be in compliance with the procedure set out in Section
3-1-11 of this Title.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Driver's License: The President shall have the right to revoke any
license issued under this Chapter to any person as a taxicab driver whenever
such person violates any of the provisions of this Chapter or any other
ordinance governing taxicabs or traffic 1 , and also whenever it appears that a
person holding any such license is not of a good moral character. (1987 Code)
Â 
Notes
1 1. See Title 7 of this Code.
3-8-8: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
Every owner of a taxicab operating upon streets in the Village shall submit for
approval to the President and Board of Trustees, insurance policies covering
liability, property damage and medical coverage in the following amounts:
Bodily injury liability
Â Â Â 1 personÂ Â Â $200,000.00
Â Â Â 2 or more personsÂ Â Â 500,000.00
Property damage liabilityÂ Â Â  50,000.00
Medical payments, per personÂ Â Â 5,000.00
A cab owner must also have a certificate (filed with the State) for "uninsured
motorist" of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) per person and twenty thousand
dollars ($20,000.00) for each accident.
Failure to carry such insurance coverage shall subject owner and operator of
each taxicab to a minimum fine of twenty five dollars ($25.00) and not to
exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) or revocation of license or both. (1987
Code)
3-8-9: RATES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Approval Of Rates Required: Rates which are to be charged per trip and
per person must be first submitted and approved by the President and Board of
Trustees before a license is issued. It shall be unlawful to charge more than
the approved rates.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Rates On File: The approved rates shall be on file with the Village
Clerk. (1987 Code)
3-8-10: VEHICLE EQUIPMENT, CONDITION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Meter Required: Every licensed taxicab shall be equipped with a meter.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Mechanical Condition, Safety Test Required: Every taxicab operated upon
the streets of the Village shall be kept and maintained in a good and safe
mechanical condition. Every taxicab, during the month of January and the month
of July of each year, shall be subject to a safety test by a duly authorized
State testing station. A sticker showing the passing of such safety test must
be prominently displayed on the window of taxicab. The passing of a safety test
shall not be a bar at any time to prosecution for operating or causing to be
operated a taxicab not in good and safe mechanical condition. Charges for all
safety inspections are to be paid for by the owner of the cab or cab company.
In the event that a safety test by a duly authorized State testing station is
not available for taxicabs, the President and Board of Trustees shall authorize
the License Committee to set up a "vehicle inspection report" form, similar to
that which the State is presently requiring of trucks. Said "vehicle inspection
report" tests are to be made by a licensed mechanic within the State. This form
shall be issued by the Village Clerk to the applicant requesting a business
license. Applicant must return same to the Village Clerk, with all requirements
checked off as satisfactory before a business license certificate can be
issued.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Sanitary Conditions: Each taxicab shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition at all times. (1987 Code)
3-8-11: OPERATION OF VEHICLE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Manner Of Operation: No taxicab shall be driven, operated or controlled
so as to violate any of the parking or traffic regulations of the Village or so
as to obstruct traffic or interfere with the free movement of traffic upon any
street, alley or public place.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Passengers In Front Seat Prohibited, Exception: No person shall be
allowed to ride in the front seat of any taxicab with the driver except at such
times as the rear seat or seats are fully occupied by paying passengers and the
person riding in the front seat is a bona fide paying passenger.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Use Of Taxicab Stands Required 1 : No unemployed taxicab shall stand or
be parked upon any public street or alley except at such places as from time to
time shall be designated by the Board of Trustees as taxicab stands and
allotted to the particular licensee in question.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Operating Under The Influence Of Alcohol Or Controlled Substances: No
person shall drive, operate or control any taxicab while under the influence of
intoxicating liquor or controlled substances. (1987 Code)
Â 
Notes
1 1. See subsection 7-4-2F of this Code.
3-8-12: SOLICITING TRADE PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for the owner or driver of any vehicle licensed as a
taxicab, to solicit by word or gesture or otherwise, the patronage of any
person upon any public street in the Village. (1987 Code)
CHAPTER 9
GASOLINE STATIONS, PUBLIC GARAGES
ARTICLE A. GASOLINE STATIONS
SECTION:
3-9A-1: Definition
3-9A-2: License Required
3-9A-3: Application For License
3-9A-4: Inspection Of Premises
3-9A-5: Location
3-9A-6: Self-Service Gas Stations
3-9A-6-1: Rules And Regulations Adopted
3-9A-6-2: Permit To Operate
3-9A-6-3: Restrictions
3-9A-6-4: Penalty
3-9A-1: DEFINITION:
"Filling stations" or "gasoline stations", as used in this Article, shall mean
any building, structure or premises, enclosure or other place within the
Village where a container or containers, tank or tanks, either portable or
stationary and containing ether, carbon bisulphite, gasoline, acetone,
kerosene, hydrocarbon, liquefied petroleum, naphtha, turpentine or other
inflammable liquids are kept or located for the purpose of selling, offering
for sale or distributing any such liquid from such container or containers,
tank or tanks. (1987 Code)
3-9A-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate the business of a filling station without first having
obtained a license therefor. (1987 Code)
3-9A-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE 1 :
The application for such license for a filling station shall conform to the
general provisions of Chapter 1 of this Title relating to licenses and shall
specify the location of the building, structure, premises, enclosure or other
place in which it is proposed to keep such filling station, and the capacity or
capacities in gallons of the containers, tank or tanks. (1987 Code)
Â 
Notes
1 1. See Section 3-1A-1 of this Title for license fees.
3-9A-4: INSPECTION OF PREMISES:
Each filling station shall be erected, conducted and maintained in accordance
with the provisions of this Code and the ordinances of the Village, the State
statutes and the rules of the State Fire Marshal. Each filling station shall be
inspected at least twice every year by the Bureau of Fire Prevention 1  or some
person duly authorized to make such inspection. It shall be the duty of the
person making such inspection to see that the premises are maintained in
compliance to this and other sections of this Code to see that there is no
dangerous accumulation of waste or other combustible material on the premises,
and to report to the President any violation which may be discovered during
such inspection. (1987 Code)
Â 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  5-1-4 of this Code.
3-9A-5: LOCATION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Restricted: No filling station or gasoline station or any installation
for the storing and handling of inflammable liquids shall hereafter be
constructed or maintained in the Village within two hundred feet (200') of any
dwelling, school, hospital, church, theater or any public meeting place. The
two hundred feet (200') shall be measured from the extremities of the tracts of
property in question.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Frontage Consents Required In Residential Districts: It shall be
unlawful to conduct or operate any such filling station anywhere in the Village
where a majority of the buildings lying wholly within a radius of three hundred
feet (300') are used for residential purposes without having first secured the
written consent of the owners of two-thirds (2/3) of the lots or parcels of
land lying within such radius. (1987 Code)
3-9A-6: SELF-SERVICE GAS STATIONS:
Self-service gas stations are permissible for operation in the Village. (1987
Code)
3-9A-6-1: RULES AND REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
Rules and regulations relating to the storage, transportation, sale and use of
gasoline and volatile oils, and the law prescribing the color and label for
gasoline or benzol receptacles, are hereby adopted by reference 2 . (1987 Code)
Â 
Notes
2 2. 430 ILCS.
3-9A-6-2: PERMIT TO OPERATE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Permit Required: It is hereby unlawful for any individual to operate a
self-service gas station in the corporate limits of the Village unless said
individual has first obtained a permit for the operation thereof.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Information Required: Prior to issuance, an individual must display the
following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â A permit issued by the State Fire Marshal of the State of Illinois;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â An accurate description of the location of the self- service gas
station;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The name, address and phone number of the individual owning and
operating the self-service gas station and the name, address and phone number
of the individual owning the property in question.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Fee: Said permit shall require a fee as provided in Section
3-1A-1 of this Title.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Issuance: All said permits issued for the operation of a self-service
gas station shall be issued by the Fire Chief of the Village.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Permit In Addition To Filling Station License: The permit required by
this Section is in addition to and separate from the license required for a
gasoline filling station. (1987 Code)
3-9A-6-3: RESTRICTIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Employment Of Minors: No individual shall be permitted to be employed
at a self-service gas station unless said individual has attained the age of
sixteen (16) years.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Use Of Pumps:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Licensed Drivers: Self-service pumps are to be used only by licensed
drivers.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Minor: No individual shall operate any device used for the pumping
of gas within the Village unless that individual has attained the age of
sixteen (16) years.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Portable Containers: It is hereby unlawful to sell gasoline by means of
a portable container unless said portable container is approved by the
Underwriters Laboratory and is six (6) gallons or less in capacity. (1987 Code)
3-9A-6-4: PENALTY:
Any violation of this Section
3-9A-6 is hereby declared to be an offense and is punishable by a fine of not
less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) but not more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) per occurrence. Each day that a violation continues shall be
interpreted as a separate occurrence. (1987 Code)

CHAPTER 10
ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS 1
SECTION:
3-10-1: Electrical Contractor Defined
3-10-2: Certificate Of Registration Required
3-10-3: Application For Certificate
3-10-4: Registration Fee
3-10-5: Compliance With Electrical Regulations, Installation Permit Required
Â 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  9-3-3 of this Code.
3-10-1: ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR DEFINED:
The term "electrical contractor" as used in this Chapter shall mean any person
engaged in the business of installing or altering equipment and electrical
appliances for the utilization of electricity supplied for light, heat or power
not including radio apparatus or equipment for wireless reception of sounds and
signals, and not including apparatus, conductor and other equipment installed
for or by public utilities, including common carriers, which are under the
jurisdiction of the Illinois Commerce Commission for use in their operation as
public utilities. The term "electrical contractor" does not include employees
employed by such contractor to do or supervise such work. (1987 Code)
3-10-2: CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Village Contractors: No person shall engage in the business of
electrical contractor without having first obtained a certificate of
registration therefor as herein required.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Out Of Town Contractors, Fee Exemption: Any electrical contractor who
is registered as such in any other city or village in the State shall not be
required to pay a fee for being registered in this Village, but every person
doing business in this Village as an electrical contractor shall secure a
certificate of registration. Such certificate shall be issued without charge to
electrical contractors registered as such under the ordinances of another city
or village in this State. (1987 Code)
3-10-3: APPLICATION FOR CERTIFICATE:
Applications for such certificate shall be made to the Village Clerk and a list
of all contractors registered shall be given by the Village Clerk to the Chief
Electrical Inspector. (1987 Code)
3-10-4: REGISTRATION FEE:
The annual fee for registering as an electrical contractor shall be as provided
in subsection 9-3-1D1a of this Code; provided that an application made after
the expiration of the first six (6) months of the register year shall be issued
upon the payment of one-half (1/2) of this fee. The register year shall
correspond with the license year. (1987 Code)
3-10-5: COMPLIANCE WITH ELECTRICAL REGULATIONS, INSTALLATION PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person registered under the provisions of this
Chapter to install any electrical appliances, wiring or fixtures without strict
compliance with the regulations relating to such fixtures; and it shall be
unlawful for any such person to do any such work without having obtained such
permits as may be required. (1987 Code)

Each licensed house mover may file an annual bond, conditioned to save the
Municipality harmless from any loss, damage or liability resulting from the
conduct of the business by the licensee, in the sum provided in Section
3-1-6 of this Title. If such bond is duly filed, it shall be unnecessary for
such licensee to file a bond for each individual house moved in the Village.
(1987 Code)

3-13-1: MACHINE SHOP DEFINED:
The term "machine shop" as used in this Chapter, shall include every workshop
in which machines are made or metal parts thereof are repaired, or where parts
of machines or tools, implements, gears, dies, screws or other metal articles
are cut, filed, shaped or repaired by means of a lathe or other machinery.
(1987 Code)
3-13-2: LICENSE REQUIRED 1 :
No person shall operate a machine shop within the Village without having first
obtained a license therefor; provided, that this Chapter shall not be construed
as requiring an additional license for any class of machine shops specifically
licensed under any other provision of the ordinances of the Village. (1987
Code)
Â 
Notes
1 1. See Section 3-1A-2 of this Title.
3-13-3: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Generally: No building, structure or part thereof used for or in
connection with any machine shop shall be so used as to endanger the health or
property of the employees or of the public.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Premises: The owner, occupant or manager of any machine shop shall
cause all floors and other surface around or beneath any machine or workbench
to be kept in good order and repair and shall have suitable, convenient and
sanitary receptacles for receiving waste and cloths used in and about the
machine shop for the purpose of cleaning machines or parts thereof or which are
intended for any other use.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Employees: No person suffering from any actively contagious or
infectious disease shall be employed in or about any machine where cutting
compound or fluid is used. All such cutting compound or fluid shall be kept
free from infectious or harmful matter. (1987 Code)
3-13-4: HOURS PROHIBITED IN RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT:
No machine shop shall be operated in the nighttime between the hours of eight
o'clock (8:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. in any place in which a
majority of the buildings within a radius of four hundred feet (400') are used
exclusively for residence purposes. (1987 Code)
3-13-5: INSPECTION OF PREMISES:
It shall be the duty of the Fire Chief to make or cause to be made such
inspections as may be necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of

an undertaker or mortician in the Municipality without first having obtained a
license therefor. (1987 Code)

3-19-2: POLICE TO BE NOTIFIED:
It shall be the duty of every undertaker to notify the police whenever a body
is brought to him or turned over to him for his services. (1987 Code)
3-19-3: EXHIBITIONS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any undertaker to permit his establishment to be used
for the exhibition of the body of any deceased person to the public, other than
friends and relatives of the deceased. (1987 Code)
CHAPTER 20
MISCELLANEOUS BUSINESS PROVISIONS
SECTION:

3-20-1: CIGARETTE, CIGAR AND TOBACCO SALES:
See chapter 3-23 for comprehensive regulation of tobacco products. (Ord. 2002-
10, 7-15-2002; amd. Ord. 2019-21, 8-5-2019; Ord. 2025-3, 2-10-2025)
3-20-2: JUNKYARDS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful to keep or store any junk, or to establish or maintain any
junkyard in the Village. (1987 Code)
3-20-3: MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS:
As used in this section, the following words are defined as follows:
MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENT: Any premises, place of business, or membership club,
where there is conducted the business or activity of furnishing, providing or
giving for a fee or other form of consideration, a massage, fomentation, bath,
manipulation of the body, electric or magnetic treatment, alcohol rub or other
similar massage service or procedure.
MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENT - EXCEPTION: The words "massage establishment" and the
provisions of this section shall not apply to any duly licensed physician,
surgeon, osteopath, chiropractor or to other persons duly licensed by the State
of Illinois to treat, manipulate, operate upon, or prescribe for the person or
bodies of human beings and who are actually practicing said licensed profession
or to graduate nurses registered with the Department of Registration and
Education of the State of Illinois.
The operation of massage establishments in the Village is hereby prohibited.
Any person violating any provisions of this section shall be fined not less
than two hundred dollars ($200.00) and not more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) for each offense and every day that such violation continues and
exists shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. (1987 Code)

Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Employers located within the Village shall comply with all applicable

and paid sick leave. Employee eligibility for paid sick leave and minimum
hourly wages shall also be in compliance with all applicable Federal and/or
State laws and regulations as such laws and regulations may exist from time to
time.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â No additional obligations with regard to paid sick leave, or minimum
hourly wages, including, without limitation, any additional obligations by
ordinance adopted by the County of Cook Board of Commissioners, shall apply to
employers located within the Village, except those required by Federal and/or
State laws and regulations as such laws and regulations may exist from time to
time.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â For the purposes of this section, the term "employee" means an
individual permitted to work by an employer regardless of the number of persons
the employer employs, and the term "employer" means any person employing one or
more employees, or seeking to employ one or more employees, if the person has
its principal place of business within the Village or does business within the
Village.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â For the purposes of this section, the term "employer" does not mean:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The government of the United States or a corporation wholly owned by
the government of the United States;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A Native American tribe or a corporation wholly owned by a Native
American tribe;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The government of the State or any agency or department thereof; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The government of any municipality. (Ord. 2017-121, 6-5-2017)
CHAPTER 21
REGULATION OF FILM PRODUCTION
SECTION:
