4-5-1: COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS:
Compliance with this chapter will be required under the public health and
safety regulations of the village. (1987 Code)
4-5-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the following
meanings:
INITIAL VILLAGE PICK UP DATE; MULTI-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL STRUCTURES OF FOUR UNITS
OR MORE: The first date that the village begins to collect waste following the
expiration, avoidance or cancellation of a prior contract, for multi- family
residential structures of four (4) units or more, governing the disposal of
waste. For the purpose of this definition, "current contract" shall mean the
contract in effect on the date of the passage hereof. No multi-family
residential unit owner shall extend or allow the extension of any such contract
by any means including, but not limited to, renewal, automatic renewal or
option so as to delay the initial village pick up from multi-family residential
structures of four (4) units or more.
LANDSCAPE WASTE OR YARD WASTE: All accumulations of grass or shrubbery
cuttings, leaves, tree limbs, and other material accumulated as the result of
the care of lawns, shrubbery, vines and trees.
LIGHT RUBBISH: Any inorganic refuse, paper or other items not consisting of
recyclables or yard waste.
MULTI-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL STRUCTURES OF FOUR UNITS OR MORE: All condominiums,
apartments and other multi-family development which contain four (4) units or
more.
MUNICIPAL WASTE OR GARBAGE: All garbage, refuse, industrial lunchroom or office
waste, and other material resulting from the operation of residential,
municipal or multi-family establishments and from community activities which
are not defined as recyclable or landscape waste.
RECYCLABLES: Aluminum cans, metal cans, bimetal cans, glass containers, plastic
milk bottles, other plastic containers, chipboard, cardboard, glossy paper and
newsprint/junk mail.
RESIDENTIAL UNITS: All single-family homes, two-family development and multi-
family development up to, and including, three (3) units in size, including
townhomes, duplexes, and two-flats. (Ord. 11-13, 5-16-2011)
4-5-3: COLLECTION BY VILLAGE; RESIDENTIAL UNITS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Residential Units:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Solid Waste Containers: Residential units shall be responsible to
utilize village approved sixty five (65) gallon solid waste containers for the
disposal of municipal waste within the village.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Additional Waste: If the residential unit has additional waste,
which exceeds the maximum capacity of the sixty five (65) gallon solid waste
container, they may place their own thirty five (35) gallon containers out for
collection provided that the residential unit attaches an additional solid
waste sticker to said garbage receptacle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Containers: The containers for residential unit village waste or
garbage refuse shall be:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Of durable plastic material;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Of waterproof construction;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Equipped with a watertight fitting cover and with handles
suitable for mobility by one person;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â Of a capacity of no more than sixty five (65) gallons.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Landscape Waste: Residential unit landscape waste shall be placed in
disposable paper bags no smaller than twenty (20) gallons and no larger than
thirty two (32) gallons, and must be used for grass clippings, leaves, weeds
and garden waste materials approved by the village.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Bulky Landscape Waste: Residential unit landscape waste too bulky
for disposal into paper bags, including brush and other branches (3 inches or
less in diameter) must be securely tied into bundles not exceeding four feet
(4') in length and sixty (60) pounds in weight.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Recyclable Materials: Residential unit recyclable materials shall be
placed in village approved sixty five (65) gallon solid waste recycling
containers. Additional materials, which do not fit into the designated
recycling containers, may be placed directly adjacent to the filled container.
However, junk mail, magazines, and glossy paper must be put in paper bags.
Chipboard may be put in paper bags or bundled and tied with string or twine
(except nylon or other synthetic materials).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Placement Of Containers: Residential unit garbage and trash
containers shall be placed at the edge of the alley or on the parkway between
the hours of six o'clock (6:00) P.M. of the day preceding collection until
seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. of the day of collection.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â Containers Complying With Specifications: Only containers complying
with the above specifications for garbage and municipal refuse, landscape waste
and recyclable materials respectively may be utilized.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â Receptacle Capacity: Residential units shall not exceed the maximum
capacity of any waste container within the village. Lids on the sixty five (65)
gallon receptacle must close fully to form a watertight seal. No refuse may
protrude above the rim of the receptacle. Residents must utilize an additional
waste container and attach an additional solid waste sticker to said garbage
receptacle as specified in subsection A2 of this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â Location Of Containers: All containers for garbage, ashes and
household rubbish shall be stored outside the residence or other building in an
accessible place and at ground level on the owner's private property. No
container used for the storage, collection and removal of garbage or other
refuse shall be placed in a thoroughfare or in a manner which constitutes a
nuisance to adjacent property or the occupants thereof or to the public in
general. (Ord. 11-13, 5-16-2011)
4-5-3-1: COLLECTION BY VILLAGE; MULTI-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL STRUCTURES OF FOUR
UNITS OR MORE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Multi-Family Residential Structures Of Four Units Or More:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Containers For Waste Disposal: Multi-family residential structures
of four (4) units or more shall be responsible to utilize village approved
containers for the disposal of municipal waste within the village.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Containers: The containers for multi-family residential structures
of four (4) units or more municipal waste or garbage refuse shall be:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Of durable material;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Of waterproof construction;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Equipped with a cover and with an approved means of collection.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Landscape Waste: Multi-family residential structures of four (4)
units or more must arrange for the removal and disposal of its own landscape
waste and shall not be part of the village landscape program.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Landscape Waste Prior To Removal: Multi-family residential
structures of four (4) units or more landscape waste must be kept orderly and
contained prior to removal.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Recyclable Materials: Multi-family residential structures of four
(4) units or more must arrange for the removal of its own recyclable materials
and shall not be part of the village recyclable program. However, if a multi-
family residential structure of four (4) units or more decides to institute a
recyclable program the contractor providing such a program shall ensure that
recyclable material be placed in sixty five (65) gallon solid waste recycling
containers substantially similar to the village approved containers used for
residential units. Additional materials, which do not fit into the designated
recycling containers, may be placed directly adjacent to the filled container.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Containers Complying With Specifications: Only containers complying
with the above specifications for garbage and municipal waste, landscape waste
and recyclable materials respectively may be utilized.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Container Capacity: The container for each multi-family residential
structure of four (4) units or more shall be properly sized to meet the
municipal waste and garbage needs for each particular multi-family residential
structure of four (4) units or more. Lids on the container must close fully. No
refuse may protrude above the rim of the receptacle. If the refuse is
protruding above the rim of the container, the owner or manager of the multi-
family residential structure of four (4) units or more shall be obligated to
contact the vendor contracted to collect the municipal waste in the village.
The owner of the multi-family residential structures of four (4) units or more
shall also ensure that such garbage is orderly and contained until such time as
the garbage vendor completes the pick up.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â Location Of Containers: All containers for garbage, ashes and
household rubbish shall be stored outside of the multi- family residential
structures of four (4) units or more or other building in an accessible place
and at ground level on the private property of the multi-family residential
structures of four (4) units or more. No container used for the storage,
collection and removal of garbage or other refuse shall be placed in a
thoroughfare or in a manner which constitutes a nuisance to adjacent property
or the occupants thereof or to the public in general.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â Initial Village Pick Up Date: Initial village pick up date for
multi-family residential structures of four (4) units or more shall occur
within sixty (60) days of the passage of this chapter. No resident shall extend
or allow the extension of any existing contract for the collection of waste, by
any means including, but not limited to, renewal, automatic renewal or option
so as to delay the initial village pick up date from multi-family residential
structures of four (4) units or more. All existing contracts for the removal of
waste from multi-family residential structures of four (4) units or more shall
be terminated and/or canceled within sixty (60) days of the passage of this
chapter. (Ord. 11-13, 5-16-2011)
4-5-3-2: COLLECTION BY VILLAGE; PUBLIC RECEPTACLES:
Village waste containers provided for public use in commercial areas shall be
supplied by the village, not exceeding thirty two (32) gallons in capacity and
of wire mesh or enclosed material as approved by the village. (Ord. 11-13, 5-
16-2011)
4-5-3-3: COLLECTION BY VILLAGE; COLLECTION FEES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Collection Fees:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The village board shall establish a schedule of fees, charges and
expenses for the collection of waste and recyclables, stickers for excess
containers of waste, stickers for landscape or yard waste, and penalties for
failure to comply with these provisions.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The approved schedule of fees shall be filed and posted in the
office of the village hall, and may be altered or amended by the village board
from time to time.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â For the purpose of defraying the cost of collecting containers of
garbage and recyclables from either the parkway or the alley of residences
within the village, a charge per month for residential units municipal waste
disposal shall be levied against each single-family dwelling, and for each
household unit in a multiple-family dwelling containing three (3) units or
fewer. The charges shall be totaled and added to the monthly water bill and the
resulting total bill shall be paid as a unit and shall not be divisible. The
ten percent (10%) penalty provided in subsection 8-4-6A of this code also
applies to the portion of the bill designated as a collection fee for garbage.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â For the purpose of defraying the cost of collecting any container of
garbage in excess of the one 65-gallon solid waste container and one 65-gallon
solid waste recycling containers covered in the monthly bill, a resident shall
purchase a solid waste tag from the village and attach it to each container in
order for the container to be collected. The charge for each solid waste tag
shall be posted in the village hall and may be altered or amended by the
village board from time to time.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â For the purpose of defraying the cost of collecting landscape waste
or yard waste, a residential unit shall purchase landscape or yard waste tags
from the village and attach one to each bag or bundle to be collected. The
charge for each tag shall be posted in the village hall and may be altered or
amended by the village board from time to time.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â For the purpose of defraying the cost of collecting containers of
garbage from either the parkway or the alley and in the alleys within the
village for multi-family residential structures of four (4) units or more
municipal waste disposal, a charge per month shall be levied against each
multi-family residential structure of four (4) units or more. The charges shall
be billed separately to each unit in the unit's monthly water bill. The ten
percent (10%) penalty provided in subsection 8-4-6A of this code also applies
to the portion of the bill designated as a collection fee for garbage. (Ord.
11-13, 5-16-2011)
4-5-3-4: COLLECTION BY VILLAGE; SPECIAL PICK UPS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Special Pick Ups For Residential Units: One item per week consisting of
miscellaneous waste and bulk items such as discarded furniture, household
appliances (white goods), water tanks (capable of being handled by 1 person),
and trash items not exceeding ninety (90) pounds in weight shall be picked up
at no charge upon prior arrangement between the resident and the garbage
collection contractor. Other special pick ups for additional items or items not
so designated above shall be provided upon terms agreed to between the resident
and the garbage collection contractor.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Special Pick Ups For Multi-Family Residential Structures Of Four Units
Or More: There are unlimited pick ups under the multi-family residential
structures of four (4) units or more disposal program. The owner, manager, and
tenants of the multi-family residential structure of four (4) units or more
shall be obligated to call the garbage vendor when additional pick ups are
necessary. (Ord. 11-13, 5-16-2011)
4-5-4: STORAGE AND REMOVAL FROM BUSINESSES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Nonresidential Buildings: Every person or entity occupying, operating
or controlling any building or portion thereof where persons do not reside,
board or lodge, shall provide a separate container for garbage which shall be
plainly marked in a conspicuous place "Not For Domestic Use". Such person or
entity shall have the contents of the container removed from the premises at
his own expense at such time and in such manner as the health department may
direct. In the buildings described herein, garbage containers of the kind in
domestic use are prohibited.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Hotels And Restaurants: Every person or entity owning or controlling
any hotel, restaurant, cafe or other premises where more than twenty (20)
guests or boarders are fed daily, shall cause all garbage to be placed in a
proper metallic container which shall be practically airtight and watertight
and shall cause all substances deposited in such containers to be removed from
the premises as frequently as the health department shall direct. The removal
and disposition of such substances shall be done by such person or entity at
his or its own expense. (Ord. 11-13, 5-16-2011)
4-5-5: SCAVENGERS, CATCH BASIN CLEANERS:
4-5-5-1: VILLAGE MAY CONTRACT FOR SERVICE:
The village may contract with private scavengers for the collection of garbage,
ashes and rubbish. (1987 Code)
4-5-5-2: LICENSE REQUIRED, FEE:
No person may operate as a waste disposal firm or scavenger for hire, or
otherwise shall remove waste from any premises in the village; or transport
waste through the streets, alleys or public ways for the village; or dump,
incinerate, or in any other manner dispose of waste originating in the limits
of the village; or contract for, or permit himself to be employed or engaged
for any such removal, transportation or disposal, without first having secured
a license for performing such waste disposal service or scavenger service from
the village clerk, evidencing the payment to the village of the license fee
provided in section
3-1A-1 of this code. No more than one business license shall be available for
municipal waste, recycling waste and landscape waste removal for residential
units of three (3) units or less. No more than one business license shall be
available for municipal waste removal for multi-family residential structures
of four (4) units or more. This limitation on licenses shall not apply to roll-
off dumpsters for purposes of construction, remodeling, concrete, and other
refuse needs of the community not mentioned herein. (Ord. 11-13, 5-16-2011)
4-5-5-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE, BOND:
Each application shall be accompanied by a bond in the sum as provided in
section
3-1-6 of this code, conditioned on compliance with this code. (1987 Code)
4-5-5-4: INVESTIGATION, INSPECTION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Investigation Of Applicant: Upon the receipt of any application for a
license, the health officer shall investigate the character of the applicant.
No license shall be issued to any person who is not a person of good character.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Inspection Of Vehicle: The health officer shall inspect or cause to be
inspected all vehicles intended to be used by the applicant and shall not
approve the issuance of a license unless these vehicles comply with the
provisions of this code. (1987 Code)
4-5-5-5: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Sanitary Vehicles: All vehicles used for waste disposal or scavenger
service must be kept in a sanitary condition. The wagon box must be waterproof,
and each vehicle must be equipped with tight covers.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Obey Traffic Regulations 1 : All persons doing business as scavengers
or catch basin cleaners in the village must fully comply with all ordinances
relating to traffic or to the movement of vehicles on the streets.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Waste Deposits On Premises: Care must be taken when removing any
garbage or offal that no waste material is permitted to fall or remain on any
premises.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Employees: It is unlawful to employ any person as a driver on any
vehicle or as helper therefor who is not a person of good character. (1987
Code)

4-5-6: PROHIBITED ACTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Collection Without Permit: To collect and dispose of refuse for hire
over the streets of the village without a permit is declared to be a nuisance.
Such business shall be carried on under the conditions of this chapter.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Refuse Accumulation:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Private Property: The owner of any premises in the village shall
remove from the premises or otherwise dispose of all garbage, ashes, tin cans,
metalware, broken glass, crockery, stoneware and all refuse and rubbish of
every description whatsoever. Any loose accumulation of such refuse is
prohibited.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Public Ways: No person shall leave or suffer to be left, any refuse
in or upon any street, alley, parkway or other public place or upon any vacant
or unimproved lot or parcel of land in the village. (1987 Code)
4-5-7: FLY DUMPING PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person who is not a resident of the village or who
does not own, operate or maintain a business in the village to deposit, leave
or dump any garbage, yard waste or other debris in, on or upon any public
alley, street or other publicly owned property in the village.
It shall be unlawful for any person who is not a resident of the village or who
does not own, operate or maintain a business in the village to deposit, leave
or dump any garbage, yard waste or other debris in, on or upon any vacant lot
or privately owned property in the village.
It shall be unlawful for any person who is a resident of the village or who
owns, operates or maintains a business in the village to deposit, leave or dump
any garbage, yard waste or other debris in or upon any public alley, street or
other publicly owned property in the village, except in such areas adjacent to
property owned or occupied by said person and then only at the times and in the
receptacles as authorized by the village. (Ord. 90-8, 9-4-1990)
4-5-8: PENALTY:
Any owner or occupant of the premises accused of violating any provision of
this chapter regarding garbage and rubbish storage and removal as contained in
this chapter shall be issued a written warning to correct the violation within
a specified number of days of the date of the warning, or shall be issued a
notice of code violation requiring a court appearance by the violator in thirty
(30) days. Issuance of a warning or a notice of code violation is entirely
within the discretion of the health inspector, building inspector, public works
director or their designee(s).
Any violation is subject to the penalty provisions contained in title 1,
chapter 4, "General Penalty", of this code, with each day of a continuing
violation constituting a separate offense. (Ord. 11-13, 5-16-2011)
CHAPTER 6
FOOD AND FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:

4-6-9: Application After Revocation

4-6-1: APPLICABILITY:
The issuance, suspension, and revocation of permits, licenses, or certificates
to operate retail food establishments; the prohibiting of the sale of unsound
or mislabeled food or drink; and the enforcement of this chapter shall be
regulated in accordance with section
4-6-3 of this chapter concerning the compliance procedures. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-
1997)
4-6-2: CODES:
The inspection of food service establishments shall be regulated in accordance
with the 1993 and all subsequent editions of, or amendments to, the Illinois
Department of Public Health's publication currently titled, "Food Service
Sanitation Code", that are on file with the Secretary of State. The inspection
of retail food stores shall be regulated in accordance with the 1992 and all
subsequent editions of, or amendments to, the Illinois Department of Public
Health's publication currently titled, "Retail Food Store Sanitation Code",
that are on file with the Secretary of State.
Three (3) copies of each of the Illinois Department of Public Health's
publications currently titled, "Food Service Sanitation Code", and "Retail Food
Store Sanitation Code", shall be on file at the Village Clerk's Office. (Ord.
97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-3: COMPLIANCE PROCEDURES - GENERAL:
No person shall operate a food establishment who does not have a valid permit,
license, or certificate issued to them by the Village. Only a person who
complies with the requirements of this chapter shall be entitled to receive or
retain such a permit, license, or certificate. Permits, licenses, or
certificates are not transferable. A valid permit, license or certificate shall
be posted in every food establishment. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-4: ISSUANCE OF PERMIT, LICENSE OR CERTIFICATE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any person desiring to operate a food establishment shall make written
application for a permit, license, or certificate on forms provided by the
Village.
Such application shall include the name and address of each applicant, the
location and type of the proposed food establishment, and the signature of each
applicant.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Prior to approval of an application for a permit, license, or
certificate, the Village and the Cook County Department of Public Health shall
inspect the proposed food establishment to determine compliance with the
requirements of this chapter.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The Village shall issue a permit, license, or certificate to the
applicant if its inspection reveals that the proposed food establishment
complies with the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-5: SUSPENSION OF PERMIT, LICENSE OR CERTIFICATE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The Village may, without warning, notice, or hearing suspend any
permit, license, or certificate to operate a food establishment if the holder
of the permit, license, or certificate does not comply with the requirements of
this Chapter, or if the operation of the establishment does not comply with the
requirements of this Chapter, or if the operation of the food establishment
otherwise constitutes a substantial hazard to public health.
Suspension is effective upon service of the notice required by subsection B of
this Section. When a permit, license, or certificate is suspended, food
operations shall immediately cease. Whenever a permit, license, or certificate
is suspended, the holder of the permit, license, or certificate shall be
afforded an opportunity for hearing within twenty (20) days of receipt of a
request for hearing.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Whenever a permit, license, or certificate is suspended, the holder of
the permit, license, or certificate, or the person in charge shall be notified
in writing that the permit, license, or certificate is, upon service of the
notice, immediately suspended and that an opportunity for hearing will be
provided if a written request for hearing is filed with the Village by the
holder of the permit, license, or certificate within ten (10) days. If no
written request for hearing is filed within ten (10) days, the suspension is
sustained. The Village may end the suspension at any time if reasons for
suspension no longer exist. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-6: REVOCATION OF PERMIT, LICENSE OR CERTIFICATE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The Village may, after providing opportunity for hearing, revoke the
permit, license, or certificate for serious or repeated violations of any of
the requirements of this Chapter or for the interference with the Village or
the Cook County Department of Public Health in the performance of duty.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Prior to revocation, the Village shall notify, in writing, the holder
of the permit, license, or certificate, or the person in charge, of the
specific reason(s) for which the permit, license, or certificate is to be
revoked and that the permit, license, or certificate shall be revoked at the
end of the ten (10) days following service of such notice unless a written
request for hearing is filed with the Village by the holder of the permit,
license, or certificate within such ten (10) day period. If no request for
hearing is filed within the ten (10) day period, the revocation of the permit,
license or certificate becomes final. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-7: SERVICE OF NOTICES:
A notice provided for in this Chapter is properly served when it is delivered
to the holder of the permit, license, or certificate, or the person in charge,
or when it is sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested,
to the last known address of the holder of the permit, license, or certificate.
A copy of the notice shall be filed in the records of the Village. (Ord. 97-8,
10-6-1997)
4-6-8: HEARINGS:
The hearings provided for in this Chapter shall be conducted by the Village at
a time and place designated by it. Any oral testimony given at a hearing shall
be reported verbatim, and the presiding officer shall make provision for
sufficient copies of the transcript. The Village shall make a final finding
based upon the complete hearing record and shall sustain, modify or rescind any
notice or order considered in the hearing. A written report of the hearing
decision shall be furnished to the holder of the permit, license, or
certificate by the Village. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-9: APPLICATION AFTER REVOCATION:
Whenever a revocation of a permit, license, or certificate has become final,
the holder of the revoked permit, license, or certificate may make written
application for a new permit, license or certificate. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-10: INSPECTION FREQUENCY:
An inspection of a food establishment shall be performed at a frequency
prescribed by the Village.
Additional inspections of the food establishment shall be performed as often as
necessary for the enforcement of this Chapter. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-11: ACCESS:
Duly authorized representatives of the Village or the Cook County Department of
Public Health, after proper identification, shall be permitted to enter any
food establishment at any reasonable time for the purpose of making inspections
to determine compliance with this Chapter. The representatives shall be
permitted to examine the records of the establishment to obtain information
pertaining to food and supplies purchased, received, or used. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-
1997)
4-6-12: REPORT OF INSPECTIONS:
Whenever an inspection of a food establishment is made, the findings shall be
recorded on the inspection report form on file and available at the Village
office. The inspection report form shall summarize the requirements of this
Chapter and shall set forth a weighted point value for each requirement.
Inspectional remarks should be written to reference, by item number, the item
violated and should state the correction to be made. The rating score of the
establishment shall be the total of the weighted point values for all
violations, subtracted from one hundred (100). A copy of the completed
inspection report form shall be furnished to the person in charge of the
establishment at the conclusion of the inspection. The completed inspection
report form is a public document that shall be made available for public
disclosure to any person who requests it according to law. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-
1997)
4-6-13: CORRECTION OF VIOLATIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The completed inspection report form shall specify a reasonable period
of time for the correction of the violations found; and correction of the
violations shall be accomplished within the period specified, in accordance
with the following provisions:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â If an imminent health hazard exists, such as complete lack of
refrigeration or sewage backup into the establishment, the establishment shall
immediately cease food operations. Operations shall not be resumed until
authorized by the Cook County Department of Public Health.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â All violations of four (4) or five (5) point weighted items shall be
corrected as soon as possible, but in any event, within ten (10) days following
inspection. A follow-up inspection to confirm correction may be conducted at
the discretion of the Cook County Department of Public Health.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â All one or two (2) point weighted items shall be corrected as soon
as possible, but in any event, by the time of the next routine inspection.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â When the rating score of the establishment is less than sixty (60),
the establishment shall initiate corrective action on all identified violations
within forty eight (48) hours. One or more reinspections may be conducted at
reasonable time intervals to assure correction.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â In the case of temporary food establishments, all violations shall
be corrected within twenty four (24) hours. If violations are not corrected
within twenty four (24) hours, the establishment shall immediately cease food
operations until authorized to resume by the Cook County Department of Public
Health.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The inspection report shall state that failure to comply with any time
limits for corrections may result in cessation of food operations. An
opportunity for hearing on the inspection findings or the time limitations or
both will be provided if a written request is filed with the Village within ten
(10) days following cessation of operations. If a request for hearing is
received, a hearing shall be held within twenty (20) days of receipt of the
request.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Whenever a food establishment is required under the provisions of this
Section to cease operations, it shall not resume operations until it is shown
on reinspection that conditions responsible for the order to cease operations
no longer exist. Opportunity for reinspection shall be offered within a
reasonable time. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-14: EXAMINATION AND CONDEMNATION OF FOOD:
Food may be examined or sampled by the Cook County Department of Public Health
as often as necessary for enforcement of this Chapter. The Cook County
Department of Public Health may, upon written notice to the owner or person in
charge, specifying with particularity the reasons therefor, place a hold order
on any food which it believes is in violation of sections 750.100, 750.110,
760.100, or 760.110 of the Illinois Department of Public Health's "Food Service
Sanitation Code", or the "Retail Food Store Sanitation Code", respectively, or
any other section of this Chapter. The Cook County Department of Public Health
shall tag, label, or otherwise identify any food subject to the hold order. No
food subject to a hold order shall be used, served, or moved from the
establishment. The Cook County Department of Public Health shall permit storage
of the food under conditions specified in the hold order, unless storage is not
possible without risk to the public health, in which case immediate destruction
shall be ordered and accomplished. The hold order shall state that a request
for hearing may be filed within ten (10) days and that if no hearing is
requested the food shall be destroyed. If a request for hearing is received,
the hearing shall be held within twenty (20) days after receipt of the request.
On the basis of evidence produced at that hearing, the hold order may be
vacated, or the owner or person in charge of the food may be directed by
written order to denature or destroy such food or to bring it into compliance
with the provisions of this Chapter. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-15: SUBMISSION OF PLANS:
Whenever a food establishment is constructed or extensively remodeled and
whenever an existing structure is converted to use as a food establishment,
properly prepared plans and specifications for such construction, remodeling,
or conversion shall be submitted to the Village and the Cook County Department
of Public Health for review and approval before construction, remodeling, or
conversion is begun. The plans and specifications shall indicate the proposed
layout, arrangement, mechanical plans, and construction materials of work
areas, and the type and model of proposed fixed equipment and facilities. The
Village and the Cook County Department of Public Health shall approve the plans
and specifications if they meet the requirements of this Chapter. No food
establishment shall be constructed, extensively remodeled, or converted except
in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the Village and the
Cook County Department of Public Health. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-16: PREOPERATIONAL INSPECTION:
Whenever plans and specifications are required by Section
4-6-15 of this Chapter to be submitted to the Village and the Cook County
Department of Public Health, the Village and the Cook County Department of
Public Health shall inspect the food establishment prior to the start of
operations, to determine compliance with the approved plans and specifications
and with the requirements of this Chapter. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-17: PROCEDURE WHEN INFECTION IS SUSPECTED:
When the Cook County Department of Public Health has reasonable cause to
suspect possible disease transmission by an employee of a food establishment,
it may secure a morbidity history of the suspected employee or make any other
investigation as indicated and shall take appropriate action. The Cook County
Department of Public Health may require any or all of the following measures:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The immediate exclusion of the employee from employment in food
establishments;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The immediate closing of the food establishment concerned until, in the
opinion of the Cook County Department of Public Health, no further danger of
disease outbreak exists;
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Restriction of the employee's services to some area of the
establishment where there would be no danger of transmitted disease;
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Adequate medical and laboratory examination of the employee and of
other employees and of his and their body discharges. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-18: REINSPECTION COSTS:
In the event a reinspection is deemed necessary by the inspector, the cost of
any and all subsequent reinspections shall be borne by the holder of the
permit, license, or certificate. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-19: CONDITIONAL PERMIT, LICENSE OR CERTIFICATE:
When structural, plumbing, electrical, ventilation, or similar such defects
exist in an established food facility that may require significant expenditures
to correct, but are not considered to be imminent health hazards, a conditional
permit, license, or certificate may be granted at the discretion of the
Village. Under no circumstances will a conditional permit, license, or
certificate be issued for more than two (2) consecutive twelve (12) month
periods. The purpose of the conditional license or permit is to allow a
reasonable period of time for correction of existing defects. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-
1997)
4-6-20: PENALTIES:
Any person violating the provisions of this Chapter shall be fined not more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and a separate offense
shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation continues.
(Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-21: INJUNCTIONS:
The Village shall have the right to enjoin any person or establishment in the
event violations occur on a continuing basis. (Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-22: AUTOMATIC FOOD VENDING MACHINES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Application For License: In addition to the requirements of Section
4-6-4 of this Chapter, application for automatic food vending machine license
shall set forth the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Types of automatic food vending machines intended to be operated;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A description of each type;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Such further information as may be required by the Village
sanitarian in order to inform him fully as to the type of machine and the kind
of food to be dispensed therefrom.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Approval Of Machine, Inspection Of Premises: Before any license shall
be issued, the type of vending machine intended to be operated shall be
approved by the sanitarian who also shall cause an inspection to be made of the
premises of the applicant to determine the character and fitness of the
premises from the standpoint of ensuring protection of the food from improper
handling, dust, dirt, flies, vermin or other contamination.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â License Emblem: The Village Clerk shall deliver to each person licensed
to engage in a business of installing, keeping or maintaining automatic food
vending machines a license emblem. It shall be the duty of each licensee to
properly identify each food vending machine which he installs. Such
identification shall contain the name and business address of the licensee and
failure to properly affix and maintain such identification on each food vending
machine shall constitute a violation of this section.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Prohibited Acts Or Conditions:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Location In Toilet Or Washroom: No automatic food vending machine
shall be installed or kept for use in any toilet or washroom.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to install,
keep or maintain or use or permit the installation, keeping, maintenance or use
upon his premises of any automatic food vending machine owned or operated by
any person who has not obtained a license as provided herein. (1987 Code; amd.
Ord. 97-8, 10-6-1997)
4-6-23: MOBILE FOOD VENDORS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Definitions: For the purposes of this section:
Â Â Â  LICENSEE: Shall mean any mobile food vendor or mobile food preparer that
has been licensed by the Village of Broadview to serve food from mobile food
vehicle.
Â Â Â MOBILE FOOD PREPARER OR PREPARER: Means any person who, by traveling from
place to place upon the public ways, including highways, alleys, sidewalks, or
other public ways, prepares and serves, sells or distributes perishable food
items from a mobile food vehicle.
Â Â Â MOBILE FOOD VEHICLE OR VEHICLE: Means a manufactured, motorized mobile food
unit, including but not limited to trucks, cars or other vehicles, as well as
motorcycles and bicycles, in which ready-to-eat food is cooked, wrapped,
packaged, processed, or portioned for service, sale or distribution. This
definition does not include any trucks, cars, other vehicles, motorcycles, or
bicycles used to deliver food ordered from a restaurant with a fixed place of
business.
Â Â Â MOBILE FOOD VENDOR OR VENDOR: Means any person who, by traveling from place
to place upon public ways, including highways, alleys, sidewalks, or other
public ways, serves ready-to-eat food which is cooked, wrapped, packaged,
processed, or portioned for service, sale or distribution, including selling
food prepared by a mobile food preparer, and shall include the owner of mobile
food vehicle or the owner's agent.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â License Required:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate
within the Village a mobile food vehicle or operate as a mobile food preparer
or mobile food vendor, as defined in this section, without first having
obtained a license for that purpose.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â License Application: Any person desiring to operate a mobile food
vehicle shall make a written application for such license to the Building
Commissioner or his/her designee. The application for such license shall be on
forms provided by the Building Commissioner or his/her designee and shall
include the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Name, signature and address of each applicant and each corporate
officer, owner, partner, or proprietor;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Name and address of the approved commercial supply source;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â A description of the preparation methods and food products
offered for sale, including the intended menu, display and distribution
containers;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â The anticipated volume of food to be stored, prepared and sold;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â Plans and specifications for the mobile food vehicle, including
the proposed layout, photographs, mechanical schematics, construction
materials, finish schedules, equipment types, manufacturers, model numbers,
locations, dimensions, weight of vehicle per wheel, performance capacities,
power source, installation specifications and information on any custom
fabricated equipment;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â Proof of full, unfettered and continuous access during hours of
operation to restrooms with a hand sink for use by employees within two hundred
feet (200') of the mobile food vehicle during times when the vehicle is parked
in one location for more than two (2) hours. Proof of access shall be evidenced
by written agreement between the mobile food vendor and the party providing
said access;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â g.Â Â Â A valid copy of all necessary licenses or permits required by
State health or transportation authorities. This includes proof of food handler
certification training or valid Illinois Food Service Sanitation Manager
Certification as required in the Food Handling Regulation Enforcement Act, 410
Illinois Compiled Statutes 625/0.01 et seq. During all times of mobile food
vehicle operation in the Village, at least one certified trained food handler
or someone holding a food service sanitation manager certificate issued by the
Illinois Department of Public Health must be present on the vehicle;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â h.Â Â Â A signed statement that the mobile food vendor shall defend, hold
harmless, and indemnify the Village and its officers and employees, and shall
indemnify the Village, its officers and employees for any claims for damage to
property or injury to persons which may be occasioned by any activity carried
on under the terms of the permit. Mobile food vendor shall furnish and maintain
such public liability, food products liability, and property damage insurance
as will protect the mobile food vendor, property owners, and the Village from
all claims for damage to property or bodily injury, including death, which may
arise from the operations under the license or in connection therewith. Such
insurance shall provide coverage of not less than one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) per occurrence. The policy shall further provide that it may
not be cancelled except upon thirty (30) days' written notice served upon the
Village President and on the Building Commissioner. A license issued pursuant
to the provisions of this section shall be invalid at any time the insurance
required herein is not maintained and evidence of continuing coverage is not
filed with the Building Commissioner and the Village President; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â i.Â Â Â The proposed location(s) and times of operation for conducting
business in accordance with this section. Mobile food vendors shall be required
to provide to the Village a signed statement that the mobile food vendor shall
defend, hold harmless, and indemnify the adjacent property owner(s) for any
claims for damage to property or injury to persons which may be occasioned by
any activity carried on or under the permit. No application will be accepted
for a permit to operate at a location where a current permit has been issued or
a complete application is pending. If the proposed location is private
property, the applicant shall provide to the Village written consent from the
property owner, which shall be duly notarized.
Mobile food vendor shall notify the Building Commissioner or his/her designee
within thirty (30) calendar days of any changes to application information.
It shall be the duty of the Building Commissioner or his/her designee to
inspect the vehicle and determine the fitness and suitability of the vehicle
for its intended use. The Building Commissioner may also direct the applicant
to have the vehicle inspected by the Cook County Department of Health, the
costs of which shall be paid by the mobile food vendor.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â License Fees: All mobile food vendors licensed under this section
shall pay an annual license fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). The fee
for any such license issued after July 1 in any calendar year shall equal one
hundred twenty five dollars ($125.00). One-day license fees shall also be
available for fifty dollars ($50.00) per day. No more than six (6) one-day
licenses will be issued to any applicant in a one year period.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Form And Condition Of Permit: In addition to naming the mobile food
vendor, the approved operating location site diagram, and other information
deemed appropriate by the Building Commissioner or his/her designee, the mobile
food vehicle vending permit shall contain the following conditions:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Each mobile food vehicle vending license shall expire on December
31 of each year.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The license shall not be transferrable from person to person or
from place to place without the written approval of the Building Commissioner
or his/her designee.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The approved operational location may be changed, either
temporarily or permanently, by written notice of the Building Commissioner or
his/her designee.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â The license is valid for one mobile food vehicle only.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â There shall be issued to each mobile food vendor a suitable decal
that shall be permanently and prominently affixed to the vehicle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Refusal To Issue; Suspension; Revocation: Licenses authorized to be
issued pursuant to this section may be suspended, revoked or refused to be
issued upon good cause shown. The Village may refuse to issue, revoke, or
suspend a license if any applicant or agent thereof refuses to comply with any
requirement of this section or has a debt that is in arrears to the Village.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Location Review And Restrictions:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The license shall be referred to the Building Commissioner or his/
her designee for approval or disapproval. In the course of his or her review,
the Building Commissioner may, but is not required to, consult with the
Director of Public Works, the Police Chief, and the Fire Chief related to the
application for a license and the location(s) at which the license may be used.
The use of the licensed operating location for mobile food vending must be
compatible with the public interest in use of the public right-of-way. In
making such determination, the Building Commissioner, in consultation with the
Director of Public Works, the Police Chief, and the Fire Chief or their
designee shall consider the width of the public way, parking issues and traffic
congestion, the weight that can be supported by the paving or street surface at
the proposed location, the proximity and location of existing street furniture,
including, but not limited to, utility poles, parking meters, bus shelters,
benches, street trees, news racks, as well as the presence of bus stops, truck
loading zones, taxi stands, valet parking zones, fire hydrants, or other
businesses or approved mobile food vehicles to determine whether the requested
location would result in pedestrian or street congestion.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The Building Commissioner or his/her designee shall not approve a
location where a mobile food vehicle would substantially obstruct highways,
alleys, sidewalks, or other public ways, impair the movement of pedestrians or
vehicles, or pose a hazard to public safety. The Building Commissioner or his/
her designee shall not approve any location which is adjacent to a bus stop,
taxi stand, or handicap loading zone, within thirty feet (30') of an
intersection, within three feet (3') of a curb, within fifteen feet (15') of a
fire hydrant, within twenty feet (20') of a fire station or police station, or
directly in front of a property entryway. Pedestrian walkways of no less than
six feet (6') must be maintained around the mobile food vehicle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â It shall be unlawful for a mobile food vehicle vendor to park,
stand, or operate in a location which is adjacent to or within one hundred feet
(100') of the address point of a licensed restaurant. This requirement may be
waived if the application is submitted with the duly notarized written consent
of the proprietor of the adjacent restaurant. No person or entity shall either
pay or accept payment for the written consent provided herein. If applicable,
this requirement shall not apply to a licensed restaurant affiliated with the
mobile food vehicle vendor provided that satisfactory written proof as
determined by the Building Commissioner is provided.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The Village shall not approve more than one mobile food vehicle per
private parking lot, which must remain in compliance with this Code.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Mobile food vendor shall not operate a mobile food vehicle within
five hundred feet (500') of the address point of any fair, carnival, circus,
festival, special event, or civic event that is licensed or sanctioned by the
Village except when mobile food vendor has obtained a one-day food permit from
the Village.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â On days when school is in session at elementary, middle, and
secondary schools (public or private), it shall be unlawful for any mobile food
vendor to operate a mobile food vehicle within five hundred feet (500') of the
address point of property of a school. During summer school sessions, this
restriction shall apply only to those individual schools which are in
operation.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â A mobile food vendor shall not operate on private property within
the corporate limits of Village without first obtaining written consent to
operate from the affected private property owner to operate.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â The Building Commissioner, the Director of Public Works, the Police
Chief, and the Fire Chief, or their designees, shall work cooperatively to
review and determine location restrictions related to the parking and operation
of mobile food vehicles and shall consider public safety and right-of- way
safety issues.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â Mobile food vehicle vendors may be permitted to operate and locate
within locations and times approved by the Building Commissioner. The license
must be prominently displayed on the mobile food vehicle at all times. The
mobile food vehicle vendors must pay any and all parking meter fees for the
time and usage of any and all Village parking spaces, including paving parking
meter fees for the usage of multiple parking spaces during operation of the
vehicle and must obey all parking and traffic regulations.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Sanitation And Inspections:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â All mobile food vehicles shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition. It shall be the duty of the Building Commissioner or his/her
designee, which may include the Cook County Health Department, to make or cause
to be made such inspections as may be necessary to ensure all mobile food
vehicles are kept in a clean and sanitary condition. The Building Commissioner
or his/her designee, which may include the Cook County Health Department or
his/her designee, bearing proper identification, shall be permitted to enter or
access any mobile food vehicle at any reasonable time for the purpose of
inspecting to determine whether the mobile food vendor has complied with the
terms of this section. Additionally, the mobile food vendor shall, on request,
provide the Building Commissioner or his/her designee, which may include the
Cook County Health Department, with the records of the mobile food vehicle to
obtain information pertaining to food and supplies purchased, received or used.
Denial of access to the mobile food vehicle or to said records shall be deemed
an interference with the Building Commissioner or his/her designee, which may
include the Cook County Health Department, in the performance of his/her duties
and may result in an immediate suspension of the mobile food vendor's license.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â All food storage, preparation and distribution of food, and vehicle
equipment must meet applicable Illinois Department of Public Health and the
Cook County Department of Health standards and requirements, as well as
standards to be determined by the Building Commissioner or his/her designee.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â All food, beverages, ice and other materials sold or used in
preparation of goods to be sold must be obtained from an approved commercial
supply source. The Building Commissioner shall be responsible for approving
commercial supply sources and shall keep a list of approved commercial supply
sources in a conveniently accessible location.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â All off-site food preparation and food storage must be done either
at a Village of Broadview licensed food establishment or if the mobile food
vehicle vendor is outside the jurisdiction of the Village, it must comply with
the applicable requirements of this Code as well as all requirements of the
Cook County Department of Health and the State of Illinois. All mobile food
vendors or applicants that intend to dispense foods that are prepared and
wrapped in a commissary, must conduct their operations under the supervision of
a State and/or local health authority. All mobile food vehicle vendors and the
mobile food preparers must prepare food in compliance with any and all rules
and regulations of the Illinois Department of Health and the Cook County
Department of Health and conducts its operations under the supervision of a
State or local health authority. The mobile food vehicle vendor shall, in
addition to the application, if requested, provide reports including inspection
reports and laboratory results from the State and local health authority in the
jurisdiction where the food source or commissary is located, indicating
compliance with such approval. Food cannot be prepared in a home, apartment,
other living space or garage.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â All waste liquids, garbage, litter and refuse shall be kept in leak-
proof, nonabsorbent containers which shall be kept covered with tight-fitting
lids and properly disposed of either at an affiliated licensed restaurant or
alternative location(s) as disclosed and agreed to with the Building
Commissioner or his/her designee. No waste liquids, garbage, litter or refuse
shall be dumped or drained into sidewalks, streets, gutters, drains, trash
receptacles, other than the agreed locations with Village staff. A garbage
receptacle shall be easily accessible for customer use. Mobile food vendors
shall be responsible for all litter and garbage left by customers.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Restrictions On Use:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Hours of operation for mobile food vendors shall be limited to the
hours between seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. The
hours of operation for mobile food vehicles located within three hundred feet
(300') of a residential building or a mixed use building with a residential
component shall be limited to the hours between seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and
nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. No mobile food vehicle shall be left unattended on
highways, alleys, sidewalks, or other public ways, nor remain on highways,
alleys, sidewalks, or other public ways outside of these allowed hours of
operation.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â No mobile food vehicle vendor shall use or maintain any outside
sound amplifying equipment, lights, or noisemakers, such as bells, horns or
whistles to attract attention or customers, except that the vehicle may
maintain standard issued vehicle equipment without modifications to said
equipment.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â No mobile food vehicle shall use external signage, bollards,
seating, or any other equipment not contained within the vehicle except that a
retractable awning may be used at the exterior food service and food sales
area.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The mobile food vehicle shall not have a drive-through.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Mobile food vendor shall obey all State, local, and Village laws as
well as any lawful order of a police officer to move to a different permitted
location to avoid congestion or obstruction of a public way or remove the
vehicle entirely from the public way if necessary to avoid such congestion or
obstruction.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â The mobile food vehicle must prominently display the name, address,
and phone number of the owner.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â The mobile food vehicle shall display its permit/decal prominently
on the vehicle's windshield in the lower right hand corner (passenger's side)
of the windshield.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â Any power required for the mobile food vehicle located on a public
way shall be self-contained and shall not use utilities drawn from the public
right-of-way. Mobile food vehicles on private property may use electrical power
from an adjacent property only when the property owner provides written
consent. All other power sources must be self- contained. No power cable or
equipment shall be extended at grade across any Village street, alley or
sidewalk.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â All identifying information, logos, advertising, decorations, or
other displays on the exterior of a mobile food vehicle shall conform to this
Code related to regulating commercial signage, to the extent applicable. In
particular, exterior displays shall be designed to minimize confusion or
distraction that jeopardizes vehicular and pedestrian safety and shall be
harmonious with the surroundings and consistent with the character of the
community in which the mobile food vehicle operates.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â License Adverse Action:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â An application or approved license may be denied, revoked,
suspended, or not renewed for any of the following reasons listed herein,
however, this list is not exhaustive and licenses could be denied, revoked,
suspended or not renewed for other reasons provided good cause is shown. Some
of the reasons that licenses may be denied, revoked, suspended, or not renewed,
include but are not limited to:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â The application contains material omissions or false, fraudulent,
or deceptive statements.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The vehicle is operated in such a manner as constituting a public
nuisance per the Village of Broadview Code of ordinances or State Statutes.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The applicant or mobile food vendor's operation has or likely
would endanger the health, safety, and welfare of the residents, business-
owners, and visitors to the Village.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â The proposed operation is in violation of any Federal, State, or
local laws including, but not limited to, the provisions of this Code and the
Cook County Code of Ordinances pertaining to food, fire prevention, public
health or safety.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The provisions of this section are not exclusive. This section shall
not preclude the enforcement of any other provisions of this Code or County,
State and Federal laws, regulations, rules, and ordinances.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Appeal Rights:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â A licensee or mobile food vendor applicant shall have the option to
appeal an adverse decision of the Building Commissioner to the Corporate
Authorities. Such appeals must be in writing with a copy of the adverse
decision attached thereto and the licensee or the mobile food vendor applicant
must state the reason he or she believes this decision to be in error. The
appeal shall be filed with the Village of Broadview - Village Clerk's Office no
later than fourteen (14) calendar days after the issuance of the adverse
decision. A failure to timely appeal and attach a copy of the decision shall be
grounds for the appeal to be dismissed with prejudice. The decision of the
Corporate Authorities is final.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Violations:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Any mobile food vendor or mobile food preparer shall be subject to a
fine of not less than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) and not more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Each day of a continuing violation shall constitute a separate
violation and a penalty of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00)
per day may be assessed for each day the violation continues.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Pending a hearing pursuant to title 1, chapter 13 of this Code, the
Building Commissioner shall be authorized to suspend the license of the mobile
food vendor and the mobile food vendor shall cease its operations pending the
outcome of the hearing. (Ord. 2017-133, 9-18-2017)

4-7-1: UNWHOLESOME BUSINESSES PROHIBITED 1 :
It shall be unlawful to establish any unwholesome business, or any business or
factory causing noxious odors within the Village or within one mile of the
Village limits. (1987 Code)

4-7-2: TREATMENT OF METALS:
4-7-2-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to engage in any business in which nitric acid, muriatic
acid, sulfuric acid or similar chemicals are used in the treatment of metals
without having first secured a license therefor. (1987 Code)
4-7-2-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE 2 :
Application for license shall be made in full compliance with the general
provisions of Title 3, Chapter 1 of this Code and shall designate the kinds and
quantities of such chemicals to be stored on the premises. (1987 Code)
Â 
Notes
2 2. See Section 3-1A-2 of this Code.
4-7-2-3: REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Storage And Ventilation: All chemicals referred to herein shall be
safely stored in adequate containers labeled and used only for such chemicals,
and all rooms in which such chemicals are stored or used shall be properly

working hours.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Excessive Fumes: It shall be unlawful to permit the escape of sulfuric
acid fumes or of any harmful fumes, in quantities sufficient to be noticeable
or an annoyance to the inhabitants of any building in the Village. (1987 Code)
4-7-2-4: INSPECTION OF PREMISES:

4-7-2. (1987 Code)
4-7-3: FOUNDRIES, RENDERIES, SLAUGHTERHOUSES:
4-7-3-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to operate or maintain any foundry within the Village or
any rendery, tallow chandlery, soap factory, tannery, packing plant or
slaughterhouse within the Village or within one mile of the Village limits
without having secured a license therefor. (1987 Code)
4-7-3-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE, ISSUANCE:

such license shall be issued except upon the express order of the Village Board
of Trustees. (1987 Code)
4-7-3-3: LOCATION:

unlawful to establish any factory or establishment mentioned herein in any

two-thirds (2/3) of all the premises within such radius. Such frontage consents
must be obtained and filed with the Clerk before a license will be issued.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Zoning Requirements Take Precedence: The provisions of this Section
shall not be construed to permit the establishment of any factory or place of
business in any location where such factory or place of business is prohibited
by the zoning regulations 1 . (1987 Code)

4-9-1: DEFINITION:
The word "home" is hereby defined to be any institution, place or facility used
for the reception or care of three (3) or more infants or children, apart from
their parents; and any institution used for the care of persons who are
dependent or not capable of properly caring for themselves. The term "home"
shall be understood to include homes for the aged or infirm, orphan asylums,
half orphan asylums, refuges and shelters. (1987 Code)
4-9-2: LICENSE REQUIRED 2 :
It shall be unlawful for any person other than the regularly constituted
authorities of the United States, the County or any association or institution
which has been accredited, certified or licensed by the State pursuant to an
act of the legislature to regulate the treatment and control of dependent,
neglected and delinquent children, to conduct or operate any home within the
Village without first obtaining a license therefor. (1987 Code)

Notes
2 2. 225 ILCS 10/1 et seq.
4-9-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
The applicant shall file an application with the Village Clerk stating the
following:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The proposed location of the home;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The purpose for which it is to be conducted or operated;
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The accommodations for the inmates thereof;
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The nature and kind of care;
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Instructions or benefits given or proposed to be given;
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â The name and address of the party or parties conducting, managing or
maintaining the home;
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â The name of the superintendent or person in charge of the home; and
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â The name and address of the attending physician. (1987 Code)
4-9-4: INVESTIGATION, INSPECTION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Investigation Of Applicant: The application must be filed with the
Chief of Police who shall make or cause to be made, a strict inquiry into the
facts set out in such application to determine whether such home is or is

the persons received or proposed to be received, and that the superintendent in

Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Building Inspection: Every home shall at all times be opened to
inspection by the Chief of Police, the Fire Chief and the Building Commissioner
whenever and as often as they shall deem proper. (1987 Code)
4-9-5: LICENSE FEE EXEMPTION:
Homes which are operated without charge being made for care of inmates shall be
exempt from the payment of a license fee. Operators of such homes shall file an
affidavit with application stating that no charge is to be made for the care of
inmates. This affidavit shall be investigated as to its credibility by the
Chief of Police and upon his recommendation to the Village Trustees, the
license will be issued without charge. Such exemption shall continue only for
the duration of the license period. (1987 Code)
4-9-6: FRONTAGE CONSENTS REQUIRED:
No license shall be issued to any person to operate or conduct a home in any
block in which two-thirds (2/3) of the buildings on the street are devoted
exclusively to residential purposes unless a majority of the property owners on
both sides of the street in such block consent in writing of the operation of
such home. (1987 Code)
4-9-7: RECORDS:
Every home shall keep a complete record of each inmate showing the date
admitted to the home, name, address, sex, social status, date of discharge,
name and address of persons from whom received. (1987 Code)
4-9-8: BUILDING REQUIREMENTS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Compliance With Building And Fire Regulations: Any building used as a
home shall comply with the building code 1  and fire regulations of the Village
2 .
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Isolation Room For Contagious Diseases: Every home shall be provided
with a suitable room or rooms, to be used for the isolation of cases of
contagious, infectious, epidemic or communicable diseases that may be found in
the home, until such time as the person suffering from such contagious disease
is removed. This room shall have separate toilet facilities and washstands.
(1987 Code)

CHAPTER 10
DAY NURSERIES 1
SECTION:
4-10-1: Definition
4-10-2: Permit Required, Application
4-10-3: Investigation, Inspections
4-10-4: Issuance Of Permit, Term, Appeals
4-10-5: Revocation Of Permit

Notes
1 1. See Title 3, Chapter 1 of this Code and Chapter 9 of this Title.
4-10-1: DEFINITION:
For the purpose of this Chapter the term "day nursery" shall mean any childcare
facility receiving one or more children for care during part or all of a day
between six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and shall include
facilities commonly called "childcare centers", "day nurseries", "nursery
schools", kindergartens", and "playgroups", with or without stated educational
purposes. The term "day nursery" does not include:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Bona fide kindergartens or nursery schools operating under the auspices
of established public or private boards of education;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Bona fide kindergartens or nursery schools approved by the
superintendent of public instruction or the school districts in which such
kindergartens or nursery schools are located; or
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Those facilities operated in connection with a shopping center or
shopping service where transient children are received while parents are
shopping on the premises. (1987 Code)
4-10-2: PERMIT REQUIRED, APPLICATION:
Every person desiring to operate a day nursery in the Village shall obtain a
permit therefor before commencing operation and shall make application therefor
to the Village Clerk on forms furnished by him. The application shall contain
such information as may be required by the Clerk. (1987 Code)
4-10-3: INVESTIGATION, INSPECTIONS:
Upon receipt of an application for a permit required herein, the Village Clerk
shall refer it to the Health Department for investigation. The Health
Department shall inspect the premises where in the day nursery is proposed as
to the following conditions:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The operation and conduct of the facility and the responsibility it
assumes for childcare;
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The character, suitability and qualifications of the applicant and
other persons directly responsible for the care and welfare of children served;
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The general financial ability and competence of the applicant to
provide necessary care for children and to maintain prescribed standards;
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The adequacy of the number of individuals required to ensure adequate
supervision and care of the children;
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â The appropriateness, safety, cleanliness and general adequacy of the
premises, including maintenance of adequate fire prevention and health
standards in conformance to State laws;
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Provisions for food, clothing, education opportunities, program,
equipment and individual supplies to assure the healthy physical, mental and
spiritual development of the children served; and
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Discipline of the children.
The Health Department and the Fire Chief shall make periodic inspections of all
premises used as day nurseries and shall issue such orders as they deem
necessary to maintain health standards and fire protection. (1987 Code)
4-10-4: ISSUANCE OF PERMIT, TERM, APPEALS:
If, after investigation, the Health Department recommends the issuance of the
permit, the Village Clerk shall issue such permit which shall be valid for the
Village license year.
Any person aggrieved by the failure of the Health Department to approve the
issuance of a day nursery permit may appeal to the Board of Trustees whose
decision shall be final. (1987 Code)
4-10-5: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
Any permit issued under the terms of this Chapter may be revoked for the
following reasons:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Consistent failure to maintain health standards prescribed.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Violation of the terms of the license.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Furnishing or making false or misleading information in the
application. (1987 Code)
4-10-6: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The Health Department of the Village shall prescribe rules and regulations
pertaining to the operation and standards of day nurseries. (1987 Code)

hereinafter provided.
It shall be lawful to inter dead bodies within the limits of any cemetery
established and used as a cemetery on September 17, 1934, under such rules and
regulations as may, from time to time, be made by the President and the Board
of Trustees; but the burial of any corpse outside of such limits and within the
Village shall be deemed a violation of this Section. (1987 Code)

CHAPTER 12
GARAGE SALES
SECTION:
4-12-1: Defined
4-12-2: Items Prohibited
4-12-3: Permit Required
4-12-4: Length And Frequency Of Sales
4-12-5: Location Of Sale
4-12-6: Signs
4-12-7: Penalty
4-12-1: DEFINED:
"Garage Sale" means an occasional sale of used or surplus household goods,
furnishings, wares and other items of personal property owned by the occupier
of the residence where such sale is held, and includes sales commonly known as
basement sales, house sales, yard sales, attic sales, rummage sales, estate
sales or other similar occasional sales from residentially zoned premises.
(Ord. 2001-20, 9-10-2001)
4-12-2: ITEMS PROHIBITED:
The sale of the following items is prohibited at a garage sale: food; drink;
animals; bulk sales of any item; multiple new items of the same description;
consigned merchandise; junk or antique items sold as a business activity by a
person involved therein as a junk or antique dealer. Items purchased for
intentional sale or resale may not be sold at such a sale. (Ord. 2001-20, 9-10-
2001)
4-12-3: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or allow a "garage sale" as
defined herein on premises zoned or used for residential purposes without first
obtaining a permit to conduct such sale. The applicant must be the owner or
occupant of the residence where the sale is to be held, and the applicant shall
apply for and obtain such a permit from the village clerk at least seventy two
(72) hours in advance of the date of such sale. There shall be a ten dollar
($10.00) fee for such permit. The permit shall list the name of the applicant
and the address at which the sale is to be held. Each permit shall be
prominently displayed on the premises covered by the permit in such a manner as
to be easily visible to persons passing by the premises on a public street.
(Ord. 2001-20, 9-10-2001)
4-12-4: LENGTH AND FREQUENCY OF SALES:
Garage sales shall be permitted for not more than three (3) consecutive days
between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. of
each day. Not more than three (3) garage sales shall be conducted on the same
premises within any calendar year. (Ord. 2001-20, 9-10-2001)
4-12-5: LOCATION OF SALE:
All activity associated with the garage sale shall be limited to the property
specified on the permit. Additionally, no garage, no sidewalk, street, alley,
or parkway may be hindered, obstructed, or occupied by any items for sale or
any related garage sale activity. (Ord. 2001-20, 9-10-2001)
4-12-6: SIGNS:
No more than two (2) signs advertising the garage/yard sale may be posted on
the lot where the sale is being held, and the size of such signs shall not
exceed two feet by three feet (2' x 3'). Such signs shall not be posted for
more than four (4) days. (Ord. 2002-02, 1-14-2002)
4-12-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this section shall, upon conviction, be
fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one hundred
dollars ($100.00) for each offense. Each day that such a violation occurs or
continues shall be deemed to constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2001-20, 9-
10-2001)
CHAPTER 13
VACANT PROPERTY
SECTION:
4-13-1: Declaration Of Policy
4-13-2: Other Ordinances

4-13-4: Determination
