4-13-15: Single-Family Residential; Registration And Renewal Fee
4-13-16: Multi-Family Residential Or Commercial Buildings; Registration And
Renewal Fee
4-13-17: Industrial Buildings; Registration And Renewal Fee
4-13-1: DECLARATION OF POLICY:
The purpose of this chapter is to protect the public health, safety, and
welfare by:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Establishing a program for identification, registration, and
maintenance of buildings which are or become vacant on and after the effective
date of this chapter.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Determining the responsibilities of the owners of record of vacant
buildings.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Providing for administration, enforcement, including the abatement of
public nuisances, and imposition of penalties. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-2: OTHER ORDINANCES:
This chapter shall not be construed to prevent the enforcement of other
applicable ordinances, codes, legislation, and regulations prescribing
standards other than are provided herein, and in the event of conflict, the
most restrictive shall apply. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-3: DEFINITIONS:
Unless otherwise expressly stated or clearly indicated by context, the
following terms shall, for the purpose of this chapter, have the meanings
indicated in this section:
BOARDED BUILDING: A building which has had in a manner intended to be temporary
or permanent, any or all openings, which openings are windows or doors which
were present for the purpose of light, ventilation or egress, some material
whether opaque, solid or transparent, affixed to such openings, from the
interior or exterior of the building, for the purpose of securing or preventing
access or damage to the building or its components.
BUILDING: Any structure occupied or intended for supporting or sheltering any
occupancy.
DANGEROUS OR UNSAFE BUILDING: All buildings or structures that are found to
pose a danger to the life, health, property or safety of the public by not
providing minimum safeguards to protect or warn the public in the event of a
fire, or because such structure contains unsafe equipment, or is so damaged,
decayed, dilapidated, structurally unsafe or of such faulty or incomplete
construction or unstable, that partial or complete collapse or systems failures
are possible.
DIRECTOR: The building commissioner, or his/her designee.
OWNER: Any person, agent, operator, firm, or corporation having a legal or
equitable interest in the property, including lienholders of record; or
recorded in the official records of the state, county, or municipality as
holding title to the property; or otherwise having control of the property,
including the guardian of the estate of any such person, and the executor or
administrator of the estate of such person if ordered to take possession of
real property by a court.
PERSON: Includes a corporation, a partnership, or other entity, as well as an
individual.
PREMISES: A lot, plot or parcel of land including any structure thereon.
UNOCCUPIED BUILDING: A building or portion thereof which lacks the habitual
presence of human beings who have a legal right to be on the premises,
including buildings ordered vacated by the director pursuant to authority
granted by this code. This definition does not include a building that is
actively for sale, lease or rent, as evidenced by a contractual agreement
between the homeowner of record and a licensed real estate agent or brokerage,
and performance of sufficient maintenance that the building or the property on
which it sits does not become a nuisance.
VACANT BUILDINGS: Any building that has not been legally occupied for a
consecutive period of one month unless one of the following is true:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The building is the subject of an active building permit for repair or
rehabilitation and the owner is progressing diligently to complete the repair
or rehabilitation.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The building meets all codes, is not in a state of disrepair or
deterioration, is ready for occupancy, and is actively being offered for sale,
lease or rent and is actively being maintained and monitored by the owner.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, if the building is still not legally occupied
within thirty (30) days after completion of the repairs as specified in
subsection A of this definition or within sixty (60) days after the director
has determined that the building has met all codes as specified in subsection B
of this definition, the director may declare the building a vacant building.
(Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-4: DETERMINATION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â After the effective date of this chapter, the director shall evaluate
all buildings in the village believed to be unoccupied on the effective date of
this chapter and make a determination for each as to whether the building is a
"vacant building" within the meaning of section
4-13-3 of this chapter. The director may determine that a building which meets
any of the criteria set forth in this chapter is not to be regulated under this
chapter for a stated period, if upon consideration of reliable, substantiated
and sufficient evidence, the director determines that regulation of the
building under this chapter would not serve the public health, welfare, and
safety and makes written findings in support of this decision. The
determination shall be in writing and shall state the factual basis for the
determination.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â For buildings the director determines to be "vacant buildings", the
director shall send notice of this written determination with the factual
findings to the last taxpayer of record listed on the most recent Cook County
tax roll and if notice is to a lienholder then to the address of the
lienholder. Said notice of determination shall be sent first class United
States mail, with proper postage prepaid. Failure of delivery shall not excuse
a person from complying with this chapter. The director may also personally
serve or cause personal service of the notice of determination. Any person
making such service shall execute an affidavit attesting to the facts of
service. The director shall maintain an affidavit of such mailing for each
notice of determination sent.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The notice shall specify a date and time on which the owner may
voluntarily allow for a code compliance inspection of the interior of the
vacant building and surrounding yards and property to determine the extent of
compliance with village property, building, health, fire, and plumbing codes.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â For residential buildings, if a voluntary code compliance inspection is
scheduled by the owner and a plan to maintain the structure, yards and property
is submitted by the owner to and approved by the village, no costs for the code
compliance inspection will be assessed by the village.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â For all residential buildings in which a voluntary code compliance
inspection is not scheduled by the owner and for all commercial and industrial
buildings, all village inspection fees and any costs and fees associated with
all actions to gain entry to the structure, yards and property and any costs
and fees associated in correcting code violations will be the responsibility of
the owner. Any unpaid costs and fees shall be recaptured by a lien upon the
premises.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â The notice shall contain a statement of the obligations of the owner of
a building determined to be vacant, a copy of the registration form the owner
is required to file pursuant to this chapter, and a notice of the owner's right
to appeal the director's determination. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-5: APPEAL OF DETERMINATION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â An owner of a building determined by the director to be a vacant
building as provided for in this chapter may appeal that determination to the
village president. Such appeal shall be in writing and shall be filed with the
village president within fifteen (15) days of the date of mailing of the notice
of determination. The filing of an appeal stays the owner's obligation to
register his building as required by this chapter. The appeal shall contain a
complete statement of the reasons the owner disputes the director's
determination, shall set forth specific facts in support thereof, and shall
include all evidence the owner relies upon to support the appeal. The village
president or the village president's designee shall decide the appeal on the
basis of facts presented by the owner in his or her written appeal and the
director's written determination.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The burden is upon the owner to present sufficient evidence to persuade
the village president that had the evidence been known to the director at the
time the director made the determination, the director would more likely than
not have determined that the subject building was not a "vacant building"
within the meaning of this chapter.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The village president or his designee shall send written notice of a
decision to the owner within thirty (30) days of his or her receipt of the
appeal. The village president may, but is not required to, seek additional
information from the owner. The village president may, upon written notice
thereof to the owner, take no more than ten (10) additional days, to decide the
appeal if he or she determines that such additional time is required for
consideration of the appeal. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-6: REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
The owner of a building who knows, or from all the facts and circumstances
should know, that his or her building is or has become a "vacant building"
within the meaning of this chapter after the effective date of this chapter, or
the owner of a building, which the director determines at any time to be a
"vacant building", or the owner of a building whose appeal from the director's
determination has been denied by the village president shall take the actions
provided for in this section within fifteen (15) days after either the date of
director's notice of determination or occurrence of the facts that would cause
a reasonable person to believe that the building was a "vacant building", or
denial of the appeal, whichever is applicable. Registration does not exonerate
the owner from compliance with all applicable codes and ordinances, including
this chapter, nor does it preclude any of the actions the village is authorized
to take pursuant to this chapter or elsewhere in this code or as allowable by
Illinois or federal law. In such case, the owner shall do the following:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Register the building with the director, on a form provided by the
director and pay the annual nonprorated vacant building registration fee as
provided in this chapter. The form shall include, as a minimum, the name,
street address, and telephone number of the owner; the case name and number of
any litigation pending concerning or affecting the building, including, but not
limited to, bankruptcy, foreclosure and other cases; and the name, street
address, and telephone number of all persons with any legal interest, including
lienholders, in the building or the premises. The form shall require the owner
to identify a natural person twenty one (21) years of age or older who
maintains a permanent address in Cook County, Illinois, to accept service on
behalf of the owner with respect to any notices the director sends pursuant to
this chapter or service of process in any proceeding commenced to enforce any
provision of this chapter, and file with the director on the registration form,
the name, address, telephone number, of said person. A street address is
required. A post office box is not an acceptable address; and
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Renew the vacant building registration each year on the anniversary
date of the first filing for the time the building remains vacant and pay the
annual fee as provided in this chapter; and
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â File an amended registration within fifteen (15) days of any change in
the information contained in the annual registration. A new registration is
required for any change in ownership whatsoever.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The owner executing a form to indicate his or her "acceptance of notice
by posting" consenting to service of notices sent or required to be sent,
pursuant to this chapter, by posting on the building if the owner fails to
renew the registration, if required, or maintain as current with the director
the information required regarding the person designated to accept notice and
service of process.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â The owner shall allow for a code compliance inspection of the interior
of the vacant building and shall be subject to village costs and fees outlined
in this chapter within fifteen (15) days of the registration or renewal
registration. Such inspection will determine the extent of compliance with all
applicable village property, building, electrical, plumbing, fire and similar
codes.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Obtain liability insurance and maintain such insurance for as long as
the building is vacant, and file evidence of such insurance with the director,
as follows:
For a vacant residential building of:
Â 1 to 3 units                                      Â $ 500,000.00
Â 4 to 11 units                                     Â 750,000.00
Â 12 to 48 units                                    Â 1,000,000.00
Â More than 48 units                                Â 2,000,000.00
                                                    Â Â 
For a vacant manufacturing, industrial, storage, or Â 2,000,000.00
nonresidential commercial building
Â 
The director may waive or reduce the required amount of liability insurance in
the director's discretion. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-7: VACANT BUILDING PLAN:
At the time a building is registered as required herein, the owner shall submit
a vacant building plan. The director may prescribe a form for the plan. If the
owner fails to submit the plan as provided for by this section, the director
may determine the plan. The plan shall contain the following as a minimum:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â A plan of action to repair any doors, windows, or other openings which
are boarded up or otherwise secured by any means other than conventional
methods used in the design of the building or permitted for new construction or
similar type. The proposed repair shall result in openings being secured by
conventional methods used in the design of the building or by methods permitted
for new construction of similar type with board removed. The owner shall
maintain the building in an enclosed and secure state until the building is
reoccupied or made available for immediate occupancy. If the owner demonstrates
that securing of the building will provide adequate protection to the public,
the director may waive the requirement of an enclosure.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â For buildings and premises thereof that the director determines as
being or containing public nuisances, as defined in this code, then the vacant
building plan shall contain a plan of action to remedy such public nuisance(s).
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â A time schedule identifying a date of commencement of repair and date
of completion of repair for each improperly secured opening and nuisance
identified by the director.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â When the owner proposes to demolish the vacant building, then the owner
shall submit a plan and time schedule for such demolition.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â A plan of action to maintain the building and premises thereof in
conformance with this chapter.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â A plan of action, with a time schedule, identifying the date the
building will be habitable and occupied or offered for occupancy or sale. The
time schedule shall include date(s) of commencement and completion of all
action required to achieve habitability and shall be based on the time period
as determined by the director, to achieve such compliance.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â All premises upon which unoccupied or vacant buildings are located and
the exteriors shall at all times be maintained in compliance with this code.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Exterior lighting according to standards established by the director.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â On written notice of the director, provide bonded, licensed, and
insured security guard service at the building between the hours of three
o'clock (3:00) P.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. Such service to remain in
place until the director gives written notice that the service is no longer
required. Such service shall be required when the director makes a written
determination that the vacant building constitutes a fire hazard, is otherwise
dangerous to human life or the public welfare, involves illegal or improper
use, occupancy, or maintenance, under such conditions that boarding and
securing the building are insufficient to prevent the actual or threatened
harm.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Affixed to any building which is boarded, a sign, no smaller than two
feet by two feet (2' x 2') and compliant with the village's sign ordinance,
title 9, chapter 8A of this code, and providing the following information: the
name, address, and telephone number of the owner, and in addition, for
buildings that are the subject of a foreclosure action, the name, address, and
telephone number of the plaintiff and the plaintiff's attorney, if any, in the
foreclosure action. The sign must be placed so that its message is legible from
the public way. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-8: APPROVAL OF PLAN:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The director shall review the proposed vacant building plan in
accordance with the standards below. The director shall send notice to the
owner of the vacant building of the director's determination.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In considering the appropriateness of a vacant building plan, the
director shall include the following standards in his or her consideration and
shall make written findings as to each:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The purposes of this chapter and intent of the village board to
minimize the time a building is boarded or otherwise vacant.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The effect of the building and the proposed plan on adjoining
property.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The length of time the building has been vacant.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The presence of any public nuisances on the property.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The likelihood that the plan or portion(s) thereof will prevent or
ameliorate the condition it is designed to address. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-9: MODIFY VACANT BUILDING PLAN:
The director shall, upon notice to the vacant building owner, have the right to
modify the vacant building plan by modifying the dates of performance, the
proposed methods of action, or by imposing additional requirements consistent
with this chapter that the director deems necessary to protect the public
health, safety, or welfare. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-10: FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH PLAN:
Failure to have an approved plan within thirty (30) days of filing the
registration form or failure to comply with the approved plan shall constitute
a violation of this chapter subjecting the owner of the building to penalties
as provided in this chapter and to any remedies the village may avail itself of
as provided for herein and elsewhere in this code or by Illinois law,
including, but limited to, an action to compel correction of property
maintenance violations and/or the correction of property maintenance violations
by the village, and/or its designees, with the owner being liable for any and
all fees for such action. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-11: OTHER ENFORCEMENT:
The registration of a vacant building shall not preclude action by the village
to demolish or to take other action against the building pursuant to other
provisions of this chapter, this code or 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-31-
1. This shall also include the right of the village to secure and take remedial
actions to the building and the premises when it is in the best interest of the
public safety and welfare. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-12: CERTIFICATION:
A certificate of code compliance for vacant buildings issued by the building
department, and payment in full of all fines and fees imposed pursuant to this
chapter are required prior to any occupancy of a vacant building. (Ord. 10-28,
5-3-2010)
4-13-13: TIME RESTRICTIONS:
It is the policy of the village that boarding is a temporary solution to
prevent unauthorized entry into a vacant building and that boarded buildings
are a public nuisance. A vacant building may not remain boarded longer than
fourteen (14) days unless an extension of that time is part of a plan approved
by the director. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-14: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Any person found to have violated any provision of this chapter shall
be subject to the general penalty of this code, in addition to any other legal
or equitable remedies available to the village. Such other remedies include,
but are not limited to, injunctive relief, application to a court of competent
jurisdiction for a receiver, demolition, or condemnation, contracting for the
repair or purchase of the premises, or foreclosure of any lien the village may
have thereon. Any expenses incurred by the village as enumerated above shall be
assessed against the building, and shall serve as a lien on the property.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â A separate and distinct offense shall be committed each day on which
such person or persons shall violate the provisions of this chapter.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The village may enforce this chapter in a system of administrative
adjudication or through the circuit court of Cook County.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Nothing herein contained shall prohibit the village from immediately
condemning, as provided for in this code, a building, or taking other immediate
action upon a determination that the building is a public nuisance or poses an
imminent danger to the occupants of the building, or the public health, safety
and welfare. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-15: SINGLE-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL; REGISTRATION AND RENEWAL FEE:
The registration and renewal fee for each registered single- family residential
building shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), the "base registration
fee". Provided however that the owner shall be charged a fee of five hundred
dollars ($500.00) on the subsequent renewal periods in which any vacant
residential, single-family building is in violation of any provision of this
code. However, if the owner of a single-family residential building can show to
the satisfaction of the director at the time of renewal that the building is in
full compliance with this code then such renewal shall revert to the base
registration fee. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-16: MULTI-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL OR COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS; REGISTRATION AND
RENEWAL FEE:
The registration and renewal fee for each registered multi-family residential
or commercial building shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00), the "base
registration fee". Provided however that the owner shall be charged a fee of
one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) on the subsequent renewal periods in which any
vacant multi- family residential or commercial building is in violation of any
provision of this code. However, if the owner of a multi-family residential or
commercial building can show to the satisfaction of the director at the time of
renewal that the building is in full compliance with this code then such
renewal shall revert to the base registration fee. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
4-13-17: INDUSTRIAL BUILDINGS; REGISTRATION AND RENEWAL FEE:
The registration and renewal fee for each registered industrial building shall
be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), the "base registration fee". Provided
however that the owner shall be charged a fee of two thousand dollars
($2,000.00) on the subsequent renewal periods in which any vacant industrial
building is in violation of any provision of this code. If the owner of an
industrial building can show to the satisfaction of the director at the time
renewal is required that the building is in full compliance with this code then
such renewal shall revert to the base registration fee. (Ord. 10-28, 5-3-2010)
CHAPTER 14
LIENS
SECTION:
4-14-1: Notice Of Lien
4-14-2: Priority Lien
4-14-1: NOTICE OF LIEN:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Removal Cost: If the village elects to incur a removal cost under this
title, then that cost is a lien upon the underlying parcel. To perfect such a
lien, the village must, within one year after the removal cost is incurred,
file notice of lien in the office of the recorder in Cook County. The notice
must consist of a sworn statement setting out: 1) a description of the
underlying parcel that sufficiently identifies the parcel; 2) the amount of the
removal cost; and 3) the date or dates when the removal cost was incurred by
the village. If, for any one parcel, the village engaged in any removal
activity on more than one occasion during the course of one year, then the
village may combine any or all of the costs of each of those activities into a
single notice of lien.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Notice: The removal cost is not a lien on the underlying parcel unless
a notice is personally served on, or sent by certified mail to, the person to
whom was sent the tax bill for the general taxes on the property for the
taxable year immediately preceding the removal activities. The notice must be
delivered or sent after the removal activities have been performed, and it
must: 1) state the substance of this chapter; and 2) identify the underlying
parcel, by common description; and 3) describe the removal activity.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Payment Of The Lien Cost: Upon payment of the lien cost by the owner of
the underlying parcel, after notice of lien has been filed, the village (or its
agent) shall release the lien, and the release may be filed of record by the
owner at his or her sole expense as in the case of filing notice of lien.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Illinois Municipal Code: The provisions of the Illinois municipal code,
specifically section 11-20-15, shall be followed and shall apply to all liens
filed hereunder.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Foreclosure Of Lien: Subsequent to the filing of the above described
lien, the village may cause to be filed a complaint for foreclosure of such
lien, or upon becoming a defendant in a pending lawsuit affecting the premises
or real estate, by answer to the complaint or in the nature of an intervening
petition or cross complaint, the village may proceed in its corporate name to
foreclose such lien. An action to foreclose a lien under this title must be
commenced within two (2) years after the date of filing notice of lien. The
property subject to a lien arising under this chapter shall be sold for
nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to pay
the monies owing the village. (Ord. 13-36, 5-20-2013)
4-14-2: PRIORITY LIEN:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Priority Lien: The priority lien procedure described in this section
shall apply only to costs incurred for activities performed on abandoned
residential properties, as defined in chapter 13, "Vacant Property", of this
title and is an alternative to the traditional lien authorized by section
4-14-1 of this chapter. If a bill sent pursuant to section
4-14-1 of this chapter is not paid in full within thirty (30) days of the date
of the bill, the village shall have the authority to file and record a priority
lien against the property, pursuant to section 11-20-15.1 of the Illinois
municipal code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-15.1, in the following
manner:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Notice Of Lien: The village or the person performing the service by
authority of the village, in its, his or her own name, may file a notice of a
priority lien in the office of the recorder of deeds in the county in which the
real estate is located. The notice of lien shall be filed within one year after
the cost and expense is incurred. If, for any one property, the village engaged
in any nuisance abatement activity described in section 98.03 on more than one
occasion during the course of one year, then the village may combine any or all
of the costs of those activities into a single notice of lien.
The notice of lien shall consist of a sworn statement setting forth:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â A description of the abandoned residential property that
sufficiently describes the parcel;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The amount of the cost incurred or payable for the activities;
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â The date or dates when such cost was incurred by the village or
someone working on behalf of the village; and
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â A statement that the lien has been filed pursuant to one or more
of the property maintenance activities described in section 98.03 and
authorized by 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-7(d), 5/11-20-8(d), 5/11-
20-12(d), 5/11-20-13(e), 5/11-31-1.01, as applicable.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Sent By Certified Mail: After recording, the notice of lien shall be
sent by certified mail to the property owner, his agent or legal representative
or occupant in legal possession or control of the premises and, if different,
to the person who received the tax bill for the preceding year.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Remedial Actions: The village may not file a lien if the lender has
provided notice to the village that the lender has performed, or will perform,
remedial actions; provided, however, that the remedial actions must be
performed or initiated in good faith, within thirty (30) days of the lender's
notice to the village.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Recordkeeping: To enforce a lien pursuant to this section, the village
must maintain contemporaneous records that include, at a minimum:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Dated statement of a finding by the village that the property has
become abandoned residential property;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The date when the property was first observed to be unoccupied by
any lawful occupant;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â A description of the actions taken by the village to contact the
legal owner of the property, or if known, any agent of the owner;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â A statement that no contacts were made with the legal owner or, if
known, any agent of the owner;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â A dated certification by a village official of the necessity and
specific nature of the work performed;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â A copy of the agreement with the person or company performing the
work and the rates and estimated cost of the work, if applicable;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Detailed invoices and payment vouchers for the work;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â A statement whether the work was competitively bid, and if so, a
copy of all proposals submitted by the bidders.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Release Of Lien: Upon payment of the cost after the notice of lien has
been filed as provided herein, the lien shall be released by the village or
person in whose name the lien has been filed, and the release shall be recorded
of record in the same manner as recording the notice of lien.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Enforcement Of Lien: A lien under this section is enforceable by the
village, or entity or person who performs work on behalf of the village, at the
hearing for confirmation of the foreclosure sale of the abandoned residential
property and is limited to a claim of interest in the proceeds of the sale. The
priority lien is superior to all other liens and encumbrances, except tax
liens. (Ord. 13-36, 5-20-2013)
CHAPTER 15
NOISE
SECTION:
4-15-1: Declaration Of Policy

4-15-1: DECLARATION OF POLICY:
It is hereby declared that the making, creation or maintenance of excessive,
loud, raucous or unnecessary noise within the Village affects and endangers the
public health, comfort, convenience, safety, and welfare of the people of the
Village. The provisions and prohibitions hereinafter contained are enacted for
the purpose of securing and promoting the public health, safety, and welfare of
the Village and its residents. (Ord. 2014-65, 11-3-2014)
4-15-2: DEFINITIONS:
Certain words and terms used in this chapter are hereby defined as follows:

4-15-3: UNLAWFUL NOISE:
It is unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person within the
Village to make, continue, or cause to be made or continued, any excessive,
loud, raucous or unnecessary noise within the limits of the Village. (Ord.
2014-65, 11-3-2014)
4-15-4: SPECIFIC LIMITATIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, acts declared to be excessive, loud, raucous
or unnecessary noises include, but are not limited to, the following:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Instruments And Sound Amplification Devices: The playing, using,
operating or permitting to be played, used or operated of any musical
instrument or sound amplification device, or combination thereof, played or
operated in such a manner as to disturb the peace, quiet comfort and repose of
the neighboring inhabitants or at more volume than is necessary for the
convenient hearing for the person or persons who are in the room, chamber,
vehicle or outdoor area, within the Village limits, in which or where such
instrument or sound amplification device is played, used or operated and who
are voluntary listeners thereto. The playing, use or operation of any such
instrument or sound amplification device between the hours of ten o'clock (10:
00) P.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. in such manner as to be plainly audible
for a continuous period of one minute or more at a distance of seventy five
feet (75') from the location of such instrument or sound amplification device
shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Yelling, Shouting, And Similar Activities: Yelling, shouting, hooting,
whistling or singing in the public parks, parkways and streets of the Village,
particularly between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and eight o'clock
(8:00) A.M., or at any other time or place so as to annoy or disturb the peace,
quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office, business establishment,
dwelling or residence or of any person in the vicinity within the limits of the
Village.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Advertising Noise Or Attention: The playing, using, operating or
permitting to be played, used or operated of any instrument or sound
amplification device which is cast upon the public streets, parks and parkways
of the Village for the purpose of commercial advertising or of attracting the
attention of the public to any building or structure, except when a permit has
first been procured from the proper Village authorities.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Animals: The keeping of any animal within any yard, house, enclosure,
garage or other place within the Village, which by frequent or long continued
barking, howling, crying, singing or other noise shall disturb the peace,
quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any neighboring dwelling or residence or
of persons in the vicinity within the limits of the Village.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Construction; Landscaping: The conduct of any outside construction,
excavation, demolition, alteration or repair work, or landscaping activities
other than between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:
00) P.M. on week days, and between nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:
00) P.M. on weekends, except in case of urgent necessity in the interest of
public health and safety, and then only with the written permission of the
Building Director, which permit may be granted for a period not to exceed three
(3) days or less while the emergency continues. The permit may be renewed for
periods of three (3) days or less while the emergency continues. The Building
Director should, in making a determination regarding such a permit request that
the permittee will suffer loss or inconvenience in the absence of such a
permit, that the public health and safety necessitate such work, and that the
noise generated during the hours requested will not negatively impact or impair
persons or businesses in the vicinity.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Exhausts: The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam
engine, stationary internal combustion engine, motorboat or motor vehicle
except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or
explosive noises therefrom.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Blowers And Generators: The use or operation of any noise creating
blower, power fan, or internal combustion generator within twenty five feet
(25') of any residential property between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00)
P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Defect In Vehicle Or Load: The use of any automobile, truck, cart,
trailer, motorcycle or other vehicle, so out of repair or loaded in such a
manner or with material of such nature so as to create loud, excessive or
unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noises.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Loading/Unloading: Causing, allowing or permitting the loading,
unloading, opening or handling of boxes, crates. containers, garbage cans or
recyclable containers between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. and seven
o'clock (7:00) A.M. daily when such operations are conducted on a property
within the Village located within seventy five feet (75') of any residential
property within the Village, measured from the property line of the residential
property.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Drums: The use of any drum or similar instrument or device for the
purpose of attracting attention, by the creation of noise, to any place of
business, entertainment or public assembly.
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â Horns And Signaling Devices: The use or operation of any horn or
signaling device on any motor vehicle within the Village, except as a danger
warning or in an emergency. No person shall use or operate any horn or
signaling device operated by an engine exhaust or for the purpose of attempting
to increase traffic flow or move traffic in any manner. (Ord. 2014-65, 11-3-
2014)
4-15-5: AMPLIFIED SOUND - MOTOR VEHICLES:
No person shall cause, allow or permit the operation of any sound amplification
device, including but not limited to a radio, loudspeaker or stereo, from any
motor vehicle which is plainly audible outside the vehicle at a distance of
seventy five feet (75') or more from the motor vehicle. This provision shall
not apply to any sound amplification device being operated by an authorized
emergency vehicle. (Ord. 2014-65, 11-3-2014)
4-15-6: EMERGENCY SIGNALING DEVICES:
No person shall sound, allow or permit the sounding outdoors of any emergency
signaling device, including fire, burglar, civil defense alarm, siren, whistle,
or similar emergency signaling device except in an emergency or as a permitted
test as specified herein. Permitted testing of an emergency signaling device
may only occur between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and seven o'clock
(7:00) P.M. Any testing shall use only the minimum cycle test time for the
emergency signaling device, but in no event shall the test time exceed five (5)
minutes. (Ord. 2014-65, 11-3-2014)
4-15-7: MUFFLERS:
No person shall operate a motor vehicle within the Village that is not equipped
with an adequate muffler or exhaust system in constant operation and properly
maintained to prevent any excessive or unusual noise. No person shall operate a
motor vehicle with a muffler or exhaust system modified with a cutout bypass or
similar device. (Ord. 2014-65, 11-3-2014)
4-15-8: SCHOOLS; LIBRARIES; CHURCHES; NURSING HOMES AND HOSPITALS:
No person shall cause, make or assist in the making of any noise or diversion
which disturbs or tends to disturb the peace or good order or interferes with
operation of any school, library, church, nursing home or hospital within the
Village. (Ord. 2014-65, 11-3-2014)
4-15-9: EXEMPTIONS:
Sounds caused by the following are exempt from the prohibitions contained in
this chapter:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Utility Repairs: Repairs of utility structures that pose a clear and
immediate danger to life or safety.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Emergency Vehicles: Sirens, whistles or bells lawfully used by
emergency vehicles.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Emergency Signals: The emission of sound for the purpose of alerting
persons to the existence of an emergency or in the performance of emergency
work.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Repairs: Repairs or excavations of bridges, streets or highways, or
utilities by or on behalf of the Village, Cook County, the State of Illinois or
the United States government between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. and
seven o'clock (7:00) A.M., when the public welfare and convenience renders it
impractical to perform the work during hours otherwise allowed by ordinance.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Parades And Public Events: Parades and public events, provided that
such events are Village-sponsored or a permit has been obtained from the
appropriate permitting authority.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Power Outages: Internal combustion engines when used during power
outages to generate electricity, prevent freezing or to prevent flooding. (Ord.
2014-65, 11-3-2014)
4-15-10: AUTHORIZED COMPLAINANTS:
Any person witnessing a violation of the provisions of this chapter, including
a police officer, is authorized to be a complainant on any complaint, citation
or other notice of violation issued under this chapter. (Ord. 2014-65, 11-3-
2014)
4-15-11: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating or being liable under any of the
provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than seventy five dollars
($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for a first
violation within the past twelve (12) months, not less than one hundred fifty
dollars ($150.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for a
second violation within the past twelve (12) months, and not less than three
hundred dollars ($300.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00)
for a third or subsequent offense within the past twelve (12) months. A
separate offense shall be deemed committed with each recurrence of a violation
of the noise disturbance provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 2014-65, 11-3-2014)
CHAPTER 16
PUBLIC CAMPING PROHIBITION AND RELATED ENFORCEMENT
SECTION:
4-16-1: Public Camping As A Nuisance
4-16-2: Regulation Of Public Camping Necessary To Promote Public Health
4-16-3: Public Camping Not Intended Use Of Public Property
4-16-4: Definitions
4-16-5: Public Camping Prohibited
4-16-6: Exceptions To Prohibition
4-16-7: Removal Of Campsite

4-16-9: Penalty; Mitigation
4-16-1: PUBLIC CAMPING AS A NUISANCE:
Public Camping, as the term is defined herein, is hereby declared to be a
nuisance within the Village for the reasons identified above.
(Ord. CO-2024-11, 8-5-2024)
4-16-2: REGULATION OF PUBLIC CAMPING NECESSARY TO PROMOTE PUBLIC HEALTH:
In an effort to address the public health concerns identified above, the
President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Broadview hereby declare it
necessary or expedient for the promotion of health or the suppression of
diseases, to regulate public camping, as that term is defined herein, within
the Village's corporate limits.
(Ord. CO-2024-11, 8-5-2024)
4-16-3: PUBLIC CAMPING NOT INTENDED USE OF PUBLIC PROPERTY:
Except for those parcels of property specifically designated by the Village in
any subsequent ordinance, the Village hereby declares that none of its property
is permitted nor intended to be used for public camping, as the term is defined
herein.
(Ord. CO-2024-11, 8-5-2024)
4-16-4: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions apply to this chapter:
Â 
BEDDING:                  A sleeping bag, or any other material, used for
                          bedding purposes.
                          Any physical space that is not within an established
                          structure, where bedding or any stove or fire is
                          placed, established or maintained for the purpose of
CAMPSITE:                 maintaining a temporary place to live, whether or not
                          such place incorporates the use of any tent, lean-to,
                          shack or any other structure, or any vehicle or part
                          thereof.
                          Items which would otherwise constitute personal
                          property under the terms of this chapter, but which
                          (i) has no apparent utility or monetary value; (ii)
                          personal property which is unsanitary to store or
                          otherwise maintain; (iii) any weapon possessed
EXEMPT PERSONAL PROPERTY: illegally; (iv) drug paraphernalia; (v) items
                          appearing to be stolen or otherwise appearing to be
                          evidence of a crime; (vi) items which the person
                          cannot demonstrate the requisite lawful authority to
                          possess; and, (vii) any items of food which can
                          reasonably be expected to spoil or otherwise perish
                          within the next thirty (30) days.
                          Any item reasonably recognizable as belonging to a
PERSONAL PROPERTY:        person and having apparent utility or monetary value,
                          except for exempt personal property.
PUBLIC CAMPING:           To cause or participate in the establishment of, or
                          the act of remaining in or at, a campsite.
Â 
(Ord. CO-2024-11, 8-5-2024)
4-16-5: PUBLIC CAMPING PROHIBITED:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â No person may sleep, nor otherwise engage in public camping, on a
public sidewalk, street, alley, lane, other public right-of-way, park, bench,
or any other publicly-owned property, nor on or under any bridge or viaduct, at
any time.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â No person may sleep, nor otherwise engage in public camping, in any
pedestrian or vehicular entrance to public or private property abutting a
public right-of-way.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â No person may sleep, nor otherwise engage in public camping, on any
real property owned or otherwise maintained by the Village.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â No person may park a vehicle overnight within the Village for the
purpose of sleeping or otherwise engaging in public camping in said vehicle.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â For the purposes of this section, the act of parking or leaving a
vehicle parked for two (2) consecutive hours, and/or remaining within a public
vehicle on any property under the jurisdiction of the Village for the purpose
of public camping, for two (2) consecutive hours without permission from the
President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Broadview, between the hours
of midnight (12:00) and six (6:00) A.M., shall be considered a violation of
this chapter.
(Ord. CO-2024-11, 8-5-2024)
4-16-6: EXCEPTIONS TO PROHIBITION:
Notwithstanding the foregoing, it shall not be a violation to engage in public
camping when done (i) in a manner specifically authorized by this Code; (ii)
after a formal declaration of the Village in emergency circumstances; or, (iii)
upon resolution of the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of
Broadview, the same may exempt a special event from the prohibitions of this
section, if the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Broadview
finds such exemption to be in the public interest and consistent with the goals
and objectives of the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of
Broadview, and with such conditions imposed as the President and Board of
Trustees of the Village of Broadview deems necessary. Any conditions imposed
will include a condition requiring that the applicant provide evidence of
adequate insurance coverage and agree to indemnify the Village for any
liability, damage or expense incurred by the Village as a result of the
activities of the applicant. Any findings by the President and Board of
Trustees of the Village of Broadview shall specify the exact dates and location
covered by the exemption.
(Ord. CO-2024-11, 8-5-2024)
4-16-7: REMOVAL OF CAMPSITE:
Removal of a campsite in violation of this chapter may occur under the
following circumstances:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Prior to removing a campsite, the Village shall post a notice, twenty-
four (24) hours in advance of the removal, unless immediate removal of the
campsite is deemed to be necessary for one of the reasons in subparagraphs 1-4,
below. If such immediate removal is undertaken, the basis for causing the
immediate removal of such campsite should be adequately documented by the
appropriate person(s).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Immediate removal of the campsite is necessary to maintain access to
a property;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Immediate removal of the campsite is necessary to maintain the
sanitary condition of a property;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Immediate removal of the campsite is necessary because the campsite
is an obstruction to any public right-of-way; or,
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Immediate removal of the campsite is necessary because the campsite
poses a risk to the health and safety of the Village and its residents.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Upon any action pursuant to Section A, above, the person causing such
action to be taken shall inform an appropriate agency delivering social
services to homeless individuals in the Village, of the location of the
campsite and the persons found to be in violation of this chapter, so said
agency may determine whether or not it would be appropriate to offer its
services to those persons.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â If a twenty-four (24) hour notice has been posted, and the twenty-four
(24) hour notice period has passed, then the campsite, as well as all personal
property thereon, shall be removed by the appropriate person(s) acting on
behalf of the Village.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â No portion of this Section shall be construed to prohibit any person
found to be engaging in public camping from removing their personal property
from the campsite; however, such personal property that constitutes exempt
personal property and which a reasonably prudent law enforcement officer,
exercising the applicable constitutional standard, would conclude that said
exempt personal property constitutes items appearing to be stolen or otherwise
appearing to be evidence of a crime, and/or items which the person cannot
demonstrate the requisite lawful authority to possess, may be retained and
stored as evidence.
(Ord. 2024-11, 8-5-2024)
4-16-8: DISPOSITION AND RELEASE OF PERSONAL PROPERTY:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â All personal property removed from any campsite which is not exempt
personal property shall be stored by the appropriate law enforcement agency of
the Village, for a minimum of thirty (30) days, during which time it shall be
reasonably available for and released to an individual confirming ownership.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â All exempt personal property may be disposed of or retained as evidence
by the appropriate law enforcement agency of the Village.
(Ord. CO-2024-11, 8-5-2024)
4-16-9: PENALTY; MITIGATION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â The penalty for any person's first violation of this chapter within a
rolling twenty-four (24) month period shall be seventy-five dollars ($75).
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The penalty for any person's second violation of this chapter within a
rolling twenty-four (24) month period shall be one hundred fifty dollars
($150).
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â The penalty for any person's third violation of this chapter within a
rolling twenty-four (24) month period shall be three hundred fifty dollars
($350).
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â The penalty for any person's' fourth violation of this chapter within a
rolling twenty-four (24) month period shall be five hundred dollars ($500).
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â The penalty for any person's fifth violation of this chapter within a
rolling twenty-four (24) month period shall be seven hundred fifty dollars
($750);
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â The penalty for any person's sixth or subsequent violation of this
chapter within a rolling twenty-four (24) month period may be a monetary
penalty of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750) or incarceration for a period not
exceeding the maximum time allowed pursuant to Section 1-2-9 of the Illinois
Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/1-2-9).
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â As a substitute for any monetary penalty assessed pursuant to
paragraphs A-F, above, and if consented to by the Village, the penalty assessed
to any person found in violation of this chapter may be that said person must
engage in public service by cleaning the rights-of-way and other public
facilities of the Village for an amount of time that, if the person found to
have violated this chapter was being paid the minimum wage under Illinois law,
the amount paid for that person's labors would have been equal to the monetary
penalty assessed under this section.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â The Village is hereby empowered to exercise all powers afforded to it,
at law or in equity, to collect any fines assessed against a person pursuant to
this chapter, including but not limited to seeking incarceration of said person
for a period of time that conforms with Section 1-2-9 of the Illinois Municipal
Code (65 ILCS 5/1-2-9).
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â In the imposition of any penalty pursuant to this Section, the penalty
shall be mitigated by whether or not the person immediately removed all
personal property and litter, including but not limited to bottles, cans, and
garbage, from the campsite after the person was informed that the person was in
violation of this chapter.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â A separate offense of this section shall be deemed committed on each
day on which a violation occurs or continues.
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â In addition to any other remedy provided by law or this chapter, any
person found in violation of this section may be immediately removed from the
premises where the campsite is located.
(Ord. CO-2024-11, 8-5-2024)

5-1-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
A department to be hereafter known as the Broadview Fire Department, the object
of which shall be the prevention and extinguishment of fire and the protection
of life and property within the limits of the Village, is hereby created. (1987
Code)
5-1-2: FIRE CHIEF:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Chief: The Fire Department shall be headed by a Chief, who shall be the
Administrator, and shall be appointed by the President with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees. The Chief shall be technically qualified by
training and experience and shall have the ability to command men and hold
their respect and confidence. The Chief shall reside in the Village. He may be
removed from office by the President as provided by statute. (Ord. 87-5, 7-20-
1987)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Powers And Duties:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Generally: The Fire Chief shall have control, subject to the order
and direction of the Board of Trustees, of the Fire Department and of all fire
apparatus belonging to the Village. Whenever any fire apparatus needs
repairing, the Fire Chief shall cause same to be done without delay. The Chief
shall be held accountable to the President and Board of Trustees only and shall
make written and verbal reports thereto as the President and Board of Trustees
may require. All other department companies and officers shall be accountable
to the Chief.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Formulate Rules And Regulations: The Chief shall formulate a set of
rules and regulations to govern the department, which rules and regulations
shall be in conformity with the rules and regulations of the Board of Fire and
Police Commissioners 1 , and shall be responsible to the President and Board of
Trustees for the personnel, morale and general efficiency of the department.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Determine Department Composition: The Fire Chief shall determine the
number and kind of divisions, platoons and companies of which the Fire
Department is to be composed and shall determine the response of such platoons
and companies.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Conduct Monthly Drills: The Fire Chief shall, at least once a month,
conduct suitable drills or instructions in the operation and handling of
equipment, first aid, rescue work, salvage, a study of buildings in the
Village, fire prevention, water supplies and all other matters considered
essential to good firemanship and safety of life and property from fire.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Records: The Fire Chief shall see that complete records are kept on
all fires, inspections, apparatus and minor equipment, personnel and other
information about the work of the department.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Reports:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â The Fire Chief shall submit a monthly report to the President and
Board of Trustees containing a statistical analysis of the activities of the
Firefighting Division, Training Division, Fire Prevention Bureau, Mechanical
Division and Personnel Division of the department.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The Fire Chief shall make a complete annual report to the
President and Board of Trustees within one month after the close of the fiscal
year. Such report shall include the information specified in subsection B6a of
this section together with comparative data for previous years and
recommendations for improving the effectiveness of the department. (1987 Code)
Â 
Notes
1 1. See title 2, chapter 1 of this Code.
5-1-3: COMPOSITION OF DEPARTMENT:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Officers And Members:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Department Members: A Deputy Chief, three (3) Captains, three (3)
Lieutenants and such additional members of the Fire Department as may from time
to time be prescribed by the Chief and approved by the President and Board of
Trustees shall constitute the remainder of the department and they shall
function as provided by the rules and regulations of the Fire Department.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Paid On-Call Firefighter:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Number Recommended By Chief: The department may be supplemented
by "paid on-call firefighters", the number of which may be recommended by the
Chief with the approval of the President and Board of Trustees.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Membership; Appointment; Removal; Obedience To Orders: The
membership of the "paid on-call firefighters" shall consist of such persons as
may be appointed by the Chief with the approval of the President and Board of
Trustees. Appointments shall be made by the Chief only after a medical and
physical examination and such other examination as prescribed by the Chief and
President and Board of Trustees. Any member of the department who is a "paid
on-call firefighter" may be suspended or discharged from the department by the
Chief at any time he may deem such action necessary for the good of the
department. Any member of the department who is a "paid on-call firefighter" in
attendance at a fire and who shall neglect or refuse to obey the orders of the
officer in command at the fire, shall be subject to immediate dismissal. (Ord.
87-5, 7-20-1987)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Inspectors: The Fire Chief may detail such members of the Fire
Department as inspectors as shall from time to time be necessary only after the
approval of the President. The Fire Chief shall recommend to the Village the
employment of technical inspectors who, when such authorization is made, shall
be selected through an examination to determine their fitness for the position.
The examination shall be open to members and nonmembers of the Fire Department,
and appointments made after examination shall be for an indefinite term with
removal only for cause. (1987 Code)
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Fire Department Organization: The Fire Department may have a social
organization approved by the Fire Chief and the President and Board of Trustees
and may hold such meetings and engage in such social functions and community
activities as the rules provide. Officers of the organization may be elected by
members of the department, and shall include a Secretary and Treasurer and the
officers shall make such rules and regulations as may be necessary. In the
event foreign fire insurance sums are received by the Fire Department, the
Treasurer shall give a sufficient bond to the Village. Any monies so received
shall be used only as provided by statute. (Ord. 87-5, 7-20-1987)
5-1-4: BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Bureau Established: The Bureau of Fire Prevention in the Fire
Department is hereby established and shall be operated under the supervision of
the Chief of the Fire Department. (1987 Code)
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Annual Report: A report of the Bureau of Fire Prevention shall be made
annually and transmitted to the Chief Executive Officer of the Municipality. It
shall contain all proceedings under the Fire Code 1 , with such statistics as
the Chief of the Fire Department may wish to include therein. (1987 Code; amd.
Ord. 2018-33, 12-17-2018)
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Chief Enforcement Officer: The Chief Enforcement Officer of the Fire
Code shall be a current sworn member of the Fire Department who shall be
appointed by the Fire Chief and who shall serve until a successor is appointed.
The Chief Enforcement Officer shall be under the supervision and control of the
Fire Chief and shall perform, in addition to the regular firefighting duties
which may be assigned, all duties required of the officer under the provisions
of the Fire Code and the ordinances of the Village. (Ord. 89-11, 8-7-1989; amd.
Ord. 2018-33, 12-17-2018)
Â 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 2 of this title.
5-1-5: FIRE PROTECTION TRAINING:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Village To Participate In State Programs: The Village hereby elects to
participate in the programs provided for in the Illinois Fire Protection
Training Act 2 .
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Certification Required: Before an individual may commence regular full-
time employment as a firefighter, he must have been certified by the Illinois
State Fire Marshal as a firefighter II and as having successfully completed an
approved training course as provided in said Act. Except for part-time
personnel, the firefighter II training must be completed by the trainee within
his probationary period.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Incorporation Into Rules And Regulations: The Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners is hereby instructed and directed to make the necessary
amendments to the Personnel Rules, the Manual of Rules of the Broadview Fire
Department and rules of said Board of Fire and Police Commissioners in order to
require that any person appointed to the Fire Department of the Village shall
not become a regular member of the said department unless and until he shall
complete, pursuant to said Illinois Fire Protection and Training Act, the
approved training course within twelve (12) months of the date of his initial
employment. (1987 Code)

Notes
2 2. 50 ILCS 740/1 et seq.
5-1-6: POWERS AND DUTIES OF MEMBERS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Fire Prevention Duties: It shall be the function and duty of the Fire
Department and every member thereof to extinguish accidental or destructive
fires and to prevent the occurrence or spread of such fires.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Police Powers: All regularly appointed members of the department are
hereby given the necessary special police powers for the purpose of enforcing
the provisions of this title. (1987 Code)
5-1-7: COMPENSATION:
The compensation of the officers and members of the Fire Department shall be
prescribed from time to time by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village. (1987 Code)
5-1-8: FIREFIGHTERS' PENSION FUND 1 :
There shall be a Firefighters' Pension Fund established in the Village as
provided by statute 2 . (Ord. 87-5, 7-20-1987)

Notes
1 1. See section 2-3-1 of this Code.
2 2. 40 ILCS 5/4-101 et seq.
5-1-9: BADGE ISSUED:
Each member of the Fire Department shall be issued a badge designating his
rank. (1987 Code)
5-1-10: FIREFIGHTER TO OBEY ORDERS:
Any firefighter in attendance at a fire who shall neglect or refuse to obey the
orders of the officer in command at such fire shall, upon conviction, be fined
in accordance with the rules and regulations as set forth by the Fire
Department and the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. (Ord. 87-5, 7-20-
1987)
5-1-11: EQUIPMENT:
The Fire Department shall be equipped with such apparatus and other equipment
as may be required from time to time to maintain its efficiency and properly
protect life and property from fire.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Purchases: Recommendations for the apparatus and equipment needed
pursuant to this section shall be made by the Fire Chief. Said recommendations
shall be approved by, and after approval, shall be purchased in such manner as
may be designated by the President and Board of Trustees.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Storage Locations: All equipment of the fire department shall be safely
and conveniently housed in such place as may be designated by the president and
board of trustees.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Prohibited Acts:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Improper Use: No person shall use any fire apparatus or equipment
for any private purpose.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Injury To, Interference With Equipment: No person shall wilfully or
negligently break, deface or in any manner injure any fire engine, hose
equipment or other fire apparatus belonging to the fire department, or shall
remove any screw, bolt, nut or any part of such engine or fire apparatus or in
any manner interfere with the same when being used by the proper person or
authority.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Entering Firehouse: It shall be unlawful for any person to enter the

Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Authority Of Officer In Charge: When the service of rescue squad 213
and/or rescue squad 218 is called for, the officer of the rescue squad shall be
in charge of the emergency and will be responsible for all orders given and

emergency lend assistance, they shall follow the orders of the officer in
charge of the rescue squad. The authority of the Fire Department officer
extends only to the well being of the injured and not to the administrative
police matters in connection with the emergency calls not involving fire.

5-1-11-4: RESPONSIBILITY FOR PAYMENT:
The person transported shall be responsible for payment of the charge to the

estate, executor, beneficiaries, heirs or assigns. (Ord. 92-2, 2-3-1992)
5-1-11-5: MUTUAL AID CALLS:
Pursuant to chapter 4 of this title, the Village participates in the Mutual
Fire Aid Program with neighboring municipalities.
In the event that the Village Fire Department ambulance responds to a mutual
aid call in a neighboring municipality, the Village will charge an ambulance
user fee on a reciprocal basis; that is, if the neighboring municipality has
enacted a user fee for ambulance services, the Village will reciprocally charge
that fee; however, if the neighboring municipality has not enacted a user fee,
the Village will reciprocally not charge a fee. (Ord. 92-2, 2-3-1992; amd. Ord.
98-04, 3-16-1998)
5-1-11-6: EFFECTIVE DATE:
This ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage and
publication in accordance with law. (Ord. 92-2, 2-3-1992)
5-1-11-7: ENGINE AND CREW FEES:
Any person, firm or corporation receiving emergency fire service of an engine
and crew from the Village shall be charged the following fees: two hundred
fifty dollars ($250.00) per engine and thirty five dollars ($35.00) per crew
member, per hour or any part thereof, payable to the Village. (Ord. 98-04, 3-
16-1998; amd. Ord. 13-68, 10-21-2013)

5-2-1: FIRE PREVENTION CODE ADOPTED:
There is hereby adopted for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing
conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion, those certain
codes known as the International Fire Code (2018 edition) and appendices as
stated below and the Life Safety Code, NFPA 101 (2015 edition), save and except
those portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified or amended, copies of which
are available in the Village Clerk's Office in compliance with section 1-3-2 of
the Illinois Municipal Code 1 Â and the same are hereby adopted and incorporated
as if fully set forth herein, and from the effective date hereof, the
provisions thereof shall be controlling within the limits of the Village. Where
there are competing clauses or conflicts occur between the codes adopted in
this section (International Fire Code (IFC) and the Life Safety Code (LSC 101
or NFPA 101)) and another referenced code or standard, the codes adopted by
this section shall prevail to the extent the referenced code or standard
includes subject matter that is within the scope of the codes adopted by this
section.
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â IFC International Fire Code 2018 appendices B, D, E, F, G, H, I, K and
N are adopted as part of this Code as follows:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Appendices D, F, G, I and N are adopted as regulatory and
enforceable parts of this Code.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Appendices B, E, H, and K, are adopted as reference guidelines only.
(Ord. 2018-33, 12-17-2018; amd. Ord. 2020-7, 2-18-2020)
