7-4.2-3: CONFLICT OF LAW:
The provisions of this chapter shall be in addition to and shall not replace or
otherwise abrogate any existing state or federal law or village ordinance that
relates to the seizure and/or impoundment of motor vehicles, and any penalty
provided herein shall be in addition to any and all penalties that may be
assessed or imposed by a court for violation of any criminal offense or local
ordinance violation offense. (Ord. 09-39, 9-8-2009)
7-4.2-4: APPROVAL OF TOWING COMPANY FEES:
Any and all fees incurred for towing and/or storage of a motor vehicle seized
under this chapter shall be those approved by the chief of police for all
towing companies authorized to operate in the village. (Ord. 09-39, 9-8-2009)
7-4.2-5: THEFT OF MOTOR VEHICLE:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply if at the time of the offense
the motor vehicle was stolen and the theft was reported to the appropriate
police authority within twenty four (24) hours after the theft was discovered.
(Ord. 09-39, 9-8-2009)
7-4.2-6: TOWING/SEIZURE OF MOTOR VEHICLE:
Whenever a police officer has probable cause to believe that a motor vehicle
subject to seizure and impoundment pursuant to this chapter and the police
officer has arrested the operator or person in physical control of the motor
vehicle for any of the offenses set forth above herein, the police officer
shall provide for the towing of the motor vehicle to a facility authorized by
the village. The police officer shall make a reasonable attempt to notify the
owner or any person identifying themselves as the owner of the motor vehicle,
or any person who is found to be in physical control of the motor vehicle at
the time of the alleged offense, of the fact of the seizure and of the motor
vehicle owner's right to request a preliminary motor vehicle impoundment
hearing to be conducted in accordance with the procedure set forth herein. The
motor vehicle shall be impounded pending the completion of the hearings
provided for herein, unless the owner of the motor vehicle or someone on their
behalf posts with the village a cash bond in the amount of five hundred dollars
($500.00) and pays all applicable towing and storage fees and any existing
fines owed to the village on the motor vehicle or owed by the owner of record.
(Ord. 09-39, 9-8-2009)
7-4.2-7: PRELIMINARY HEARING:
Where the owner of a motor vehicle seized under the provisions of this chapter,
or the designated agent of the owner of the motor vehicle, makes a request to
the chief of police and/or his authorized officer for a preliminary hearing
within twenty four (24) hours after the seizure of the motor vehicle, the chief
of police and/or his authorized officer must conduct a preliminary hearing
within three (3) business days after the request for preliminary hearing is
received by the village; not including Saturdays, Sundays, or legal holidays.
In order for a designated agent to request a preliminary hearing on behalf of
the owner of the motor vehicle, the designated agent must present a written
authorization authorizing the designated agent to act and which is signed by
the owner of the motor vehicle and which is notarized by a notary public. For
purposes of this chapter, the following shall apply:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â All interested persons will be given a reasonable opportunity to be
heard at the preliminary hearing.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â The formal rules of evidence will not apply at the hearing, and hearsay
testimony will be allowed, and shall be admissible.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â If, after the conclusion of the hearing, the chief of police and/or his
authorized officer determines that there is probable cause to believe that the
motor vehicle was used as described in section 7-4.2-2 of this chapter, the
chief of police and/or his authorized officer shall order the continued
impoundment of the motor vehicle, unless the owner of the motor vehicle posts a
cash bond with the village in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00),
plus any towing and storage cost plus existing fines owed to the village on the
motor vehicle or owed by the owner of record.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â If the chief of police and/or his authorized officer determine that
there is not probable cause to believe that the motor vehicle was used as
described in section 7-4.2-2 of this chapter, the motor vehicle will be
returned to the owner of record of the motor vehicle after the owner of record
pays the towing and storage fees. (Ord. 09-39, 9-8-2009)
7-4.2-8: NOTICE OF HEARING:
Within ten (10) days of the motor vehicle's impoundment, the village shall
notify the owner of record of the motor vehicle by United States mail and/or
certified mail, return receipt requested, postage prepaid, of his/her right to
a full hearing before the hearing officer to contest the impoundment; and that,
in the event that the owner of record would like a hearing, he/she must file a
request for such hearing in writing with the village of Broadview police
department. If a written request is not received within thirty (30) days of the
mailing of the notice by the village, then the owner is defaulted ("default
date"). If the motor vehicle owner fails to pay the impoundment fee, towing
charges and storage fees on or before the thirty first day after the expiration
of the default date, then the motor vehicle can be disposed of in the manner
provided by law for the disposition of unclaimed motor vehicles under the
Illinois vehicle code. (Ord. 09-39, 9-8-2009)
7-4.2-9: HEARING:
For purposes of this section, the following shall apply to the owner's hearing:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Unless continued by order of the hearing officer, the hearing shall be
held within thirty (30) days but not more than forty (40) days after a request
for hearing is received by the village of Broadview police department.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â All interested persons will be given a reasonable opportunity to be
heard at the hearing.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â If, after the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer determines
by a preponderance of the evidence that the motor vehicle was used as described
in section 7-4.2-2 of this chapter the hearing officer shall order the
continued impoundment of the motor vehicle until the owner of the motor vehicle
pays to the village a penalty in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00),
plus the towing and storage costs, plus existing fines owed to the village on
the motor vehicle or owed by the owner of record. This amount shall be a debt
due to the village.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â If the owner of record fails to appear at the hearing, the hearing
officer shall enter an order of default in favor of the village, which order
shall require the payment to the village of an administrative penalty of five
hundred dollars ($500.00) plus the towing and storage costs.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â If the hearing officer determines that the motor vehicle was not used
as described in section 7-4.2-2 of this chapter, the motor vehicle will be
returned to the owner of record of the motor vehicle without any penalty; and,
if a cash bond had previously been posted, the cash bond shall be returned.
(Ord. 09-39, 9-8-2009)
7-4.2-10: UNCLAIMED MOTOR VEHICLES:
If the administrative penalty and applicable towing and storage fees are not
paid within thirty five (35) days after the expiration of time in which
administrative review of the hearing officer's final determination may be
sought, or within thirty (30) days after an action seeking administrative
review has been resolved in favor of the village, whichever is applicable, the
motor vehicle shall be deemed unclaimed and shall be disposed of in the manner
provided by law for the disposition of unclaimed motor vehicles under the
Illinois vehicle code. (Ord. 09-39, 9-8-2009)
7-4.2-11: LIENHOLDERS:
Whenever a person or other entity with a lien of record against an impounded
motor vehicle has proof of commenced repossession proceedings, and also
provides the village with a hold harmless letter, possession of the motor
vehicle shall be given to that lienholder upon payment of the five hundred
dollar ($500.00) impoundment fee and all towing and storage costs. (Ord. 09-39,
9-8-2009)
7-4.2-12: ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION:
Other than for the preliminary hearing, section 7-4.2-7 of this chapter, the
code hearing department identified in title 1, chapter 13 of this code shall be
charged with the adjudication of all claims under this chapter. (Ord. 09-39, 9-
8-2009)

7-4-1: NO PARKING PLACES 1 :
At any time it shall be unlawful to permit any vehicle to stand in any of the
following places, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or
in compliance with the directions of a policeman or traffic control device:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â In any intersection.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â In a crosswalk.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Upon any bridge or viaduct, or in any subway or tunnel or the approach
thereto.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet (30')
of a point of the curb immediately opposite the end of a safety zone.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Within thirty feet (30') of a traffic signal, beacon or sign on the
approaching side.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Within twenty feet (20') of any intersection or crosswalk.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â At any place where the standing of a vehicle will reduce the usable
width of the roadway for moving traffic to less than eighteen feet (18').
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â At any place where the vehicle would block the use of a driveway.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad grade
crossing.
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â Within twenty feet (20') of a driveway entrance to any Fire Department
station; and on the side of the street opposite the entrance to any such
station, within seventy five feet (75') of such entrance when properly
signposted.
Â Â Â L.Â Â Â On any sidewalk or parkway.
Â Â Â M.Â Â Â At any place where official signs prohibit parking. (Ord. 2006-04, 2-
22-2006)

7-4-2: GENERAL PARKING RESTRICTIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Parking At Curbs, Angle Parking: No vehicle shall be parked with the
left side of such vehicle next to the curb, except on one-way streets, and it
shall be unlawful to stand or park any vehicle in a street other than parallel
with the curb and with the two (2) right wheels of the vehicle within twelve
inches (12") of the regularly established curb line, except that upon those
streets that have been marked for angle parking, vehicles shall be parked at
the angle to the curb indicated by such marks.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Peddling: It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street from
which vehicle merchandise is sold, however, said vehicles may stand or park for
such length of time as it is necessary to complete such sale or sales,
thereafter such vehicles must move.
Vehicles used for sale of merchandise are hereby prohibited on the Village
streets from the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M.
and said vehicles are hereby prohibited from ringing bells or making other
noise to attract customers.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Sale Of Vehicles: It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on the
street for the purpose of displaying it for sale.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Trailers And Truck Tractors:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â No person shall park any vehicle on any street in the Village to
which is attached a trailer for hauling except as may be allowed for loading
and unloading, which loading and unloading shall be done as expeditiously as
possible. Said trailer must remain attached to the truck or otherwise properly
anchored so as to not damage the street, sidewalk or other Village-owned
property or right-of-way. Any trailer, whether being actively loaded or
unloaded, shall not be parked on any street in the Village for more than four
(4) hours unless said owner or operator of the trailer gets prior written
permission from the Villageâ€™s police department. Any trailer parked in
violation of this section may be impounded as provided in this title.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â No person shall leave any trailer under his control unattended, and
no trailers shall be parked on municipal property, including but not limited to
Village-owned rights-of-way at any time without prior written permission of the
Village and without taking all required precautions so as to not damage the
Village owned property, including but not limited to Village-owned rights-of-
way. Any unattended trailer may be impounded as provided in this title.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â No truck tractor may be parked on any Village street or alley at any
time, unless an overnight parking permit has been purchased for the truck
tractor and is properly displayed as required by section
7-4-2-2 of this section
7-4-2. For purposes of this section, "truck tractor" is defined as every motor
vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing other vehicles and not so
constructed as to carry a load other than a part of the weight of the vehicle
and load so drawn. Trailers are not allowed to be parked on Village streets
without written approval by the Village, subject to conditions set forth by the
Village.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Alleys: It shall be unlawful to let any motor vehicle stand or park in
any alley in the Village at any time.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Cab And Bus Stands: No vehicle other than a licensed taxicab shall be
parked in any area designated by ordinance as a cab stand; and no vehicle other
than a bus shall be parked in a place so designated as a bus loading zone.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Double Parking Trucks: No person shall stop, stand or park any truck,
tractor, semitrailer, trailer or bus on the roadway side of any vehicle stopped
or parked at the edge or curb of a street.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Overnight Parking:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Overnight Parking Prohibited; Exceptions: No person shall park any
vehicle on any street for a period of time longer than thirty (30) minutes
between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M. of
any day, except physicians on emergency calls, unless that person has purchased
and is properly displaying an overnight parking permit as provided for in
section
7-4-2-2 of this section
7-4-2. The Chief of Police or any other person authorized by the Chief of
Police may grant special overnight parking permission to those persons
requesting it, and may also designate where those persons receiving the
permission shall park their vehicle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Overnight Parking In Municipal Parking Lots: No person shall park
any vehicle in any Municipal parking lot for a period of time longer than
thirty (30) minutes between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and five
o'clock (5:00) A.M. of any day unless that person has purchased a parking
permit as provided for in section
7-4-2-2 of this section
7-4-2. The Chief of Police or any person authorized by said Chief may grant
special overnight parking permission to those persons requesting it, and may
also require those persons receiving this parking permission to register their
vehicles on forms provided by the Police Department.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Parking In Municipal Parking Lots After Snowfall: No person shall park
any vehicle or allow any vehicle to remain parked in any Municipal parking lot
after a snowfall of two inches (2") or more. Any police officer is hereby
authorized to remove or cause to be removed by a towing service any vehicle
parked in any Municipal parking lot in violation of this subsection. The owner
or operator of such removed vehicle will be responsible for all towing and
storage costs.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â In Residential Front Yards: No person shall let stand or park any
vehicle on that portion of the front yard which lies between the building used
for residential purposes or for apartment purposes, less than three (3) units,
and the front lot line, except on side driveways which are not wider than
twelve feet (12').
Â Â Â K.Â Â Â Parking Restricted In Specified Places For The Handicapped: It shall be
unlawful to park any vehicle in an area restricted by sign to parking for
handicapped persons only unless the vehicle is equipped with a duly authorized
handicapped license plate or identification card or sticker.
The Board of Trustees shall designate certain parking areas within Municipal
parking lots as restricted to handicapped persons only from time to time upon
recommendation of the Safety Committee.
(Ord. 2018-20, 8-20-2018; amd. Ord. CO-2024-9, 5-20-2024)
7-4-2-1: SNOW REMOVAL:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â It is hereby declared and proclaimed that it is necessary to the public
health, safety and welfare that the streets of the Village be cleared of snow,
and if the clearing of snow is impeded and delayed by vehicles parked on the
streets, such impediment is detrimental to the health, safety and welfare of
the public. Accordingly, the following parking regulations regarding snow
removal shall be in effect:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Whenever there has been a snow event in excess of two inches (2"),
in order not to delay the cleaning of streets, all vehicles parked upon the
streets of the Village shall be removed by the owners in a timely manner.
Vehicles parked on a Village street after a snow event in excess of two inches
(2") may be issued a parking citation pursuant to this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â If such vehicles are not removed from the street after a snow event
in excess of two inches (2"), and after ticketing, then said vehicles shall be
towed pursuant to subsection 6-8-4C of this Code.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The Village shall post signs as necessary to provide notification of
the provisions of this section. (Ord. 2018-20, 8-20-2018)

dollars ($30.00) per month, unless the purchaser buys a 6-month supply of

Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Compliance With Laws And Village Ordinances: All vehicles displaying a
placard must be parked, operated, and kept in compliance with this Code, State
law, and Federal law, including but not limited to and by way of example snow
removal parking restrictions, street cleaning parking restrictions, license and
registration requirements, and abandonment prohibitions.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Violations: Violations of this section shall include but not be limited
to parking in a zone without a permit, parking in the wrong zone, failing to
properly display a placard, displaying a false or fraudulent placard, failing
to display a placard with the proper monthly sticker (or other item to identify
the month) affixed. Violations of this section shall be subject to a minimum
fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) and a maximum fine of seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00). Each day shall constitute a separate violation.
(Ord. 2018-20, 8-20-2018)

7-4-6: VIOLATIONS; NOTICE; ADJUDICATION; DETERMINATIONS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Purpose: The stated purpose of this section is to provide a fair and
efficient enforcement of village of Broadview vehicular standing, parking, and
condition of vehicle regulation violation(s), through an administrative
adjudication of violation(s) of village ordinances regulating the standing,
parking, and condition of vehicles within the geographic boundaries of the
village and a schedule of uniform fines and penalties and authority and
procedures for collection of unpaid fines and penalties.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Compliance Violation: For purposes of this section "compliance
violation" means a violation of a village regulation governing the condition or
use of equipment on a vehicle or governing the display of a village vehicle
license or village sticker.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Administrative Composition: The system of administrative
adjudication of vehicular standing, parking, and compliance, regulation
violation(s) shall provide for a traffic compliance administrator, as selected
by the village president, and hearing officer with the power, authority and
limitations as are hereinafter set forth.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Traffic Compliance Administrator: The traffic compliance administrator,
and/or their designee, shall be selected by the village president and
empowered, authorized and directed to:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Operate and manage the system of administrative adjudication of
vehicular standing, parking, and compliance regulation violation(s).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Adopt, distribute and process standing, parking, and compliance
violation notices and other notices as may be required under this section or as
may be reasonably required to carry out the purpose of this section.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Collect monies paid as fines and/or penalties assessed after a final
determination of vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation
violation(s) liability.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Certify copies of final determination(s) of standing, parking, and
compliance regulation violation(s) liability and factual report(s) verifying
that the final determination of standing, parking, and compliance regulation
violation(s) liability was issued in accordance with this section and 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Certify reports to the secretary of state concerning initiation of
suspension of driving privileges in accordance with the provisions of this
section, hereinafter set forth, and those of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
6-306.5, hereinafter adopted.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Review final determination(s) of vehicular standing, parking, and
compliance regulation violation(s) liability, validity of notices of impending
impoundment or validity of notice of impending driver's license suspension, in
an administrative review capacity in accordance with the provisions of this
section, hereinafter set forth.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Promulgate rules and regulations reasonably required to operate and
maintain the administrative adjudication system hereby created.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â Collect unpaid fines and penalties by filing complaints in the
circuit court or selecting or appointing an individual or agency to act on
behalf of the village in filing complaints seeking judgments for unpaid fines
or penalties and pursuit of all postjudgment remedies available by current law.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Hearing Officer: The hearing officer shall be empowered and is hereby
authorized and directed to:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Preside over the administrative hearings, established herein, as the
adjudicator.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Administer oaths.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Issue subpoenas to secure the attendance of witnesses and production
of relevant papers or documentation.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Assess fines, penalties or community service for the violation of
vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) as are
established herein.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Make final determination of:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â Vehicular standing, parking and compliance regulation violation
(s) liability.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Validity of notice of impending impoundment.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Validity of notice of impending driver's license suspension in

Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Provide for the accurate recording of the administrative

7-4-7: ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Procedure: The system of administrative adjudication of vehicular
standing, parking, and compliance regulation violation(s) shall be in
accordance with the following procedures and final determination(s) of
vehicular standing, parking, and compliance regulation violation(s) liability,
validity of notice of impending impoundment, validity of notice of impending
driver's license suspension. The immobilization and impoundment of a vehicle
and collections shall be made only in accordance with the provisions set forth
herein.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Violation Notice: Vehicular standing, parking, and compliance
regulation violation(s) notice(s) ("violation notice(s)") shall be issued by
the person(s) authorized herein and shall contain information and shall be
served, certified by the authorized person and have evidentiary admissibility
as is hereinafter set forth.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Authorization: All full time, part time, auxiliary police and community
service officers, as well as other specifically appointed individuals, shall
have the authority to issue violation(s) notices.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Detection Of Violations: Any individual authorized hereby to issue
violation notices and who detects a violation of any section of any applicable
village ordinance, shall issue a notice of violation thereof and shall make
service thereof as is hereinafter set forth.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Form Of Violation Notice: The vehicular standing, parking, and
compliance regulation "violation notice" shall contain, but shall not be
limited to, the following information:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The date, time and place of the violation (date of issuance).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The particular vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation
violated.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Vehicle make and state registration number.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The fine and any penalty which may be assessed for late payment for
having failed to appear at scheduled hearings.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The signature and identification number of the person issuing the
notice.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â A section entitled "administrative hearing" which shall clearly set
forth that the registered owner or lessee shall appear at the administrative
hearing to contest the validity of the violation notice on the date and at the
time and place as specified in the violation notice if the fine on the
violation notice is not paid at least five (5) days prior to the date of the
scheduled administrative hearing., or if paid online, two (2) days prior to the
scheduled administrative hearing.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â The date, time and place of an administrative hearing at which the
violation may be contested on its merits.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â A section clearly indicating that payment of the indicated fine up
to five (5) days prior to the date of the scheduled initial administrative
hearing, or if paid online, two (2) days prior to the scheduled administrative
hearing, shall operate as a final disposition of the violation and no late fee
shall be imposed and an appearance at the administrative hearing is not
required. Fines paid in-person on the date of the hearing shall not be subject
to any fees or penalties.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 9.Â Â Â That payment of the indicated fine and any late payment penalty
instituted after the initial administrative hearing shall operate as a final
disposition of the violation.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 10.Â Â Â A section setting forth procedures for nonresidents to contest
violations of this chapter.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Service Of Violation Notice: Service of the violation(s) notice(s)
shall be made by the person issuing such notice by:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Affixing the original or a facsimile of the notice to an unlawfully
standing or parked vehicle, or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Handing the notice to the operator of the vehicle, if he or she is
present.; or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Mailing the notice to the address of the registered owner or lessee
of the cited vehicle as recorded with the Secretary of State or the lessor of
the motor vehicle within thirty (30) days after the Secretary of State or the
lessor of the motor vehicle notifies the village of the identity of the owner
or lessee of the vehicle, but not later than ninety (90) days after the date of
the violation, except that in the case of a lessee of a motor vehicle, service
of a parking, standing, or compliance violation notice may occur no later than
two hundred and ten (210) days after the violation.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Certification Of Violation Notice: The correctness of facts contained
in the vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s)
notice(s) shall be certified by the person issuing said notice by:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Signature: Signing his/her name to the notice(s) at the time of
service, or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Computer Device: In the case of a notice produced by a computer
device, by signing a single certificate, to be kept by the traffic compliance
administrator, attesting to the correctness of all notices produced by the
device while under his/her control.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Retention: The original or a facsimile of the violation(s) notice(s)
shall be retained by the village and kept as a record in the ordinary course of
business and in compliance with the Illinois Local Records Act, 50 ILCS 205/1,
et seq.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Prima Facie Evidence: Any violation(s) notice(s) issued, signed and
served in accordance herewith, or a copy of the notice, or a copy of the
computer generated record shall be prima facie true and correct and shall be
prima facie evidence of the correctness of the facts shown on the notice.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Admissibility: The violation(s) notice(s), a copy(ies) or a computer
generated record, shall be admissible in any subsequent administrative or legal
proceeding. (Ord. 09-66, 12-21-2009; amd. Ord. CO-2021-12, 8-16-2021)
7-4-8: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Process: An administrative hearing to adjudicate the alleged standing,
parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) on its merits as allowed by this
chapter and the code hearing department procedures in title 1, chapter 13 of
this code:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Shall be required of the registered owner or operator of the "cited
vehicle", pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3 or the lessee
of the "cited vehicle", pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-1306,
incorporated herein by reference.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Shall be at the date, time and place as is set forth in the
violation notice issued and served, or such additional notices issued in
accordance with this chapter. Violators shall be required to appear at an
administrative hearing and failure to appear at the scheduled hearing date will
result in a "final determination of liability" as hereinafter set forth.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Shall be recorded.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Shall culminate in a determination of liability or nonliability made
by the hearing officer, who shall consider testimony and other evidence without
the application of the formal or technical rules of evidence. The hearing
officer shall, upon a determination of liability, assess fines and penalties in
accordance with this chapter. The hearing officer shall be empowered to
administer oaths and to secure by subpoena both the attendance and testimony of
witnesses and the production of relevant books and papers.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Persons appearing to contest the alleged standing, parking, or
compliance violation on its merits may be represented by counsel at their own
expense.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Any party may request a continuance for good cause shown, however,
any such request for a continuance may be granted or denied at the sole
discretion of the adjudicator.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Final Determination: The final determination of any matter which may be
decided by the hearing officer may be reviewed as is hereinafter set forth
through a petition to set aside or pursuant to the Illinois Administrative
Review Law, 735 ILCS 5/3-101, et seq. (Ord. 09-66, 12-21-2009; amd. Ord. CO-
2021-12, 8-16-2021)
7-4-9: FAILURE TO APPEAR AT HEARING:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Additional Notice: Upon failure of the registered owner or lessee of
the "cited vehicle" to appear at the administrative hearing indicated in the
vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) notice(s)
the traffic compliance administrator shall send or cause to be sent an
additional notice which:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Shall be sent to the registered owner or lessee of the "cited
vehicle" at the address as is recorded with the secretary of state.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Shall be sent to the lessee of the "cited vehicle" at the address
last known to the lessor of the "cited vehicle" at the time of the lease.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Shall be sent by first class mail, postage prepaid.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Service Of Notice: Service of the additional notice sent in accordance
herewith shall be complete as of the date of deposit in the United States mail.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Form Of Additional Notice: Upon the failure of the registered owner or
lessee of the "cited vehicle" to appear at the hearing set forth in the
vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s), additional
notice shall be mailed. The additional notice sent in accordance herewith shall
be in the following sequence and contain, but not be limited to, the following
information:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Date and location of violation cited in the vehicular standing,
parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) notice(s).
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Particular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violated.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Vehicle make and state registration number.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Fine and any penalty that may be assessed for late payment.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â Notice to the registered owner or lessee of their current payment
status, other than paid in full.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 6.Â Â Â Date, time and place of the administrative hearing at which the
alleged violation may be contested on its merits.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 7.Â Â Â Statement that failure to either pay the fine and any applicable
penalty or failure to appear at the hearing on its merits on the date and at
the time and place specified will result in a final determination of vehicle
standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) liability for the
"cited" violation in the amount of the fine and penalty indicated.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 8.Â Â Â Statement that upon the occurrence of a final determination of
vehicular standing, parking, or compliance violation(s) liability for the
failure, and the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust, available
administrative or judicial procedures for review, any unpaid fine or penalty
will constitute a debt due and owing the village. (Ord. 09-66, 12-21-2009)
7-4-10: DETERMINATION OF LIABILITY:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Final Notice Of Determination: A notice of final determination of
vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) liability
shall be served upon the violator directly at the time of the hearing or mailed
via first class mail following an appearance by the violator and a
determination of liability. A notice of final determination of vehicular
standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) liability shall be
sent via first class mail in the event that the violator fails to appear at the
initial or second administrative hearing date and upon the conclusion of any
administrative and/or judicial review, as is hereinafter set forth. The notice
shall contain, but not be limited to, the following information and warnings:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â A statement that the unpaid fine and any penalty assessed is a debt
due and owing the village.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â A warning that failure to pay the fine and any penalty due and owing
the village within the time specified may result in the village filing a
complaint in the circuit court to have the unpaid fine or penalty rendered a
judgment in accordance with 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3(f),
incorporated herein by reference.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â A warning that the vehicle owned by the person and located within
the village may be impounded for failure to pay fines or penalties for three
(3) or more vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violations.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â A warning that the person's driver's license may be suspended for
failure to pay fines or penalties for ten (10) or more vehicular standing or
parking violations under 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-306.5, incorporated
herein by reference.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 5.Â Â Â The notice shall also state that the person may obtain a photostatic
copy of an original ticket imposing a fine or penalty by sending a self-
addressed, stamped envelope to the municipality along with a request for a
photostatic copy.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Final Determination Of Liability: A final determination of vehicular
standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) liability shall:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Occur thirty five (35) days following the failure to pay the total
assessed fine or penalty after the hearing officer's final determination of
vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) liability
and the exhaustion of or the failure to exhaust any administrative review
procedures hereinafter set forth, or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Where a person fails to appear at an administrative hearing provided
to contest the alleged violation(s) on the date and at the time and place
specified in a prior served or mailed notice, the hearing officer's
determination of vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation
violation(s) liability shall become final;
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Upon denial of a timely petition to set aside that determination, or
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Upon the expiration of the period for filing a petition to set aside
without a filing having been made. (Ord. 09-66, 12-21-2009)
7-4-11: PETITION TO SET ASIDE:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Process For Setting Aside A Determination: A petition to set aside a
determination of vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation
violation(s) liability may be filed by a person owing an unpaid fine or penalty
in the manner and subject to the restrictions and grounds hereinafter set
forth:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â A written petition to vacate a determination of liability must be
filed in the village police department within, but not later than, twenty one
(21) days from the date the determination of liability is made.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The hearing officer or traffic compliance administrator shall act
upon the petition(s) timely filed and render a decision thereon within thirty
(30) days of the date filed.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â The grounds for setting aside a determination of liability shall be
limited to the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â The person against whom the determination of liability is made
was not the owner or lessee of the "cited vehicle" on the date the vehicular
standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) notice(s) was issued.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â The person having paid the fine or penalty prior to the
determination of liability for the violation(s) in question.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Excusable failure to appear at or request a new date for a
hearing.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Process After Setting Aside A Determination: Should the determination
of liability be set aside, the traffic compliance administrator shall:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Notify the registered owner, or lessee, as the case may be, that the
determination of liability has been set aside.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Notify the registered owner, or lessee, as the case may be, of a
date, time and place for a hearing on the merits of the violation for which
determination of liability has been set aside.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Notice of setting aside of the determination of liability and the
notice of the hearing date shall be by first class mail, postage prepaid to the
address set forth on the petition to set aside the determination of liability.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Service of the notice shall be complete on the date the notice(s) is
deposited in the United States mail. (Ord. 09-66, 12-21-2009)
7-4-12: NONRESIDENT PROCEDURES:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Procedures: Nonresidents of the Village who have been served vehicular
standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) notice(s), in
accordance with this chapter, shall appear at the initially scheduled
administrative hearing to contest the alleged violation on its merits, as would
a resident, or shall contest the validity without personally appearing at an
administrative hearing by:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Filing a notarized statement of facts specifying the grounds for
challenging the violation notice which must be filed with the Traffic
Compliance Administrator postmarked within ten (10) days of the violation
notice issuance. The request shall be deemed filed upon receipt by the Traffic
Compliance Administrator. After the expiration of the ten (10) days after the
issuance of the violation notice, a non-resident may not file said affidavit
and instead must personally appear for said adjudication. Said personal
appearance may be through counsel.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The Hearing Officer shall make a decision based upon the facts set
forth in the notarized statement of facts filed by the nonresident as well as
the facts set forth on the violation notice.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Notice of the determination of the Hearing Officer shall be served
upon the nonresident by first class mail, postage prepaid, addressed to the
nonresident at the address set forth in the statement of facts submitted.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â Service of the notice shall be complete on the date the notice is
placed in the United States mail.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Applicability Of Other Provisions To Nonresidents: All other provisions
of this chapter shall apply equally to nonresidents of this Village. (Ord. 09-
66, 12-21-2009; amd. Ord. CO-2021-12, 8-16-2021)

FINE PAYMENT SCHEDULE

     * The fine for violations of Section

Step Having failed to pay the fine amount specified in step 1, the fine amount, if
2.   paid after the initial hearing and prior to the end of the second hearing will
     be:
Â    1.Â Â Â General standing, parking or compliance violations, one hundred dollars
     ($100.00);
Â    2.Â Â Â Disabled parking violations, three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00).
Step Having failed to pay the fine amount specified in step 2 and upon the finding of
3.   liability for the violation, after failure to appear at the second hearing, the
     fine amount will be:
Â    1.Â Â Â General standing, parking or compliance violations, one hundred fifty

Â    2.Â Â Â Disabled parking violations, three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00).
Â 
The fines and penalties herein set forth shall be uniformly applied for each
violation of this chapter.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Immobilization Fee: If a motor vehicle has been immobilized pursuant to
this chapter, the owner of record of the motor vehicle is responsible for the
payment of an immobilization fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) ("immobilization
fee") in addition to the other fines, fees and expenses set forth in this
chapter.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Impound/Towing Fee: If a motor vehicle has been subject to towing and
impoundment under this chapter the owner of record of said motor vehicle shall
be liable to the Village for an impoundment fee in an amount of fifty dollars
($50.00) ("impoundment fee") plus the payment of the actual costs charged to
the Village by the towing company for towing fees, and the payment of a storage
fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each day of storage or the actual cost
charged to the Village if not stored by the Village (whichever fee is greater).
(Ord. 2018-12, 5-7-2018; amd. Ord. CO-2021-12, 8-16-2021; Ord. CO-2024-9, 5-20-
2024)

7-4-15: IMMOBILIZATION, IMPOUNDMENT AND TOWING:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Procedure For A Registered Owner Having Three Or More Unpaid Vehicular
Violations And For Other Violations Of This Chapter: Any motor vehicle whose
registered owner has been determined to be liable for three (3) or more
vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s), for which
the fines or penalties assessed remain unpaid, or who has violated Section
7-4-2(D)(1) and (2) related to trailer parking, may be immobilized or towed and
impounded if:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The traffic compliance administrator has determined that a person
has been determined to be liable for three (3) or more vehicular standing,
parking, or compliance regulation violation(s), the fines or penalties for
which remain unpaid, or for a violations of Section 7-4-2(D)(1) and (2)..
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The person determined to be liable for three (3) or more violations
of this code or for a violations of Section7-4-2(D)(1) and (2) is the
registered owner of a motor vehicle.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â A pretowing notice has been sent to the registered owner of the
motor vehicle which contains, but shall not be limited to, the following:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â That a final determination has been made on three (3) or more
vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s), the fines
and penalties for which remain unpaid. However, for violations of Section 7-4-2
(D)(1) and (2), a pre-towing notice shall not be required and the trailer may
be impounded without a final determination subject to the hearing procedure
provided herein (See Section 7-4-15(B)).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â A listing of the violation(s) for which the person has been
determined to be liable, which shall include for each violation:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (1)Â Â Â The vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation
violation notice number.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (2)Â Â Â Date of issuance.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â (3)Â Â Â Total amount of fine(s) and penalty(ies) assessed.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â That the motor vehicle(s) owned by the person and located within
the village is subject to immobilization and/or towing and impoundment if the
fines and penalties are not paid within fourteen (14) days of the date of the
notice.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â d.Â Â Â That the registered owner may contest the validity of the notice
by fully completing and signing the request for hearing portion of one notice
and by filing the request for hearing with the traffic compliance administrator
within, but not later than fourteen (14) days of the date of the notice.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â e.Â Â Â The request for hearing shall be deemed filed upon receipt by the
traffic compliance administrator.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â f.Â Â Â That if the motor vehicle has been immobilized pursuant to this
chapter, the owner of record of the motor vehicle is responsible for the
payment of an immobilization fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) ("immobilization
fee") in addition to the other fines, fees and expenses set forth in this
chapter. If the motor vehicle owner fails to pay the immobilization fee and
fails to act within the time parameters set forth herein, the motor vehicle
will be towed and impounded pursuant to this chapter.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 4.Â Â Â The motor vehicle(s) of the registered owner to whom notice is sent
has failed to make payment of the fines or penalties as specified in the notice
and no timely request for hearing has been filed with the traffic compliance
administrator to contest the validity of the notice.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Request For Hearing To Contest Validity Of Pretowing Notice:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Upon the receipt of the request for hearing to contest the validity
of the pretowing notice of impending immobilization or towing and impoundment,
or the impoundment of a trailer pursuant to Section
7-4-2(D)(1) and (2), the traffic compliance administrator shall schedule an
administrative hearing to contest the validity of said notice, by disproving
liability for the unpaid final determinations of parking, standing, or
compliance violation liability listed on the notice, on the next available
hearing date, but in no case shall the hearing be scheduled later than sixty
(60) days after the request for hearing is filed.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â The traffic compliance administrator shall serve notice of the
hearing date upon the registered owner.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â Notice shall be sent by first class mail, postage prepaid to the
address as is set forth on the request for hearing.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â c.Â Â Â Service of the notice shall be complete on the date it is placed
in the United States mail.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The registered owner of a vehicle(s) immobilized or towed and
impounded under this chapter, shall have the right to a prompt administrative
hearing without the requirement of payment of outstanding fines and penalties
for which final determination has been made.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Immobilization And Towing: If a motor vehicle is determined to be
eligible for immobilization and is subsequently immobilized pursuant to this
chapter, a notice shall be placed on the vehicle, in a conspicuous manner,
warning that such vehicle has been immobilized and that any attempt to move the
vehicle may result in damage to the vehicle. The notice shall state how to
obtain information regarding release of the immobilization device and the
vehicle. The notice shall also state that payment of all fines owed; or the
posting of a bond with acceptable security in an amount of all fines and fees
owed to the village; the payment of the immobilization fee; and the request for
a court hearing on the same will result in the release of the vehicle. If forty
eight (48) hours after the immobilization, the owner has not sought release of
the vehicle, the vehicle may be towed to a specified location for impoundment.
(Ord. 09-66, 12-21-2009; amd. CO-2024-9, 5-20-2024)
7-4-16: POSTTOWING NOTICE:
The traffic compliance administrator shall serve a posttowing notice upon the
registered owner of a vehicle immobilized or towed and impounded under this
chapter which notice shall contain, but not be limited to, the following
information:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Date of immobilization or towing and date of impoundment.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Location of vehicle.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â That the vehicle was immobilized under this chapter for nonpayment of
fines or penalties assessed for the violation of three (3) or more violations
of vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation(s) for which the
registered owner has been determined liable and notified of impending
immobilization or towing and impoundment.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Date of pretowing notice of impending immobilization or towing and
impoundment.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â That the registered owner may contest the validity of the
immobilization or towing and impoundment by completing and signing the request
for hearing portion of the notice and filing the request for hearing with the
traffic compliance administrator within, but not later than, fourteen (14) days
of the date of the notice which shall be deemed filed upon receipt by the
traffic compliance administrator.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â That if the vehicle is not claimed and released pursuant to this
section, within thirty (30) days after the date of the posttowing notice, then
the vehicle shall be determined to be abandoned and shall be sold at public
sale or disposed of pursuant to section
6-8-7 of this code.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â That if the motor vehicle has been immobilized, towed and impounded
pursuant to this chapter, the owner of record of the motor vehicle is
responsible for the payment of the immobilization fee of fifty dollars
($50.00), the payment of the impoundment fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) and the
payment of the actual costs charged to the village by the towing company for
towing fees, and the payment of a storage fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00)
for each day of storage or the actual cost charged to the village if not stored
by the village (whichever fee is greater) in addition to any and all fines and
penalties owed to the village as it relates to the motor vehicle or otherwise
owed to the village by the motor vehicle owner.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â That in order for the village to release the motor vehicle to the owner
of record, the owner of record must pay fines, penalties, fees and charges as
defined in this chapter or successfully contest the towing and impoundment as
described in section
7-4-17 of this chapter and obtain an order from the hearing officer to that
effect. Whenever a person or other entity with a lien of record against an
impounded motor vehicle has proof of commenced repossession proceedings, and
also provides the village with a hold harmless letter, possession of the motor
vehicle shall be given to that lienholder upon payment of the five hundred
dollars ($500.00) impoundment fee and all towing and storage costs.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â That prior to releasing the motor vehicle to the lawful owner or person
entitled to possess the motor vehicle such person must possess a valid
operator's license, proof of ownership or registration, and proof of liability
insurance. However, if the vehicle is being towed from the location of
impoundment, only proof of ownership must be provided. (Ord. 09-66, 12-21-2009;
amd. Ord. CO-2021-12, 8-16-2021)
7-4-17: CONTEST VALIDITY OF IMMOBILIZATION OR TOWING AND IMPOUNDMENT:
Â Â Â A.Â Â Â Hearing: Upon the receipt of the request for hearing to contest the
validity of the immobilization or towing and impoundment, the traffic
compliance administrator shall schedule an administrative hearing to contest
the validity of the immobilization or towing and impoundment on the next
available hearing date or if sooner scheduled by the traffic compliance
administrator for good cause shown, but in no case shall the hearing be
scheduled later than sixty (60) days after the request for hearing is filed.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â The traffic compliance administrator shall serve notice of the
hearing date upon the registered owner.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â Notice shall be sent by certified or first class mail, postage
prepaid to the address as is set forth on the request for hearing.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 3.Â Â Â Service of the notice shall be complete on the date it is placed in
the United States mail.
Â Â Â B.Â Â Â Vehicle Ownership, Prima Facie Proof: The fact that an automobile which
is in violation of this code is registered in the name of a person shall be
considered prima facie proof that such person was in control of the automobile
at the time of such parking.
Â Â Â C.Â Â Â Final Administrative Decision: An order entered after the hearing to
contest the validity of the immobilization or towing and impoundment is a final
administrative decision within the meaning of 735 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
3-101 et seq., incorporated herein by reference.
Â Â Â D.Â Â Â Release Of Vehicle: A vehicle impounded pursuant to this chapter shall
be released to the registered owner thereof, or his, her or its agent, upon
payment of the fines and penalties for the underlying violations due and owing
the village as specified in the posttowing notice as described in section
7-4-16 of this chapter and the payment of towing charges and accrued daily
storage charges, immobilization fees and impoundment fees as more fully
described in section
7-4-13 of this chapter or upon order of the hearing officer following the
hearing contesting the validity of the impoundment.
Â Â Â E.Â Â Â Judicial Review: Judicial review of final determinations of vehicular
standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) and final
administrative decisions issued after hearing(s) regarding vehicle
immobilization or towing and impoundment made under this section shall be
subject to the provisions of the administrative review law as is set forth in
735 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et seq., incorporated herein by
reference.
Â Â Â F.Â Â Â Debt To Village: Any fine, penalty or part of any fine or any penalty
assessed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and remaining unpaid
after the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust administrative remedies
created under this section and the conclusion of any judicial review procedures
shall be a debt due and owing the village and, as such, may be collected in
accordance with the applicable law. Payment in full of any fine or penalty
resulting from a standing, parking, or compliance violation shall constitute a
final disposition of that violation.
Â Â Â G.Â Â Â Judgment: The traffic compliance administrator shall, following the
expiration of the period within which administrative or judicial review may be
sought for a final determination of violation, take all necessary action(s),
execute all required documents and collect monies from the person(s) who has
been assessed fines or penalties which remain unpaid and have become a debt due
and owing the village in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3 plus costs by:
Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.Â Â Â Filing a complaint in the circuit court for the entry of a judgment
against the person for whom a final determination of standing, parking, or
compliance regulation violation(s) liability has been made.
Â Â Â Â Â Â 2.Â Â Â The complaint filed by the traffic compliance administrator or
individual or agency on behalf of the village seeking entry of a judgment
against the registered owner of the motor vehicle for unpaid fines and/or
penalties pursuant to a final determination of standing, parking, or compliance
regulation violation(s) shall have appended:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â a.Â Â Â A certified copy of the final determination of the standing,
parking, or compliance regulation violation(s).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â b.Â Â Â A certification that recites facts sufficient to show that the
final determination of standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s)
was issued in accordance with this section and 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/11-208.3.
Â Â Â H.Â Â Â Lienholders: Whenever a person or other entity with a lien of record
against an impounded motor vehicle has proof of commenced repossession
proceedings, and also provides the village with a hold harmless letter,
possession of the motor vehicle shall be given to that lienholder upon payment
of any immobilization or impoundment fees, all towing and storage cost and all
other charges, fines and penalties specified in this chapter.
Â Â Â I.Â Â Â Consolidation Of Multiple Final Determinations: Nothing shall prevent
the village from consolidating multiple final determinations of standing,
parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) liability in an action in the
circuit court against an individual and from pursuing all available remedies,
allowed by law, to collect money judgments.
Â Â Â J.Â Â Â Maximum Fines: Service of process and a copy of the complaint may be
served upon the person against whom a judgment is sought under the provisions
of this chapter by any method provided under 735 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
2-203, incorporated by reference, or by certified mail, return receipt
requested, provided the total amount of fines and penalties for final
determination of standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) does
not exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). (Ord. 09-66, 12-21-
2009)

7-5-7: LIMITED LOAD STREETS:
Whenever the weight of vehicles permitted on a street is limited by ordinance
and signs indicating such limitations are posted, it shall be unlawful to
operate a vehicle in excess of such weight on such street, except for the
purpose of making delivery or picking up a load, in which case such vehicle may
be driven on such street for not more than the minimum distance necessary for
the purpose. (1987 Code)
7-5-8: POSTING SIGNS:
The Chief of Police or any other person designated by the President or Board of
Trustees shall post or cause to be posted suitable signs for all through
streets, one-way streets or alleys and stop intersections. (1987 Code)
